question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. I've learnt, at least the foundations of seven different religions and traditions. They're all very interesting and offer valuable insight on how to approach different aspects of the good life.2. I've learnt to pick and choose more effectively. The seven different traditions and religions offer important lessons on different aspects of life. I agree with some, and disagree with others. For example, I appreciate the pragmatism of Stoicism (I think of myself as stoic to an extent), but some things to me are not indifferents, they're simply bad. I prefer Confucianism's focus on ritual in dealing with loss.3. I've learnt to appreciate writing more. We did a lot of writing in this class, particularly with the jounral entries and the many notes and questions we did in class. It's brought back a lesson I learnt from my old writing teaching: "writing is thinking". I've done a lot of thinking through writing in this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The class truly has the power to transform ideas. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to understand different points of view and relate with each other to find common ground in thought. In light of several issues concurrently happening around the world, this class was a breath of fresh air that allowed civil conversation organized by the amazing professors. The retreat also was placed at such a perfect time when I was studying for midterms, helping me escape the Duke bubble. Life at Duke isn't in any way representative of how real life is meant to be viewed or taken. Life is meant to be good. And this class reminded me of how important human interaction and conversation is.

response_text:

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having 8 different lecturers who were each so passionately involved with their respective traditions was genuinely so interesting and engaging every lecture. This method of changing topics every class made it easy to understand distinctions between units and ideas, and kept me invested in the course. I also really enjoyed having a journal and doing journal entries, as they were very personal and helped me reflect on my views in a very informal way. The dialogue group/dialogue performance was also great, as I got to build relationships with my classmates and produce something fun. The final reflective project and retreat were also great. Overall, having such dynamic meetings and assignments made the course really enjoyable.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) Weekly readings with the questions—really prompted us to actually delve into the readings.
2) Dialogue Groups & DG performances—great way to meet people!
3) THE RETREAT! Such a great embodiment of TI's values, & really helped me relax as a sophomore & meet other people & experience the importance of staying present.
4) Check system for questions & journal entries—removes pressure of thinking in a "correct" way.
5) Dialogue between traditions—having the professors representing the traditions have actual conversations together at the front of the lecture hall.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the lack of communication and expectations between students and the professors has made the class a little less stimulating. The interest I and others would gain from lectures is often overshadowed by the confusion regarding deadlines and grading expectations. I know it is hard to coordinate a class with so many students and teachers, but sometimes assignment due dates feel rushed. I have heard such amazing things about this class and felt a little disappointed with how it actually went. The retreat was absolutely amazing, and I believe the TI program has the potential to keep that energy going the entire class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Learning more about major religions & traditions —> Thinking about my purpose here. Transforming my worldview & my view of my undergraduate experience—what to prioritize, how to proceed with intentionality. —> Realizing the importance of slowing down & being present.The faculty are incredible. The readings were incredible & helped me reframe the way I thought about how I approached life. Guest speaker conversations (with dinner), especially the one focused on the Israel-Hamas War, really helped me ground reflection into the way I approached politics—it made me realize that religion can't really exist independently of politics, which changed the way I thought about political engagement.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Duke students often refer to an easy class as a good class. If you want a relatively easy class take this class. If you want a somewhat intellectually stimulating class, I recommend taking a different course. Though the teachers were interesting, the lack of student engagement will impede your own experience. There is a required overnight retreat and a dialogue section weekly which aren't noted on the course description. This course requires you to submit 2 questions a week on canvas, 10 reflective journal entries, 1 acting performance, and 1 final paper. Overall it is a very manageable class. You get what you put into this course, so know that before enrolling.

Life at Duke isn't in any way representative of how real life is meant to be viewed or taken. Life is meant to be good. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) Weekly readings with the questions—really prompted us to actually delve into the readings.
2) Dialogue Groups & DG performances—great way to meet people!
3) THE RETREAT! Such a great embodiment of TI's values, & really helped me relax as a sophomore & meet other people & experience the importance of staying present.
4) Check system for questions & journal entries—removes pressure of thinking in a "correct" way.
5) Dialogue between traditions—having the professors representing the traditions have actual conversations together at the front of the lecture hall.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the lack of communication and expectations between students and the professors has made the class a little less stimulating. I know it is hard to coordinate a class with so many students and teachers, but sometimes assignment due dates feel rushed. I have heard such amazing things about this class and felt a little disappointed with how it actually went. The retreat was absolutely amazing, and I believe the TI program has the potential to keep that energy going the entire class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Duke students often refer to an easy class as a good class. If you want a relatively easy class take this class. If you want a somewhat intellectually stimulating class, I recommend taking a different course. Though the teachers were interesting, the lack of student engagement will impede your own experience. There is a required overnight retreat and a dialogue section weekly which aren't noted on the course description. This course requires you to submit 2 questions a week on canvas, 10 reflective journal entries, 1 acting performance, and 1 final paper. Overall it is a very manageable class. You get what you put into this course, so know that before enrolling.

response_text: I learned about the history of medicine and vaccines. I learned about more about the healthcare system and about the ethics of organ transplants.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the history of medicine, the purpose of medicine, and the potential issues with medicine.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the progression of medicine from ancient times into the modern era of medicine as we know it now. We discussed topics I knew little about beforehand such as health insurance and ethical issues surrounding solid organ transplants.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- thinking about the role of medicine, doctors, patients, and hospitals in society 
- discussion of a variety of ethical and moral issues in healthcare 
- learning about the dynamics of healthcare in the past and currently

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about what it actually means to be a doctor, what the difference is betweeen healing and relieving suffering, and how complex and nuanced our healthcare system is.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course, I truly learned about empathetic patient-physician relationships as well as the complexity of medical decision making in a healthcare setting. Throughout this class, I explored topics such as truth-telling in oncology, imposter syndrome amongst healthcare workers, how past trauma affects patients in the present, mental health disorders, insurance and their effect on healthcare accessibility, and AI technology in healthcare. This class was truly eye-opening because I realized that to truly treat patients you have to consider their background, socioeconomic status, viewpoints, and culture.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was structured so that a team of scholars and medical professionals would come into class and give lectures on different areas. I gained unique perspectives from each professional who specializes in their field and gives us a sneak peek of their expertise through each lecture in the class. Indeed, I felt each lecture was a glimpse into the medical field through a different lens. For example, in one lesson we would learn about the social drivers of health and the different broader forces at play impacting the patient’s health, and in another lecture, we talked about the cultural differences in truth-telling in oncology and medicine. Though we learned a wide range of topics, the content all tied back to the core of medicine: the intricate balance between medical knowledge and treatment, caring for patients as a person, and the ethical responsibilities that guide medical practice.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to develop an understanding of religion and humanitarianism through an anthropological approach. I also learned how to interview others in an ethnographic style. Lastly, I learned more about anthropology's history and anthropological theories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One thing that I learned is the importance of critiquing and not following information blindly. Another thing that I learned is what humanitarianism aid is and how it affects all of us. Also, one thing that I learned is how to conduct a professional interview and analyze it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: thinking about the way different religions think in different time periods, how to interview people, how to collect ethnographic data, class conversations and being able to connect to other people's thoughts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed interviewing skills and learned about ethnographic writing. Also, I learned about the history of humanitarianism and how it interacts with global health and religion (two areas that I had not considered its impacts). Finally, I learned about the importance of critically examining structures and avoiding the usage of the word "inherent" because it takes away from the system's impact and reduces it to the individual (in looking at how "aid economies" manifest in various parts of the world).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
critical consideration of philanthropic organizations/work being done
analysis of the ethics behind charity work
more deeply understanding the intersection between religion and humanitarianism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class I developed my critical thinking skills and learned how to evaluate a specific topics from multiple perspectives. Prior to this class I think I accepted a lot of things for the way that they were, but through this class I've learned to leverage different perspectives and think about one topic in different ways. I also strengthened my reading comprehension skills in interacting with readings before every class and pushing myself to think about them in a high level way in order to be able to contribute/have class discussions be meaningful. I was also able to refine my abilities to write in a concise way because I found that since every class was interesting and full of new thoughts, I had too much to write for each paper and had to condense them down to the most meaningful parts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about humanitarianism, especially unspoken issues, the interview process, which aided my people and communication skills, and time management.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about ways of using ethnography to analyze ways of giving. This included thinking about how other religions might conceptualize giving entirely differently, such as "uncompassionate care." We also learned about humanitarianism more broadly and the way this can intersect with religious beliefs, such as in the case of evangelicals in Uganda. Also, we learned about how different religions handle the ethical questions that arise from power imbalances between givers and receivers, such as the ways in which Liberation Theology emphasized an approach that contextualized inequalities and emphasized rights.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically think and engage in a form of rigorous analysis when reading a cultural anthropology paper on a theory framework or case study by engaging deeply with the argument not only in a logical linear fashion following the paper but to also really think through and challenge the presented ideas. I learned how to read the case studies presented in anthropology papers and analyze and and form my own opinion by engaging with them not only on the author's presented term of the paper but through my own and differing viewpoints. I learned how to write a paper that articulated a clear concise flow of logic while gaining a greater appreciation for the many ways tones and nuances can be layered in an argument.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about the ethics and anthropology of humanitarianism, and learned how to discern advanced readings with many allusions to history, culture, and religion. Furthermore, how to engage in the process of an interview, and the challenges of social hierarchies in doing such. Overall I learned very much from the outside readings and assignments of this class, not only in regards to ethics and global affairs, but about various distinct cultures, religions, and histories which I could not gain from a regular global health class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course facilitated deeper thinking about our systems of humanitarian aid and gave me a new set of anthropologic tools by which to examine the world, introducing such terms such as philanthrocapitalism and biopower (which helped shape my program II!) I was also introduced to new philosophies of giving within different religions such as Islam and Shamanism.

response_text: Professor Dougan's course was one of the most memorable courses I have had in my time at Duke so far. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Anne Allison is fantastic. She is astoundingly brilliant on all fronts, has thought a lot about the topic of hope, and genuinely cares about what your thoughts are on the readings. Her reading-recaps are beyond helpful (she takes dense readings and makes them actually digestible), she is always able to answer questions, and she too applies the thinkers that we learned about early on in the semester on a daily basis. Professor Allison is a major component for why this class was so amazing and I think that she really went above and beyond to facilitate learning, engagement, and understanding in her class. Further, I think that she organized the class in a very intentional way. It was very smart to have thinkers first, then medicine, home, and finally disaster. She clearly thought about the structure of the course and every reading that we did / how it would weave together into conversations in class -- and I really commend her for how it played out throughout the semester. Professor Allison was also extremely available for help outside of class (I personally met with her a bunch) and she was overwhelmingly helpful each time. Finally, I really have appreciated the thought that goes into paper prompts because they prompt critical thinking that is engaging, intellectual, but also fun and enjoyable. Her and Anton did a great job with this -- serious kudos to them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Allison would guide the class through each reading. She would outline the general argument of a reading, draw connections to other readings, and emphasize the key takeaways. Some of the readings were more philosophical and dense, so I appreciated this method of instruction. Professor Allison was also incredibly encouraging. She was excited for us to participate, would help us articulate our points, and would refer back to our comments in later classes. I always felt heard and supported in class.

The structure of the course was amazing: following each episode with readings that discussed the underlying racial phenomena in the episode was smart and a great way to highlight the racial narratives the show is trying to portray. The note-taking is also extremely useful as it provides a resource for students to go back to when they might have forgotten something from a class discussion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

concepts in cultural anthropology: "double bind," the gaze, therapeutic geography

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I completely changed my reading style throughout this course.  We had to tackle a lot of challenging texts, but I think the order in which we completed them made sense because we had to use the concepts as perspectives for future readings.  It was an interesting anthropological course, something I was not used to, we did not do a lot of field work and creating our own ethnographic work, nor did we solely read ethnographic material.  I did not expect this, but I have started to apply the tools we learned in this class on reading and discussing as well as the key concepts and developing ideas in other courses.  In summary, I learned how to go through readings differently and apply new perspectives for future readings as well as connect these to other readings with my own concept I create such as we did in the papers and finally talk through and relearn a reading in a way I did not originally do such as we did in Winart.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about proper ways to annotate reading, and how to read scholarly sources in general.  I also learned how to write an anthropology paper, I had never written a true college paper let alone anthropology paper so I learned the format of how to write that but also learned the differences between high school and college writing. I also learned so much through the course through discussion, we talked all the time and it was so helpful as it developed my understanding and knowledge of the reading but also the concepts within.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is not just for pre-meds or sociology majors - this class is a wonderful and interesting way to explore society, labor, and current events through many different lenses, while building very important academic skills. It is not difficult, and only requires a few out of class assignments. The majority of work is done via a very open discussion in class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class has only a few essays throughout the semester, but readings are due almost every class. Readings are graded based on three annotations which you do on the assigned reading. The annotations are pretty easy just 3-5 sentences per. The final assignment is a podcast which is pretty easy as well you work in groups and it takes a few hours to complete.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The readings are much longer and more complex and will take longer than expected. Purchase all of the books in the beginning of the year because the due dates sneak up on you and trying to get a book quickly is difficult in the middle of the year without spending a ridiculous amount of money.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to read a lot, and know that you will not understand everything-- but you will learn so much: in addition to the concepts, you'll learn just how to read effectively and what to pull from articles and how to make sense of works within historical context. cool guest speaker opportunities, meaningful assignments. This class taught me more about how to be a better writer than w101 ever did. If you have any interest at all in healthcare then this class is worth taking, and the prof is extremely smart (can be initially hard to follow, but cares a lot about us understanding and always takes time to cool it down and explain)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed critical skills for analyzing visual and written media, particularly in how they address themes of race, history, and identity, as seen in Lovecraft Country. By studying the show alongside academic articles, I learned to connect fictional narratives with real-world social issues, such as systemic racism, historical erasure, and cultural resilience. The course improved my ability to synthesize insights from diverse texts and craft arguments that bridge media content with academic research.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There was a very open space to share your insights and ideas without raising hands I think that just allows a classroom to flow quicker. Splitting up the two days we meet with one day about an episode and the other about related texts was a fun dynamic to bounce off one another

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think one of the best activities we did in class were the 'speed dating' style discussion sessions (we would set out chairs in front of each other and speak about our thoughts on the readings/content for about 2 minutes then switch). This allowed me to learn the most about what other people thought because I had time to hear from at least half the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Structure of episodes on Tuesdays and readings on Thursday to really delve deep into the themes of the episode.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Tracie Canada created an engaging and inclusive learning environment by blending visual storytelling with academic readings. The structure of alternating between watching Lovecraft Country and reading scholarly articles provided a dynamic way to understand complex themes. Analyzing Lovecraft Country alongside academic readings made the material both accessible and thought-provoking. Class discussions were essential for unpacking layered themes and allowed for collaborative learning. Assignments like comparing media themes with historical and cultural realities helped deepen my understanding.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned not only how to further analyze the writing of Nobel prize winners themselves, but also how to unpack the historical and social contexts behind them. By covering a new work of literature every week, we got a sense of the type of writing that earns this sort of recognition, in addition to an understanding of the breadth of form and topics that have been awarded the Nobel Prize.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading a book a week and analysis readings critically, it also helped with writing literary texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read cross-textually and consider themes that persisted across all texts. I learned how to place texts in their historical, political, social environments. I learned how to bring in philosophical ideologies when reading texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking, analytical writing, literary criticism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Critical Analysis of Literature: One of the most significant skills I developed in this course was the ability to critically analyze literary works. We learned to dissect complex texts, examining their themes, narrative structures, character development, and use of language. This involved not only understanding the surface-level content but also interpreting the deeper meanings and societal implications. 
Historical and Cultural Contextualization: The course enhanced my ability to place literary works within their historical and cultural contexts. This skill was crucial in understanding the significance of each author's work in their time and its lasting impact.
Diverse Perspectives and Empathetic Understanding: Engaging with a broad range of authors from different cultural backgrounds greatly enhanced my ability to appreciate diverse perspectives. This course encouraged an empathetic approach to literature, urging us to understand and respect viewpoints and experiences different from our own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think more analytically about a literary text. I improved my skills in close reading, synthesizing my thoughts, and identifying themes that run throughout a piece.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Creative thinking and critical analysis

- Historical and cultural context in which prominent works of the 20th century were written. 
- Techniques and frames with which we can analyze literary texts 
- Practice writing interpretive essays.

response_text: The course provided extremely interesting insights into the literary "greats" of the 20th century and into different cultures. I learned about the roles of bystanders/authors and the many tragedies that have shaped certain countries and communities.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text: Our discussions of Nobel Prize-winning literature let us view these works through the lens of the author's personal background, the communal context in which they lived, and the goal with which they wrote—and of course, touched on colonialism as a recurrent theme in all the novels, short stories, dramas, poetry, and essays! I thought that although it was primarily lecture-based, I still felt that I was engaged and interested in each topic covered.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned not only how to further analyze the writing of Nobel prize winners themselves, but also how to unpack the historical and social contexts behind them. By covering a new work of literature every week, we got a sense of the type of writing that earns this sort of recognition, in addition to an understanding of the breadth of form and topics that have been awarded the Nobel Prize.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read cross-textually and consider themes that persisted across all texts. I learned how to place texts in their historical, political, social environments. I learned how to bring in philosophical ideologies when reading texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking, analytical writing, literary criticism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Critical Analysis of Literature: One of the most significant skills I developed in this course was the ability to critically analyze literary works. We learned to dissect complex texts, examining their themes, narrative structures, character development, and use of language. This involved not only understanding the surface-level content but also interpreting the deeper meanings and societal implications. 
Historical and Cultural Contextualization: The course enhanced my ability to place literary works within their historical and cultural contexts. This skill was crucial in understanding the significance of each author's work in their time and its lasting impact.
Diverse Perspectives and Empathetic Understanding: Engaging with a broad range of authors from different cultural backgrounds greatly enhanced my ability to appreciate diverse perspectives. This course encouraged an empathetic approach to literature, urging us to understand and respect viewpoints and experiences different from our own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think more analytically about a literary text. I improved my skills in close reading, synthesizing my thoughts, and identifying themes that run throughout a piece.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the best part of this course were the literary cafe's. They were great for multiple reasons. The first being that it allowed us to work with our peers in a collaborative setting, which was not done commonly in the class. Secondly, I just think it is frankly a lot less intimidating and easier to share when the students themselves are the ones presenting and asking the questions. Due to this, I think our best discussions came from our literary cafes. I think that the guiding questions that were used for each book were very effective. However, I think more needs to be done to prompt us to engage with the text rather than just asking questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to approach ethical issues by deconstructing arguments. We also approached them through open discussions as opposed to a rigid system of reading and reviewing different ethics papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Making ethical inquiries daily and considering the pros and cons of thinking a certain way in an ethical context. Knowing how to back up your arguments for a certain type of ethics academically.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I feel like I learned how to make a concrete argument in this class. We practiced this most classes by making arguments about ethical questions. I learned how to work towards an ethical conclusion through an argument in this class. Other than this, I learned how to apply what I learned in class to my own life. In other words, my thought process for what I should or shouldn't do has been affected by this class and it has taught me how to make decisions. The way I think has been altered by the topics we've talked about in this class, for example how many spoons you can take from Trinity Cafe. I never would have thought about this before this class, but I feel it has made me a better person. Another thing I learned in this class is how to prioritize different things in my life. Through all of the readings and discussions in class a major theme was what to prioritize. I feel that after all of this, my understanding of the priorities in my life has been made a lot better. You can only focus on so much, so you have to focus on what has meaning to you, which is what I learned through this class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Incredible structure. We would come to class to present everyday ethical dilemmas, and everyone would get really into the discussion. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was incredibly discussion-based, which I think facilitated the development of our own positions and thinking of ways to defend it. Additionally, the overall structure of the course was extremely well-constructed, with each major question building into an overall thesis.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Summers combined lecture and discussion styles of learning in this course. I would keep this style for this course, as his interpretations of dense philosophical texts are interesting and peer interaction is really stimulating and revealing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We had a more loose structure that included more open discussions. The open discussions facilitated learning by providing many different opinions, so I would recommend keeping the discussion format.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like group discussions and small group projects a lot. Adored the first ten minutes when we talked about our ethical inquiries and chose one to build an argument for.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked pretty much everything about the class. I feel like all of the discussion made it so we could learn more efficiently and it kept people more engaged. Personally, I like the structure where we do readings for homework then come into class and talk about them, and this was a large component of this class. I also appreciated how we talked about examples from our own lives and connected them to ethics. It truly made it so we could discus the challenges to living an ethical life and how to get around them to do just that. I would keep it where the students do readings on their own time and then come into class and discuss. I think this was really effective and I liked this format a lot.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class could be more intellectually stimulating if it implemented more ethical experiments. For example, my favorite assignment for this class was to devise an experiment to test myself and then write about the experiment. That activity taught me more about myself and allowed me to look inward at my own ethical values. I think a little less emphasis on what philosophers say and more introspection about our own ethos could make this class more stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating because of the thought provoking readings and discussions that pulled you in.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was very stimulating! I think it was all the discussion that made it stimulating. Hearing everybody's opinions and what Professor Summers responded to them was very interesting for me. Also, the fact that we pulled examples out of our own lives made it interesting for me as well. I like to hear about other peoples' lives and most of the things they said applied to my life as well. This made it so I was listening the whole time to hear about other people's lives and the ethics involved. Not to mention, I could connect most of the things to my own life and to ethics as a whole. This was really fun for me and it made the class very stimulating in my own personal opinion.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

I was a really big fan of this class and I couldn't thank Professor Summers and Dylan enough for everything they did during the semester. Thank you to them! - David Hussey

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think three things that I learned from this class were how to connect ethical theories to real-life or hypothetical cases, Aristotle ethics, and how to approach the question "what does it mean to live a good/ethical life?" This class motivated me me to think in different ways, whether it was in group discussions or class discussion, and we were introduced to a lot of different perspectives on ethical topics/questions, which I liked.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

The class is also relatively stress-free, and Dr. Summers emphasizes the importance of discussions over worrying about grades.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

The way we were given the opportunity to think and come up with thought-provoking answers instead of feeling pressure to just answer immedaitely was a great way of learning how to answer philosophical questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about what the Christian narrative of creation is, what values that Christianity upholds, and how to write about myself in a deeper manner than before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about different virtues when it came to writing. For example, different ways to improve my skills and end results as a writer that will be applicable to other places in my life and at school.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned, firstly, about religion and Christianity - something I had never really explored before. This helped me cultivate a new worldview and see things in a different light than I normally would. The class also really improved my writing. I got much better at writing creatively and enjoying the process. Lastly, I learned a lot in terms of analytical skills and reading philosophical texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I experienced a deep philosophical rejuvenation, obtained a more granular understanding of my faith, learned to perceive rational arguments in favor of religion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Became a better writer both through rigorous feedback from course instructors and the peer review process
- Came to more fully appreciate the richness of the Christian tradition beyond scripture 
- Process of writing a first draft and then delivering a final product helped push me to grow in my time management and the way I approach paper writing, as I saw the benefit of not just writing everything in one sitting before the deadline

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) various thematic threads to draw in the Christian story and how they all point to the crucifixion and the nature of God (why they're significant)
2) asking "why" in my writing and in general to answer questions that are significant for our lives and the world
3) practice expressing my thoughts clearly and intentionally
4) gained Biblical, theological, philosophical, and personal perspectives on the Christian story

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
- Instructor and TA are lovely people who clearly care about their students on a personal level
- No tech in the classroom is great. I would make sure everyone is sticking to that at all times. 
- I liked being exhorted to practice different virtues throughout the semester. I would do that more consistently next year, because we did that at first and then did not keep it up. I would even include those on the syllabus. 
- Will was a great addition to our class as TA. Permanent TA Will? 
- Sometimes Dr. Wagner would adjust the readings when she sensed they were too high

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is very difficult but interesting for someone who hasn't grown up in Christian tradition. You learn a lot but it can take a lot of confusion to get there.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to read a lot, but most times the readings are interesting enough that they are worth working through. Apart form that, if the student is Christian they will find a lot of the discussions super interesting and beneficial to better understand their faith.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I went into this class not really knowing what I'd get out of it. Now, at the end of the semester, I can confidently say that this was one of if not the best class I took at Duke in terms of the assignments, the content, and the way class was handled.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you want to learn more about the Bible, take this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend it to students who are looking to deepen their understanding of the Christian religion, and who want to read and discuss texts that are often very moving on a personal level. However, be prepared to have a relatively heavy reading/writing load for a 100 level course, and to be graded rigorously on your writing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There are a decent amount of readings, but I advise you don't skip or merely skim over them. Genuinely reading them through will likely help you grow as a person.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned various topics ranging from happiness to suffering to doctrine. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

My writing ability improved in this same way; I became significantly more comfortable in conducting deep analysis of various readings and making profound arguments.
My ability to read and fully internalize difficult, abstract texts improved significantly

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

I think hearing the differing viewpoints on such rich topics such as these was really beneficial and it continues the ongoing personal discussions and arguments I have with these topics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course facilitated learning by having a no-tech policy, forcing students to be engaged in class discussion at all times rather than using laptops or tablets. On that note, the fact that the course was discussion-based facilitated my learning, as I read the class readings knowing that I had to be prepared to participate in discussion. Additionally, I liked that the instructor briefly lectured on the historical context of each reading before we engaged in discussion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the no tech policy of the classroom. The majority of my classes at Duke do not have this policy and thus a lot of students get easily distracted in class. Was definitely a big plus in relation to the overall learning environment of the class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is by far one of the best courses I've taken at Duke. This was my first time taking a Christian Ethics course. I believe this course should be taken by anyone regardless of if you have a religious background. You will read different readings that will stick with you for life. Lean into all the ways Professor Wagner challenges you. I promise, you won't regret it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would 100% recommend it and wish that I was not graduating so that I could take more classes with Professor Wagner.  The class asks a lot in terms of close reading and strong attention to detail, but is extremely rewarding and worth the time you put into it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There are a lot of readings, but they are very engaging and powerful. I learned a lot from them so it is important to read!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Overall I think that coming out of the course if you genuinely read all the readings and pay time thinking about the various concepts in class you will come out of the class as a much better person.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to interview, how to transcribe and I worked on my deep listening skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about many youth activists, the skill of deep listening, and being receptive to the perspectives of other people.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this course, I learned so much about the history of movements and the role of youth activists in building a better world. This course opened my eyes to so many challenges that activists face and the individual obstacles to change that exist within certain movements. This course also helped me become more knowledgable about the land that Duke is on, which is super important to being an active and aware student on campus.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. The complexities of youth activism and how they are represented my society
2. How to hold intentional conversation about difficult topics
3. How to take a step back for yourself.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have learned how to formulate better questions. I have also learned to appreciate transcriptions and how to create my own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to conduct interviews of professional quality, transcribe interviews, assess historical value of youth activists, how to have hard but engaged conversations with my peers, and how to listen deeply to others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about what makes for a successful social justice movement as well as how to listen deeply, especially in an interview setting. I also learned about the history behind the land that Duke currently resides on, and the institution's relationship with Native American communities over the years.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to conduct an effective interview, I developed my deep listening skills, and I learned that often times, the most impactful questions arise throughout the interview, not through previously crafted questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to transcribe interviews, create an index, and interview someone in a respectful professional manner.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned new ways of engaging with modern movements and how to ask a probing question in a broad way, such that we could better learn about the lives of our narrators (people we interviewed for class) and the people in the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the interviews are a good component but 2 would be enough- three was unbearably hard.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor facilitated my learning through in-class discussions about youth activists and movements and by having me interview youth activists and organizers. These components of the course would be great to keep for future years of instruction.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked how the course was guided by students. While Professor Hogan did give us a lot of information, most of the learning that we did in class was from our peers. We learned about the experience of our peers that maybe had worked in a movement before or that held a certain identity that intersected with a movement we discussed. By having students lead discussions, it also ensured that classes didn't become repetitive and were always engaging. I think this would be a really great component to continue for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Hogan helped foster an incredibly inclusive, thoughtful, and inspiring learning environment, one in which I, along with my peers, felt comfortable being vulnerable, learning from one another, and and taking risks. I think the class' seating arrangement, organized in a circle, also helped facilitate meaningful discussions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor made a concerted effort to create a positive learning environment and prioritized the voices of student experience over personal instruction. I also appreciated how she prepared us for doing our own interviews through multiple in-class deep listening examples and practices. This was effective for my overall success on my own interviews, so I would definitely maintain these aspects of the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor created an environment in which we could be open and honest about our personal experiences and learn from one another, part of the purpose of a seminar class. Also, engaging reading material was provided.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Student led discussions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
