Class discussions being led by students was also great because my peers already brought really interesting thoughts and questions. I wish I knew more clearly when we were transitioning to different units, but then again, all of them are connected to each other any way.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Hearing my peers' powerful accounts and insights made this class incredibly intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Though student led facilitations of activities and discussions which emerged from the readings were often stimulating, through conversations, I often found other students and myself had previously done a lot of outside research on youth activism focusing on the specific movements studied in class prior to coming to Duke. Overall, I think it would be important to incorporate more material from lesser known movements (such as adoptee activism mentioned by Maggie) or more inclusiveness of non-western forms of activism (specifically from global southern countries).

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The best part was learning about standing rocks and tiger swan surveillance. It was something I had never heard about in all of my life and I think the instructor did a great job of presenting this information. Honestly, what could have made it more stimulating was mixing up the statement question assignments and not always having every day be reading an article/watching an interview and then discussing it.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The people in the class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will make you think critically about the world around you, one of the best professors I have ever had. I recommend this class to anyone who wants to have stimulating conversations about the history we have been taught for so long.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to be receptive to the course material and the people around you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend taking this course, even if you don't have any experience with activism or movement building. If anything, this course makes you a more aware and knowledgeable member of the Duke community. It also gives you the opportunity to interview activists yourself, which is both challenging and exciting. This teaches you a lot about how to really listen and ask good questions, which are skills applicable to any field.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The content contributes to lifelong skills, and is worth it despite the heavy workload.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Transcribing is the most tedious thing you will ever do in your life. As soon as you finish that interview, start transcribing. Also block out time for transcribing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is awesome for students looking to develop an understanding of different youth movements and how they're connected to each other. It's also great hands-on experience for conducting interviews, writing transcripts, and scheduling interviews. Professor Hogan is kind, challenging, and approachable. Can be a heavy and hopeful course in terms of content and a great reminder that change comes from all different places and ages.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a great class to take if you are interested in learning more about social issues facing today's society as well as examining the key components to successful organizing/change-making.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The title of the course is a little deceiving. Though it is listed as a Documentary Studies course, this course consists of crafting 3 of your own hour-long interviews in addition to transcribing them. Though the teacher strives to create a vulnerable and nurturing environment, she often overlooks the incredible work of youth activists sitting in the class and student experiences for the sake of the activists we read about in the class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
It's really good but make sure to pick activists to interview whose work you actually care about otherwise you will have no motivation to trascribe them. Great class and Wesley is super cool I literally want to be her when I grow up. 
Think about why you're taking this class and try to really develop your technical skills in it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Safeguard the community environment and care for one another's emotional and intellectual needs.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Listening to people in a class structure, presenting ideas based off a text, and creating discussion questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I became very familiar with the history of the BLM movement and fight for indigenous rights. I also have a much better understanding of the intersections in social movements. As far as skills, I think I got much better at participating in an academic discussions around very sensitive historical (and present day) issues. Through this, I got much better at truly listening to others, thoughtfully responding, and considering the reality of experiences that are not my own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. starting to learn to interview has been really cool and i think will be helpful just in life too
2. we also focused a lot on how to listen deeply and think critically which has made conversations more meaningful and is also important in life
3. learning about youth justice movements has been super cool and important to learn about -- we have focused on things that are not normally focused on which i like

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I improved in providing critical in-depth analysis  of texts, videos, and other works in this class.
I learned much about the history and current state of youth activism, encountering subjects, individuals, and ideas I had never heard of before. This class was not only informational, but it provided resources and knowledge that will greatly aid me in the future. 
This class has taught me how to question established norms and status quos in various areas of life through research and learning of youth activism. I have gained practical skills that are applicable in other classes, my personal life, and more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Participating in discussion about difficult topics, listening, asking questions, interviewing, basic audio editing, transcript writing, analytical thinking combined with emotional/empathetic listening/thinking

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to be a good listener when interviewing people. How to give constructive criticism. How to call people in instead of calling people out.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Interviewing skills, ranging from how to approach questions to how to make a professional transcript. We had a lot of time to flesh out these skills and I learned a lot
Seminar discussions were held in a constructive way and it was helpful to take the class first semester to learn these skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) About various youth movements since the 2010s, covering subjects from environmentalism, reproductive justice, etc.
2) How to interview 
3) Think about the intersectional identities of youth activists

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: No class was the same, we were always doing new stuff. The repetition of the statement and question thing led to consistency and habit building which made it effective rather than a one time thing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Hogan is such a warm, caring person and her authenticity as a teacher was very inviting which lead to better engagement and participation in discussions. The majority of the readings were also engaging. The open ended nature of major projects helped cater them to my interests within the framework of the class, which was very enjoyable. I also think the statement/question assignment was very beneficial as it made me put pen to paper and get ideas flowing on the reading ahead of the class discussion. The interview series is fantastic. I feel like it sharpened skills that I didn't even know I had, and that would never be acknowledged in other classes. It also feels great to participate in something larger than myself by documenting these people's stories.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: professor hogan fosters very genuine conversations in the classroom which is super nice and as a class i think we have had good conversations. the classroom also feels very chill and everyone is here to learn with and from each other which is nice.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class is seminar style, with each person having an opportunity to speak. Nevertheless, this does not mean there is chaos; although there is great disagreement and discussion, it is all carried out respectfully and in an edifying manner under the supervision, guidance and input of our great instructor.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof Hogan mixes up styles of discussion, and lets students dictate how discussions are carried out/where they go. The class really feels like a safe space in which everyone is encouraged to share what they are thinking. Early lesson plans being based on how to create this environment was really helpful to creating a safe and welcoming class culture.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class is mostly based on discussion of readings. There were times during the class when students were asked to split into two groups and debate on a topic. I think that this was the time when students felt most engaged in the class and should be kept for next year.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We did readings outside of class then went in class to discuss seminar style. The discussions were open and contesting the readings when we disagreed was encouraged, which I think was helpful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Hogan is just a genuinely nice teacher who creates a welcoming environment for discussion and discourse. She never pointed out a student's opinion wrong and was open to learning about differing opinions. I never felt scared to speak my mind in that class (unlike others).

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The variety of topics we covered, plus the commonality of importance they each brought to our lives.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: More room for disagreement and criticizing the readings. I feel the most productive and engaging discussion we had was on The Solidarity Struggle when we were criticizing some of the ideas in the reading.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: learning about movements that i have heard about in media but never really studied is really cool. also learning how to interview. also learning about how movements form and operate is really important and cool

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was stimulating because I was always learning something new and each one was applicable, informational and interesting.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Debates in class were really fun and provided deep thinking. I think that the questions posed by the professor were not open-ended enough and imposed the perspective of the professor onto the students. I felt the class did not also give any in-depth look into the history of youth justice movements. In fact we really didn't look into any of the major youth justice movements in history at all.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The discussions made the class and as the semester went on, we got more comfortable and had many interesting discussions I haven't seen in every class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: 90% of the class was discussion-based, so it was only as stimulating as our discussions (and your own personal interest in said discussion). Some days were good with interesting topics, while others not so much. Really just depends on if you are interested in that day's topic.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do the work, get interviews over with, don't stress.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Absolutely sign up for this FOCUS and take this class. After taking this class, I truly feel educated on the movements around the fight for black lives, indigenous rights, reproductive freedoms, and the environment/environmental justice. Similarly, I can more clearly see the intersections between these movements and the people groups within them. Conducting the interview series will sharpen skills that you likely won't even acknowledge in other courses. Professor Hogan is a wonderful person, and I feel incredibly privileged to have built a relationship with her.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: awesome class. i think you have to go in really wanting to learn and genuinely are about it though. i think if you do care about it then you can get a whole lot from it, if you dont care then you wont get much about it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is an excellent course for a student hoping to acquire a deeper understanding of the constructs of the world via studying youth activism! You'd be surprised how interconnected the concepts in this class are with things we encounter everyday. It is a critical thinking, though-provoking, yet fun, enjoyable class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Time-wise, not a lot of work. But if you want to make the most of it, see it as a challenge and opportunity rather than an easier class because the content is very powerful, especially when you engage with it deeply.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
(1) The class encouraged reflection, and made this easy and accessible — I'm much better at thinking verbally than I am at writing things out (writing feels so much more high-pressure to me), so I really appreciated that we were able to submit audio recordings (and also drawings) as formats for our weekly reflections.
(2) I really liked our three-week small-group sessions on topics of our choosing — I chose Democracy in Higher Ed with Dr. Eric Mlyn, and we were able to reflect deeply about the state of college education around the US through engaging discussions. We also met some of Dr. Mlyn's student researchers & learned about their research (and learned about how we ourselves could get involved), which was really cool — basically, E189 gave us opportunities to engage in our own specific topics of interest, and also served as a gateway for further opportunities beyond class.
(3) The topics were awesome, and were so applicable to us as college students — we discussed things like the construct of adulthood and whether majors mattered, all of which are really informing how I approach college!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
Aspects of E189 that were super stimulating:
(1) I really liked when we were separated into different sections (based on our preferences) for three weeks with different "What Now?" professors to explore different topic areas — I looked at Democracy in Higher Education with Dr. Eric Mlyn, and I absolutely loved our small-group discussions and how much that helped me reflect on how polarized our current college landscape is. (Our learnings and discussions are also super relevant with heavy student activism on college campuses in elite institutions in action all over the nation right now (regarding sociopolitical and geopolitical issues) — how much free speech actually exists on college campuses, and what constitutes "free speech"? What is the limit of administration "protecting" students regarding this?)
(2) Ethics 189 required us to apply our learning and reflection in tons of different settings, and that really helped me maximize what I took from this class — we went to the Gardens for one lesson, for example, and were encouraged to observe and engage with art (I went to the Asian Students Associations' Converge Showcase) for another asynchronous lesson!
(3) I was able to make tons of connections with my other courses — I enrolled in E189 as a co-requisite for my WR101 class. For example, I loved our discussion on adulthood and the social construct of being an adult, and this definitely was something that applied to my Decoding Disney class (and the concept of Disney audiences being tailored to certain audiences, plus how audience interpretation changes with differing life experiences)!
(4) This really helped me reflect on my approach towards college (& life)!

response_text:

I enjoyed using the class as a time to talk with my friends in between activities, especially people I didn't know super well. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be aware of how many points you need from the beginning and act accordingly. Don't let yourself realize you are short of the minimum once it's too late. Ferney allows you to miss a few classes/reflections and still pass, so keep that in mind from the beginning.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is very easy. It requires very minimal work outside of class and we often had weeks off. Some of the topics were really interesting, some less so. I highly recommend you do the Taylor Swift section with Professor Andres, or really any section with her, because she's the best and it's by far the most interesting thing you'll do in the class. Also, don't forget to turn in assignments and put some effort into them. There's leeway for missing things but they will be very unimpressed by the work you submit without putting in effort. Also I highly recommend taking advantage of the voice recordings for reflections!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
This was my first seminar-style class. It was a very new type of teaching/engaging, and I think a lot of my peers probably felt the same way. I learned how to value a class that puts discussion above academic performance.
I learned that although I enjoy STEM classes, I find a lot of comfort in philosophy-based classes, and I need them to balance out my course load.
I learned that people have come to Duke from incredibly different backgrounds, and they have come here to achieve very different things.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course was a wonderful space for me to engage in reflection and introspection. The online writing reflection assignments were my favorite part (I wish more of the course was like this)-- they asked questions that made me consider my life, beliefs, goals, and things I thought to be true. As an introductory ethics course, I think it did a great job introducing students to some of those ideas. I think the fact that it was a required course took away a little bit because some students obviously did not want to be there. Because of this, it was hard to feel like my peers were as invested in the class as I was. I genuinely enjoyed the overall experience and am interested in continuing to study with the ethics department.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Gregory's guidance was the heartbeat of this class. She has a remarkable ability to navigate conversations so they ebb and flow naturally, ensuring everyone is heard and feels valued. Her skill in creating a space where ideas are exchanged freely, yet with purpose, was transformative for my learning. The combination of open discussions, reflective exercises, and her thoughtful moderation fostered a learning environment that felt both challenging and supportive.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about 1) the role of a university in promoting democracy and fostering citizenship in its students, 2) social entrepreneurship and how it differed from traditional notions of civic engagement, and 3) the history and debates surrounding service-learning and national service programs.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I really learned a lot from this course. Specifically, I learned how engagement programs are constructed, why people disagree about the purposes of universities, and how changes to American culture have impacted democracy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how important citizenship is to civic engagement and what higher ed's specific role in civic engagement is. I realized that democracy is truly at risk in this country, but I also learned that universities can help alleviate this issue if they go about solutions in the right way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a lot of knowledge and insights about higher education's role within making a citizen. I also learned about the different types of citizenship was something I didn't know about. Finally, I learned about the importance of freedom of speech and academic freedom.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course challenged the ways I thought about things. I learned how to think about things differently, I learned how to understand other viewpoints, and I learned how to apply my knowledge to broader topics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have learned a lot from this class. Firstly, I have developed a new way of thinking in which I now always consider multiple perspectives on a topic as it is important to remember that not everyone has the same access to information/resources. in addition, I believe a skill I developed was in synthesizing information as with so many different readings, it was important to analyze carefully but also condense information into a manageable amount. Lastly, I learned a lot about the development of civic engagement in higher education which I previously knew nothing about, and I also learned about how it is all applicable to our current life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about issues by examining multiple perspectives. I learned how to synthesize data into a concise argument. I learned how to better discuss issues with others by building off of their opinions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
What the role of higher education is- whether it is to make students into the best versions of themselves (ex. "leaders", global thinkers, "good" citizens)
The extent of civic engagement that Duke seeks to offer through its many initiatives, as well as an overall knowledge of Duke history
Believing in political polarization in the US as more of a good thing- we should learn how to understand opposite viewpoints before we are able to critique them

response_text: This course taught me to think critically about the ways universities promote civic engagement, as well as what even constitutes as civic engagement.This course challenged me to evaluate the merits of civic engagement and social innovation as responses to societal issues.This course also helped me understand the history of civic engagement and the university's role in developing citizens.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Mlyn structured the course in a way that had a logical but clever flow, making it easy to follow along and grasp the material. Class discussions were incredibly insightful. We often spent too much time talking about a particular topic, but it was because every student was engaged and we were all learning with each new question brought up. Professor Mlyn often used humor and stories in class, contributing to a light-hearted environment more conducive to learning. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course completely reformed the way I think about justice. I learned about different theories of justice from different philosophers (Rawls, Kant, Mill, Aristotle), the function of restorative justice, and how patters in human behavior make moral repair so necessary for society. My way of thinking about how to handle conflict, how to build relationships, and how to hold people accountable for wrongdoings has completely changed, and I believe I have become a better person for it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Class was highly discussion-based, involved students building relationships and trust with one another, and debating complex issues in society. Professor Gregory was also very open to feedback, and gave great advice to students in turn. She also gave fantastic advice into academic writing, which improved my skills a lot and will serve me well throughout my time here at Duke. I wouldn't change a thing about how the class was run!

I preferred thinking about larger political concepts over curricula and different learning programs. I thought the reading by Wofford was the least captivating.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Excellent course. A little difficult, with a lot of work expected, but extremely stimulating and will gain a ton of very cool knowledge on how higher education functions in relation to the world. Would highly recommend to any student interested in the humanities, serves exceptionally well as a foundational course, and is a great transition from high school to college work.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Connect with the professor. Stick to class rules and professor preferences. If facing difficulties, talk to the professor personally. Grading is fair in terms of the published rubrics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to read and write a lot, there is a lot of content that repeats itself.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will allow you to learn a lot and stay engaged throughout the year.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course provides some very interesting insights into higher education and civic engagement from a variety of different perspectives, and allows students to explore their own opinions on topics informed by readings. It is very interesting and the discussions are low pressure and stimulating if you are willing to participate.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that the student should expect to learn a lot, but to read a lot for class each time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is thought-provoking, and a great course for freshmen, specifically, to help you analyze the rest of your Duke journey. The class isn't perfect; there's unnecessary reading at times, and Professor Mlyn is not known for being a graceful grader, but he is fair and clear. Take the class, it's worth it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Pay attention in class to what Professor Mlyn has to say both because it is interesting and it was what he will expect of you in exams and writing assignments. He is fair with his expectations and I haven't felt surprised by any grade or question on an assessment.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be ready to read a lot, and be very specific in the way you contribute to class. If you are interested in education and programs, evaluating the way higher education operates, then definitely take his class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is good overall and has a very reasonable workload. Both the professor and class are interesting and engaging. The grading has a high floor but is somewhat tough, and feedback from the instructor is limited.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do it! And be prepared to be exposed to new ideas and perspectives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how protest movements make decisions, how environmental harms are concentrated in some portions of the world, and how local decisions can impact residents' quality of life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was bale to gain a better understanding of the role of pollution and governmental policies in creating injustices for vulnerable communities. I also was able to better understand social movement dynamics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to read articles and dense texts with intention and efficiency.
2. I gained insight about how environmental justice exhibits itself in communities around me and at national level as well.
3. I learned to think through a social movements perspective, especially about dynamics of social movements in relation to countermovements, instiutional responses, and decision making.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned several things in this class. Firstly, I learned to deeply value class discussion. It was extremely beneficial to hear others’ ideas and participate in simulations. In addition, Professor also taught me new methods to effectively read and analyze notes. Lastly, I had previously known nothing about what environmental and climate justice actually entailed, and I learned not only historical aspects of each, but also how it is affecting us now and in the future.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to write essays with brevity with brevity, clarity, and concise.
How to review books and summarize text
I learned hot connect content materials together

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Sometimes, movements need to lie outside the polity as a check on institutions. 
2. Community-based research is both important and effective. 
3. The US is full of environmental racism and environmental inequality.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me about the function and strategies of social movements to affect social change, the way that movements interact with and challenge institutions as well as how institutions respond, and the importance of considering environmental justice as a focus in addressing climate change.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the simulation activities. They were interesting and shed new light on course content. The essays not being due until the end of the semester was also very helpful and allowed me to engage with them more fully than I would have otherwise.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Doing environmental justice simulations in which we were assigned to bee different countries, social movements, or industries and participating in the COP28 or another climate conference.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: During class, we would mostly discuss readings or be taught content through a lecture format (though the lectures were not often). We also had short assignments, a group project, and ethnographies to complete along the way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professors Jowers’s class was highly engaging as it was not lecture style, but instead invoked class discussions, simulation, and group presentations. This was effective for my learning style as it always kept me interested and questioning what I previously thought.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The discussion aspect was excellent! I loved how everyone got to participate in pretty unstructured dialogue about the readings. I also love the fishbowl. The simulations are FANTASTIC AND YOU SHOULD KEEP THEM FOR YEARS TO COME!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

The class discussions also allowed each student share their own insight, greatly enhancing each other's learning. I would definitely keep the simulations as they provided fun ways to learn through doing and independent research.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure you understand that the course is about protests and social movements, not about climate science or (for the most part) specific climate policies.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There is a lot of reading, so knowing how to read effectively is very important. Be prepared to engage with the class content and have discussions about it. The content is very interesting and relevant to things happening in the world today.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would definitely recommend this course to any student in the future. Professor does a really great job and enhancing your learning while also making you feel welcome in her class. She is always available to help in and out of class so if you are ever concerned about a grade or assignment, reach out.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this course! It's very interesting and very easy! Discussions are awesome. Kay gets you up and moving with simulations, which are always a ton of fun. Be warned, though. Kay is rather unorganized so it can be a headache to just try to get on the same page as her.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do the readings, have talking points prepared for the next class discussion. Don't put off the short assignments or ethnographies, or else the end of the semester will be quite the grind!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about conservative points of view and how to have effective and meaningful civil discourse.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learn how to have a civil conversation on important topics and diminish political polarization. We thought critically as a class about what factors and topics influence society, and what they actually mean.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I enjoyed this course more than any other course I have taken at Duke so far, and I have enjoyed most of my courses. I became much more educated about many political issues over the course of the semester, and I was able to have my views challenged and shaped. As John Stuart Mill said, "he who only knows his side knows little of that." Prof. Rose has that quote on his syllabus and it's exactly what you gain by taking the course. I also got better at discussing issues in a charitable way, and explaining my thoughts better.  Civil discourse can be hard, but it's not hard enough to justify avoiding it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze different viewpoints on controversial topics; how to discuss viewpoints productively and assuming goodwill; and how to better understand topics in their full complexity.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One thing I learned would be to never expect someone to have a certain position on a problem in this world because of what I know about them, or even what they look like. Another thing I learned would be utilizing papers and articles by scholars to formulate an opinion on an issue.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to engage in respectful and productive civil discourse through speaking with values of charity and understanding. I learned how to affectively discuss political and controversial topics with people who might disagree with me. I learned how to use research to back up claims effectively, while understanding opposing arguments. I also how the causes of polarization and orthodoxy often stem from characteristics of human nature. Most importantly, I learned how one's ethics and morals contribute to their outlook on life and therefore political opinions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to have charity for other people's opinions and listen to them with patience; how to listen respectfully, without immediately talking back and give people the benefit of the doubt; how to encourage good discussion in a class among people with different opinions; appreciating the nuance in people's opinions and their very different life backgrounds

response_text: I loved the learning environment of this class. Professor Rose was extremely engaging, funny, caring and lighthearted. He encouraged students to be vulnerable without fear of judgement. The class was lighthearted and low stress, yet students were extremely willing to participate and engage. By creating a class of diverse political views, discussions were more interesting and caused students to think more deeply. Professor Rose also called on a variety of students so all voices were heard. I was motivated and inspired to research discussion topics deeper after class, and I used what I learned to spark conversation with friends and family.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Rose is great at creating a welcoming, lighthearted, open classroom environment. It takes time and isn't achieved immediately, but by the end of the class a lot of us knew and trusted each other and had a good idea of each others' opinions and ways of thinking. I made friends and now say hi to my classmates whenever I pass them outside the classroom. Learning, open discussion, charity, and trust are emphasized over grades and assignments, which provides a very nice stress reliever class that still has deep discussion. I liked the more philosophical class discussions on topics like being wrong, how to think, love, etc. Most of the class was dedicated to discussion, which I enjoyed, even if I didn't participate every time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Too often college courses seem to endorse a certain way of thinking. This class won't box you in like that. Take this to expose yourself to uncomfortable conversations and perspectives that will strengthen your mind and allow you to understand what you actually believe and why.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is one of the most popular courses at Duke largely because of the professors that teach it. I would encourage everyone who has the opportunity to try to enroll in this course. No matter what you do in life, you will find yourself reflecting on the things you learn in this class. I am grateful for the growth I experienced this past semester. I would absolutely recommend every Duke student to enroll in this class.the topics discussed in the readings and in the course were engaging, informative and transformative for me. Our classroom was a community of people who challenged each other intellectually and respected each other's perspective. This was possible because the professors set the tone through their respect for us. Thank you for an amazing semester!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. I've learnt, at least the foundations of seven different religions and traditions. They're all very interesting and offer valuable insight on how to approach different aspects of the good life.2. I've learnt to pick and choose more effectively. The seven different traditions and religions offer important lessons on different aspects of life. I agree with some, and disagree with others. For example, I appreciate the pragmatism of Stoicism (I think of myself as stoic to an extent), but some things to me are not indifferents, they're simply bad. I prefer Confucianism's focus on ritual in dealing with loss.3. I've learnt to appreciate writing more. We did a lot of writing in this class, particularly with the jounral entries and the many notes and questions we did in class. It's brought back a lesson I learnt from my old writing teaching: "writing is thinking". I've done a lot of thinking through writing in this class.

response_text: The lectures are not particularly stimulating. Professor Antepuli, who taught us about Islam, was the only one I always wanted to hear more from, because of how engaging of a lecturer he was. I would suggest a total revamp of the lectures: more guest lecturers and case studies or real-world examples related to the religious concepts discussed (prompting us to apply the knowledge to practical situations). As well as the use of multimedia elements such as videos, documentaries, and interactive simulations to supplement traditional lectures and field trips to religious sites or events, allowing students to experience and observe religious practices firsthand.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) Weekly readings with the questions—really prompted us to actually delve into the readings.
2) Dialogue Groups & DG performances—great way to meet people!
3) THE RETREAT! Such a great embodiment of TI's values, & really helped me relax as a sophomore & meet other people & experience the importance of staying present.
4) Check system for questions & journal entries—removes pressure of thinking in a "correct" way.
5) Dialogue between traditions—having the professors representing the traditions have actual conversations together at the front of the lecture hall.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the lack of communication and expectations between students and the professors has made the class a little less stimulating. The interest I and others would gain from lectures is often overshadowed by the confusion regarding deadlines and grading expectations. I know it is hard to coordinate a class with so many students and teachers, but sometimes assignment due dates feel rushed. I have heard such amazing things about this class and felt a little disappointed with how it actually went. The retreat was absolutely amazing, and I believe the TI program has the potential to keep that energy going the entire class.

response_text: Interesting events and opportunities. Great lecturers but course structure was boring and discussion groups were pointless.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The dialogue across various traditions was a sight to see. It allowed me to think critically about various traditions and aspects of life. The course readings are excellent, and the lecturers are wonderful, the course has no choice but to be great.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was incredibly stimulating through the discussions and paper we had to write at the end. The freedom we are given to explore and analyze different traditions and own views on God, death, suffering, and happiness is refreshing. I don't believe the discussions were as stimulating though because they were in such large groups. The days we were split into smaller groups within our discussion groups was when I  would actually meet and talk with people.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: the teachers

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was so interesting to hear the different opinions in class. Having open conversations helped make these discussions more meaningful.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Learning more about major religions & traditions —> Thinking about my purpose here. Transforming my worldview & my view of my undergraduate experience—what to prioritize, how to proceed with intentionality. —> Realizing the importance of slowing down & being present.The faculty are incredible. The readings were incredible & helped me reframe the way I thought about how I approached life. Guest speaker conversations (with dinner), especially the one focused on the Israel-Hamas War, really helped me ground reflection into the way I approached politics—it made me realize that religion can't really exist independently of politics, which changed the way I thought about political engagement.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The Transformative Ideas program is amazing, but you would probably find more fulfillment in one of their smaller courses. The retreat is awesome and was one of the highlights of my sophomore year.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Duke students often refer to an easy class as a good class. If you want a relatively easy class take this class. If you want a somewhat intellectually stimulating class, I recommend taking a different course. Though the teachers were interesting, the lack of student engagement will impede your own experience. There is a required overnight retreat and a dialogue section weekly which aren't noted on the course description. This course requires you to submit 2 questions a week on canvas, 10 reflective journal entries, 1 acting performance, and 1 final paper. Overall it is a very manageable class. You get what you put into this course, so know that before enrolling.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: great course to take to expand your world view

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about religions and traditions I wasn't very familiar with. I feel like I gained a more holistic view of what the "good life" might be. Through lectures with different specialized professors, I learned that each tradition has its own outlook on life and that no one has a clear cut answer to the millions of questions we can pose. More specifically, I learned that Transhumanism is centered around technological advancement, which I was unaware of initially.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learning the basics and perspectives of each different tradition was extremely insightful. I developed new beliefs by learning about staying present in the moment from Buddhism, ethical obligations to others from Christianity, and how humanity as a whole could be altered/improved from Transhumanism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about philosophical thinking.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Views on the following: Texts and Traditions, Happiness and Success, Life and Death, Suffering and Healing from the perspective of Christianity, Transhumanism, Buddhism, Scientific Naturalism, Greek Virtue Ethics, Islam and Judaism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I don't think that I will be really taking a lot away from the class. This was really a struggle to try to get anything out of it..

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The class truly has the power to transform ideas. Hearing from such a diverse group of people, all experts in their fields, allowed me develop my own perspectives over life's biggest questions. The course is a truly one of one experience for sophomores, in this critical time of our lives. The teachings of various traditions allowed me to see the world in a whole different light.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to understand different points of view and relate with each other to find common ground in thought. In light of several issues concurrently happening around the world, this class was a breath of fresh air that allowed civil conversation organized by the amazing professors. The retreat also was placed at such a perfect time when I was studying for midterms, helping me escape the Duke bubble. Life at Duke isn't in any way representative of how real life is meant to be viewed or taken. Life is meant to be good. And this class reminded me of how important human interaction and conversation is.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The lecturers rotated based on the tradition we were covering in that particular class and this helped foster a good learning environment. Also, we had dialogue groups which allowed us to further discuss course content beyond lecture.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The discussion groups were great for facilitation discussion in ways that lectures don't allow. I found community in met group, entirely with people of different faiths and experiences. 
The diversity of the instructors was great, both in their fields but also in their ways of conducting the class. 
Best of all, the discussions between the instructors was fantastic. I loved hearing the students questions and listening to how the instructors found agreement and disagreements within their faiths, and how they dealt with challenging questions that arose. This was an opportunity I think people rarely get.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having 8 different lecturers who were each so passionately involved with their respective traditions was genuinely so interesting and engaging every lecture. This method of changing topics every class made it easy to understand distinctions between units and ideas, and kept me invested in the course. I also really enjoyed having a journal and doing journal entries, as they were very personal and helped me reflect on my views in a very informal way. The dialogue group/dialogue performance was also great, as I got to build relationships with my classmates and produce something fun. The final reflective project and retreat were also great. Overall, having such dynamic meetings and assignments made the course really enjoyable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Duke students often refer to an easy class as a good class. If you want a relatively easy class take this class. If you want a somewhat intellectually stimulating class, I recommend taking a different course. Though the teachers were interesting, the lack of student engagement will impede your own experience. There is a required overnight retreat and a dialogue section weekly which aren't noted on the course description. This course requires you to submit 2 questions a week on canvas, 10 reflective journal entries, 1 acting performance, and 1 final paper. Overall it is a very manageable class. You get what you put into this course, so know that before enrolling.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The role humans have in nature (stewards vs. ravagers of the land), regenerative agriculture, and the true meaning of what makes a place home

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
positionality: who am I in relation to nature, my and society's impact on things such as sustainability, land, rurality
perspective taking: learning topics from every (even controversial) povs
analytical thinking and discussion skills: knowing how to consolidate everything into a stance that accurately reflects my opinions

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. An insight I had was that ecological preservation and human flourishing can often go hand in hand which makes me hopeful for the future.
2. One thing I learned about was the practice of regenerative agriculture. I hadn't know about it at all and I had been much more cynical about non-industrial farming, but after our readings/videos/field trips, I'm much more convinced that reg. agr. could be a beneficial way forward.
3. One way of thinking that I hopefully developed was the very logical, almost mathematical approach that philosophers like Norcross take in their writing. Using "marginal cases" and proving that an argument is logically incoherent.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: regenerative agriculture, vegetarianism, humans relationship with nature, thinking critically about environmental/ethical topics

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. thinking about the environment from an ethical standpoint, considering its effect on culture and the economy
2. viewing ourselves as a part of the environment, not separate from it
3. understanding how complexity of the situation of 'saving the environment'- no easy solution, but we discussed many practices we can add to our daily lives

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, we explored the topic of positive and negative human interactions with the natural world. We explored this topic through various perspectives such as indigenous wisdom, regenerative farming, religion, etc. We learned about how centuries-old indigenous beliefs about the natural world shape indigenous communities' views about the natural world. We explored how despite the widely held view that these beliefs are not scientifically based, their knowledge has been proven to be valid through formal experimentation. We also discussed the growing movement of regenerative farming and how it has the potential to restore natural landscapes, save money, and create higher crop yields. Finally, we explored environmentalism through the lens of Pope Francis in his writing Laudato Si. We discussed his ideas of the technocratic paradigm and how it has led to increased consumerism and a detachment from the natural world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Idea of possessive individualism/property, regenerative agriculture, belonging/what home is

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

The field trip to the regenerative farm was very interesting and educational. The atmosphere of friendliness and the low-pressure environment was very beneficial to open discussion and learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Since this was a discussion based course, I appreciated the selection of readings and questions prompted. I liked how we had class in the gardens on nice days and supplemented the discussions with a few Ted Talks, documentaries, and field trips. I especially enjoyed our days in the gardens, particularly the one where we churned butter.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed being prompted questions by the professors, having a chance to discuss our viewpoints in a group, and then discussing them with the class as a whole. In other cases, we were prompted with questions and if we did not have a response, one of the professors would either rephrase the question or offer their own response, to which we would comment on. Both of these methods of discussing the material were helpful in understanding it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We had weekly readings and a series of reflection questions (500-750 words) that had to be turned in before class. We then had a guided seminar about the readings, our interpretations, personal experiences related to the readings, questions, etc. each class. The reflection questions allowed me to think critically about the readings and extract a higher understanding from them. The discussions also invited multiple perspectives from students which allowed me to see interpretations I had not considered before. I would keep the class mostly the same for future years as I feel this structure was conducive to learning the required content effectively.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a class that delves into the intricacies of the environmental movement, involving the topics of vegetarianism, fossil fuel production, and conservation. This is a class that will not offer clear cut solutions, but rather make you think about why you feel a certain way about an issue, as well as why certain positions on these controversial topics arose and exist. Tying these topics all together is a question of how this all impacts humans and their well-being to determine what really is the impact of the environment on humans (as well as the impact of humans on the environment) and what is the future of this relationship.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the dominant and foundational stances on philosophy of science, the mind, and religion from Descartes to Gould to Chalmers. I learned the specific structures of arguments like that of Descartes' epistemology, Plantinga's rebuttal to naturalistic evolution, and Jackson's qualia argument against reductive physicalism. I was given the space to show my understanding of these stances and practice synthesizing my thoughts on the matter.
