question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think this course is one of my favorite classes that I've taken at Duke. It gave me so much insight into how to think about things like science, neuroscience, biology from not only a scientific perspective but also a perspective that is focused on questioning the nature of these things. I'm a computer science major and never really got exposure to natural sciences as a whole and this class was a perfect way to be able to get that exposure. It was amazing to be able to touch on so many things such as physics, biology, computer science even from a perspective of philosophical inquiry and relating it to religion. It really gave me the skills and tools to be able to question my own views not only about science but about everything I do and really get to the bottom of whatever I'm learning or thinking about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Deconstructing complex philosophical/biological/physical arguments into palatable simple ones. I was really forced to understand the concepts underlying some of the most important questions that we as humans face, such as the reliability of our cognitive faculties. The essay prompts broke down these concepts and I'm definitely going to be breaking down complicated concepts in a similar way that the professor did for future difficult essays. 
2. Understanding of neuroscience -- I'm not a neuroscience major and so I had no prior knowledge on how the brain worked at all. Getting to hold a human brain in my own hands was really special and I thought that the level of information that we could get was varied enough that a neuroscience major would learn something and a newbie like me could as well. 
3. One of my biggest insights into the class was being truly captivated by my fellow Duke peers' intellect. Many of us came from different majors and backgrounds and every person added such an interest take to the conversations. I was truly impressed with the depth of knowledge and philosophical thinking of my peers.

Also, the people that take this class are awesome!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my first ever philosophy class, and I would highly recommend it for anybody wanting to explore the subject. I learned how to think very deeply about some of the biggest questions, write detailed papers on philosophical arguments, and perhaps most importantly, how to ask questions and work towards the answer.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Wow, this class was so much better than I anticipated. I truly enjoyed learning about the intersections between science and religion, in a way that held space for all opinions, faiths, and backgrounds. I didn't feel like one faith or perspective was pressed onto us, and I learned how to dive into my thoughts and mind and truly decide where I stood on issues. I learned how complex conversations surrounding evolution truly are through the different evolutionary theories-- I did not realize how much of evolutionary theory was not agreed upon, because in high school it seemed like Darwinian- natural selection was the main and agreed upon definition of evolution. Also, I have never taken a philosophy class before, and I am so glad I took this one, because I learned about various ancient philosophers, how to contrast their ideas, and specifically learned about their ideas of the mind and God, which I find fascinating as a Neuroscience student. Finally, we went to Prof. Len White's brain lab, and I had so much fun going in the context of this course. Looking at the biological brain, but harboring these deep questions about religion and what it means to be human in the back of my mind from our readings, was truly remarkable.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Critical Analysis of Interdisciplinary Themes: I developed the ability to critically evaluate how neuroscience and religion intersect, particularly in understanding the neurological basis of spiritual experiences and how these are perceived in various cultural contexts.
2. Integrative Thinking: This course emphasized synthesizing diverse perspectives from scientific literature, philosophical texts, and theological frameworks to address complex questions about the human condition.
3. Effective Argumentation: I learned to craft arguments that bridge empirical evidence with abstract reasoning, enabling thoughtful discourse on topics that often evoke polarizing views, as exhibited during class seminar and long papers.

response_text: Professor Watkins would move the desks so everyone could face each other, fostering better and more inclusive class discussions! I feel I was better able to listen to my peers' ideas and respond to their questions. I learned a lot of names of my classmates, which I don't feel is normally the case, and it was fun. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
QUESTION ONE:
1. Engaging Lectures: Both the instructor's dynamic lectures and his incorporation of incredible guest lectures combined clear explanations of scientific concepts with thought-provoking questions that encouraged deeper exploration, in a non-conventional lecture format.
Discussion-Based Learning: The emphasis on open discussion allowed students to express diverse viewpoints and refine their arguments collaboratively. After each comment, the instructor maintained the ideal balance between validating his students' beliefs, further fostering an environment in which communication is valid, and also challenging them, asking follow-up questions intended with gauging their depth of analysis.
QUESTION TWO (Components to Retain):
1. Interdisciplinary Readings: Including a blend of neuroscience papers, religious texts, and philosophical essays was invaluable for a holistic learning experience. I will most definitely be re-reading my favorites of the one's he provided, like Lucretius and Plantinga. Not a single reading was short of exceedingly awe-provoking.
Interactive Class Discussions: These fostered a sense of intellectual curiosity among students, compelling me to take the class' complex commentary on the workings of the world with me everywhere I go as I continue to grapple with pressing inquiries, like the pursuit for meaning and the epistemological explanation for existence.

But there is something undeniably visceral about the human experience, that cannot be explained by science, at least not right now, and so there must be room for some higher power... this is a kind of conversation we would have in class! They were so engaging and interesting!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was structured so that a team of scholars and medical professionals would come into class and give lectures on different areas. I gained unique perspectives from each professional who specializes in their field and gives us a sneak peek of their expertise through each lecture in the class. Indeed, I felt each lecture was a glimpse into the medical field through a different lens. For example, in one lesson we would learn about the social drivers of health and the different broader forces at play impacting the patient’s health, and in another lecture, we talked about the cultural differences in truth-telling in oncology and medicine. Though we learned a wide range of topics, the content all tied back to the core of medicine: the intricate balance between medical knowledge and treatment, caring for patients as a person, and the ethical responsibilities that guide medical practice.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class covers a ton of cutting-edge topics within medicine that are making their way to the forefront of public discourse surrounding the place of physicians within healthcare. As such, if you're interested in pursuing medicine and serving patients as a healthcare provider, I unequivocally suggest that you should take this course. It's an easy A and the course content is so sick. About a dozen speakers spoke to us throughout the semester (many of them faculty professors within the Duke SOM), and their talks spiced things up in an otherwise monotonous class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text: I learned about research methods in psychology, how this research can be implemented into our lives in tangible ways, and how the meaning of happiness can differ across cultures.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Since I've taken many psychology classes, I came into this course well-informed about studies, research processes, and other related concepts. However, I learned a lot more about the research part of psychology. Specifically, I was able to get a better understanding of the elements that go into validating research and having it approved. I also learned how to dissect research papers and draw out the important information embedded in those long texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned many methods and strategies to increase our happiness and regulate our emotions. Within lectures, we looked at studies and how we could use their results to increase happiness in our life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Evaluating strengths and weaknesses of existing scientific (psychological) theories, exploring ways to improve your subjective well being, reading research papers

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Positive psychology is not discussed often in the current literature and there are several misconceptions. I have learned about 1) emotional regulation 2) imposter syndrome 3) and about living a psychologically rich life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:

As much as it is a journey of discovery for you, it also is for the instructors.
2. Professor Hartemink and Professor Ebert are two amazing professors that are excellent in providing insights in group conversations and overall extremely understanding and easy to talk to.
3. There are many perks and surprises of this class that make me look forward to every class session. (Come find out for yourself)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
1. Don't take this class because of the T-reqs or the CS elective credit, but because you are genuinely interested in this topic.
2. Otherwise you will not last for a week, since weekly take-home readings range from 30 pages to 100+ pages, and 1000 word reading reflections are submitted every week.
3. But if you are genuinely interested in this topic, there is no better class at Duke that will facilitate that interest.
4. Professor Hartemink and Professor Ebert actually read all of your writings and leave personalized feedbacks (sometimes longer than my submission).
5. Even if you don't come out of this course feeling enlightened, you will still be much more knowledgable about how classical philosophy plays into modern technologies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We studying the evolving relationships of sexual violence and society throughout history and double tapped on recent cases each class where we learned how not much has really changed.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. closely reading and analyzing texts
2. looking at sexual violence in a way that's informed by history 
3. ways to think about the world in what feels like radical ways (eg. how a concept so unknown to us like restorative justice could be implemented to our lives)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about restorative justice, critical thinking, and using history to solve current problems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think that this was my first real college seminar where the course was based in the discussion of new material that I had never read or discussed before. I learned to engage with others' ideas in a way that guides the class conversation forward, to take risks in what I bring to the conversation, and to take initiative in a project that is open-ended but also specifically meant to have real-world consequences.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I now understand the ways rape culture and what it means to be a women was defined in early history to modern day. I learned how to debate for positions I did not believe in as well as positions I did.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) History of sexual violence and how "rape" as a definition is constantly changing
2) How rape is used as a weapon and how justice systems are not victim-focused, leading to lasting consequences for both sides of the party
3) Stereotypes, stories, and overall bonding with the rest of the classroom.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think critically about highly complex notions. Be involved with high level discussions and debates that delve into nuanced and complex notions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about having uncomfortable conversations and creating fundamental change in sexual violence.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Critical Reading- Sometimes I feel like I glaze over the readings for many of my classes, but in this course the content was interesting and actually discussed thoughtfully during class. There were often prompts to help us guide our notes and our thinking while we were reading.
Thinking Beyond Current Structures- This course challenged me to think outside of established structures and systems for offering solutions.
Differing Viewpoints- By having debates in class, we were forced to understand two viewpoints and really understand the merits and pitfalls of both sides of an argument.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of insight into how the legal system treats survivors of sexual harm. I also learned a lot about the history of sexual violence, as well as different strategies/frameworks for combating this issue.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the historical backgrounds on sexual violence along with how prevention and intervention efforts have changed over the years. This course also 'debunked' any misconceptions regarding sexual violence that I had prior to taking the class. It taught me how society can move forward to make an impact and change the culture surrounding sexual violence.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how the legal system doesn't provide justice to survivors of sexual assault as it is designed to prove whether something happened and catch the accused in a lie. I learned that restorative dialogue is the best way to handle conversations related to sexual assault as it fosters a space to learn from both parties. Finally, I learned our discussions of consent need to be more nuanced as solely asking for consent once is not permission for any and all sexual actions as well as it implicitly puts pressure on women to say yes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned how to articulate the causes of the local news problem and how to describe the current circumstances and consequences of the local news problem.
2) I gained insight into how the current culture and environment of the journalism landscape incentivizes some journalists to plagiarize or fabricate facts in their stories, like Stephen Glass.
3) I'm now able to better emphasize in what way the journalist of an article is biased—and I can also avow that all journalists and people are biased in some way. For example, you can be biased towards the truth.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I learned how to think critically about the partisan divide in news and reframe my perspective. I learned how to read articles from opposing viewpoints with an open mind, and consider the bias in journalism. As someone who tries to  naively and impossibly avoid politics, I was also pushed out of my comfort zone to analyze partisan issues and consider the polarization of our news. Go narrow and deep.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I found that the course struck a perfect balance between class speakers and lecturing from Bill. And throughout both mediums, we were continuously empowered as students to ask questions and contribute to the discussion. Specifically, I think the class speakers are what helped to facilitate student learning. Not only did we hear from journalists and journalist experts, but we also heard from students like us who have ventured into journalism and encountered its problems from a fresh perspective. We heard from right-wing-leaning media owners. We heard from people who were impacted by right-wing media rabbit holes firsthand. Essentially, we got a variety of perspectives on the state of journalism, and this empowered us to use these testimonies to form our own conclusions.I also think all of the writing assignments clearly signaled relevance to the class, and they helped to apply and facilitate our learning. The individual prompts were also well-timed with what we were currently learning about or where we were in the course syllabus/timeline.

Finally, we were continuously encouraged to ask and answer questions, which made the class interactive.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Better understanding of the media & journalism industry, a deep dive into some of the issues surrounding trust & polarization, writing tips, creative solutions-oriented thinking

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical media literacy skills, ability to write lively and compelling papers, interesting approaches to media and business

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: On the first day of this course, Professor Adair anonymously asked us how much news we consume on a given day... I was one of the students who consumed 0 articles/day and now I consume 5+ articles/day... all because of this class! Even though the class can be "depressing," as it explores the topic of lack of trust in journalism, it actually made me enjoy reading the news for the first time ever. Instead of reading a news article and only thinking about the subject matter of the article, I now think about how the article fits with the news outlet's business goals (ex: Athletic articles in NYT), whether it is "solutions journalism," whether it could contribute to the problem of "news avoidance," etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Entering this class I had no experience in journalism and was apprehensive of my ability to interact and engage. However, this class was an incredible introduction and inspiration to journalism. The flow of the class from the structures of journalism to innovative solutions was logical to follow. First, I gained knowledge about journalism ethics, the different types of reporting, and interviewing jargon that I will take with me into my professional career. However, these barely covered the surface of the deep insights I gained into the implications of partisan media and the challenges all media companies face. The discussions of Fox compared to CNN and MSNBC were eye-opening and going deeper into more unique media sources allowed me to interact with formats I had not seen before.

response_text:

I developed an understanding of the issues facing journalism.
I learned about the different forms of journalism, both traditional and non-traditional.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Adair was keen on participation, often asking the class to answer unresolved (or unresolvable) questions when it comes to journalism. Additionally, many of the guest speakers he brought in were very engaging and offered their own perspectives on a variety of subtopics in journalism.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Bill's excitement throughout the class and commitment to lively discourse was great. I liked a lot of the readings and the speakers as well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the learning environment is great. Very engaging and interactive from both students and professor Adair. I think the guest lecture part of this class is what makes it great. The ability to speak to people who are well established in journalism makes the class very engaging and we learn a lot as well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the method of having a discussion section in canvas to add in questions ahead of guest speakers helped facilitate learning, it helped me learn the maximum amount from each lecturer.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the mix of lectures and guest speakers. Both were interesting and informative in different ways, and class was never boring or predictable. The on background/on the record lecture was great, and I really enjoyed the chance to hear David Perpich. Phil Boyce was also really interesting to talk to as someone with a conservative take on the media landscape.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Great guest speakers, good paper topics, and Bill is a very engaging instructor

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: To those considering taking this class... we had the coolest guest speakers of any class I have taken at Duke! David Perpich (NYT board member who led acquisition of Athletic, Wordle, etc), Jon Stewart (host of the Daily Show), Nina Jankowicz (cancelled by conservatives for leading national effort to combat mis/disinformation), Amanda Lewellyn (young alum who produces Today Explained Podcast), and so many more!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the organization of the course was very influential in allowing discussion to build deeper facilitating specifically to students who may be taking this course as their first one in journalism. The introduction to ethics, types of journalism, and the leaders in media helped gain a base of knowledge and sources I was able to develop as I continued in the course. The lead into partisan media allowed the issues of today to be addressed which was critical. Finally, concluding with the innovation and future of journalism allowed me to leave this course both intrigued and inspired.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the guest speakers and learned a lot from them. I also appreciated the lectures that incorporated marginalized communities and their role in journalism, and the classes on local journalism.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I quite enjoyed the guest speakers that came to lecture at our classes. I think it was valuable having a variety of backgrounds come in and give their perspective on the topics we were discussing. I also liked that I had three assignments that were set in stone before I even started the class, that way I knew the deadline for each of them well in advance, giving me time to prepare for each one.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed all of the guest speakers and found their insights into specific aspects of journalism that they had developed expertise in to help facilitate my learning. I also enjoyed when assignments varied in their medium, whether that be podcast, documentary, film, etc.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Bill made this class perfectly structured to incorporate guest speakers in with lectures in order to keep the content engaging and fresh for students. I guest speakers should remain a cornerstone of this course for future years.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Extremely relevant, with an inside scoop on how real media works today

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The discussion made the class very intellectually stimulating and how the content is used and engaged with during discussion.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really loved all the interesting and diverse guest speakers.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The discussion component of the class made the course stimulating, and I also enjoyed how Professor Adair evolved the class due to the constantly-changing news environment.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was stimulating because of the creative class environment, lively debates, and speakers. It lacked a bit of academic rigor, however. More papers or readings that we engage with directly during class could have heightened the quality of some of our discussions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Challenging status quo of journalism and reflecting on how we can improve journalism and products of journalism.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating due to the wide variety of speakers and topics discussed.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I loved the chance to engage in deep discussions about what we read. Hearing everyone's perspectives and potential solutions was great. A bit more diversity of opinion in the class might have improved discussions even more, but I think that's hard to get at Duke.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Guest speakers taught me a lot, but felt like some class lectures were not as stimulating as they could have been. Would have liked to see current events consistently integrated into slides/lectures, as opposed to just having one or two lectures dedicated to dissecting Olivia Nuzzi and Mark Robinson or the election. Also could have included pieces from the Daily Show, Fox & Friends, etc. Also, Phil Boyce was an excellent guest and I would have liked to see some more conservative speakers or assignments from/for conservative sources (though I appreciate it's probably difficult to find people willing to talk to a liberal Duke class).

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The range of topics from local to big media and specifically the interaction with guest speakers made it very stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Some of the content assigned was very stimulating, as well as the conversations in class and questions asked to the guest speakers.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I appreciated hearing the opinions of my peers and would encourage opportunities for us to talk to each other rather than at the teacher. This being said, I think we would've benefited more from group discussions and breaking off into smaller groups so that everyone was able to share their ideas and it could've been more conversational rather than one voice in a big lecture, one at a time. That would've at least been more stimulating to me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I thoroughly enjoyed how relevant this class was. In my experience, it is rare to be in a class in which the professor is consistently addressing current issues/events. I especially enjoyed this given the recent election cycle. Keeping up with current events is something that I value, so being able to do so through assignments, lectures, and class discussions was highly enjoyable. My only suggestion would be to make the powerpoints more engaging or perhaps limiting them altogether. Although I understand the informational value they bring, they can also not be particularly intellectually stimulating when taking up the entire class period.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I do feel fortunate as this semester felt the most important and relevant to take this class as it was in the months leading up to what feels like the most important election in our lifetimes. Everything we discussed felt perfectly timed and helped inform me to what was going on in the world around me.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
- Good course
- Content seems professor oriented (ours had a lot about fact-checking)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it. It's not too difficult, but it's a great intro to the journalism and news field. Bill is very good at convincing you that this is definitely not the last class in the department you should take

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a must take course  if you are interested in journalism.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a great course for students taking the JAM minor and also students like myself who are not. It's not the hardest class, but it will require you to be intentional about the three big assignments it has, and it will also require you to be engaged with the material during class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take the course with Bill if you're specifically interested in his work with fact checking because that ends up taking a good chunk of the class. This is not the most rigorous course but it is unique in its level of exposure to great speakers and untouched topics of trust and business in media.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you want to be more informed about politics and journalism you should take this class. Opens your eyes to what is out there and keeps you informed on how to consume news the right way. I believe this is a very important skill to have especially as a young adult going through college and hopefully an election year like we did.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Enjoy it! And speak a lot more in class, I think that proves to be quite important.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class! It might be my favorite at Duke so far (and it convinced me to declare a journalism minor).  Bill is a fantastic professor who makes lectures fun and will introduce you to a variety of interesting topics. You'll learn a lot about media and meet super cool people in the industry. I also made good friends in the class thanks to the small-group environment and open discussions. As an added bonus, the workload was always very manageable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you have any mild interest in journalism or want to just try it out this course is perfect to begin. It allows you to gain so much knowledge about media and dive into all the complexities and implications. My bet is even if you start with a small interest in journalism you will definitely end with a large one after taking this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure you are outspoken enough of a student to participate in this course and get the most out of it. Perhaps take it with people with whom you feel supported.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Understand that though the content is fun and engaging at times, you should see if your learning style will fit with the instructor that is taking it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a good course to take if you enjoy politics and are liberal.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE IT! You absolutely will not regret it. This has been my favorite class and professor I have ever had in my four years at Duke.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: how to diversify my news diet, how to read news more critically

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about current news topics and the evolution of the media and the news.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about different types of reporting (opinion, profile, TV broadcasting, etc.) and the practices and ethics that come with both. I really enjoyed learning about journalists think through the purpose and impacts of their job, such as our class discussions about what is truth, the relationship between subject-journalist-audience, and how information is presented. ALSO this class made me so much more aware of the news, and I think the news quizzes were such a great idea and absolutely essential to the class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. How the Trump administration is attacking the mainstream media 2. How journalists approach the ability to respect and protect their sources and also their responsibility to hold systems/governments accountable 3.The effects of declining trust in the media

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: instructor brought in many guest speakers, many big names in the industry, which was super unique and engaging. I felt very lucky to be exposed to those people

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Guest speakers were helpful to bring new perspective to the class and they were engaging.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class speakers were great, and I really liked getting to read so many different types of pieces.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Guest speakers were great! And the news quizzes were fun, too

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: the facilitation of class discussion with lectures was great. easy to get a good takeaway even if I didn't read everything

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think that it was pretty stimulating as it is, but I think at times debates felt a little one-sided or simple. I don't think this is the fault of the professor but more the class makeup -- it was dominated by students with the same ideologies getting their news from large papers that skewed left of center. Maybe in order to combat this, more of the readings could be from conservative outlets or perhaps "extra credit" of not only keeping up with Reliable Sources/The Morning but also regularly consuming news from right-leaning papers. Not sure how feasible that is but an idea.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This might be a controversial take – and I hate to suggest more quizzes – but I think that if there were more news quizzes that were shorter and more frequent (but still worth a relatively small part of our grade), that would be more incentive to pay attention to headlines throughout the semester, rather than cramming right before. Also, they're fun. And if the stakes are relatively low, I think it would be beneficial.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: take it! I think it's important for everyone, on an academic, cultural, and personal standpoint

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Frank Bruni is a legend, and you should take any class with him that you can. More than just his direct insights, he has access to incredible guest speakers.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You will not practice journalistic writing in this class. This class is a discussion of current events and how political climates shape the media. If you do not like talking about political polarization, do not take this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I loved taking this with Professor Bruni! He was a wonderful professor, a great orator, and a kind person. He is so incredibly knowledgeable about the journalism world and I really valued the opportunity to learn from him.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to really think about political issues from both sides, to be as finely detailed as possible in my writing (reading it over and over again), and to come up with good questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my writing skills, learned more about the process of journalism, and understood the role of the media in our world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course gave unparalleled insight into the world of news and its impact on the public and policy. More specifically, I learned about the business of the news world, the struggle in maintaining local news, and the polarization in the news world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot in this course. I improved my journalistic writing but more notably I improved my idea generation when planning papers. In receiving one of my lower grades at Duke, I learned how to take constructive criticism on a piece of writing and turn it around for the next assignment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a better understanding of how to view larger themes in news. I also developed a thorough understanding of the problems in the current news landscape and the decline of local news. I also developed an understanding of the ethical issues underlying journalism and the journalistic process.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot in this course, specifically about critical analysis and discussion. I also thought this was a great opportunity to write more creatively, though sometimes I struggled with this writing style.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to synthesize news amidst such partisanship, learn from impressive guest speakers, and how to have healthy political discourse in a class environment in a respectful way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I really developed my writing skills, particularly in regards to informative but casual writing. I feel as though this was the first class I have taken which emphasizes writing for readbility, understanding and enjoyment which I think is really important. I also learned a lot about how the news is the lens through which we view our democracy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Writing with concision 
Analyzing differing perspectives and engaging in respectful dialogue 
Skills and mindsets reporters need, whether in investigative journalism, local news, etc

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned:
The importance of keeping up with the news
How to ask thoughtful questions of guest speakers
That journalism and local news is dwindling (and ways we can save it)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have never been more informed on the news than I have been in this class. I learned about how local news is dying and the younger population prefers to get a lot of their news from social media.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the ethics of journalism, the underlying factors that contribute to its eficacy or lack thereof, and what can be done to make the institution of journnalism better.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The legal and ethical protocols for journalism; how journalistic enterprises function as businesses; how to better recognize biases in journalism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how important it is to report against your beliefs and stay quick on your feet in this industry. Being part of the news gives you tremendous power, and it is your absolute responsibility to not fall into easy ways of thinking but rather constantly confer with others, challenge yourself, and make bold decisions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learn all about the news industry. Through the coruse readings, guest speakers and discussion topics, I recognized the important role that news has played and currently plays in our society. I also developed a critical thought process when consuming news.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was amazing. I learned countless things throughout the semester, so I'll just name a few. First, I learned that objectivity is a difficult ideal to achieve in journalism, and the closest we can get to total objectivity is by reporting against our own biases and hypotheses. I also learned that there is no single path to a successful career in journalism, and many successful reporters began their professional lives in other careers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. The intersection between journalism and community-building. 
2. How the news functions as a first draft of history which is why journalistic practices of fairness and truth-seeking are so important. 
3. Ways journalism can distinguish itself in an increasingly crowded media environment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: lots of insights from acclaimed guest speakers in the journalism field, knowledge about the troubles facing the news industry today, knowledge about the values and principles that journalism ought to embody

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned virtually everything about journalism as an industry, and what it means to be a great journalist. I had never taken a journalism class before, so a lot of the material that we covered was completely new to me. I learned so much about the importance of preserving this industry, and what it really takes to be a journalist during this day and age. I learned how to make my writing more muscular, the importance of collecting trustworthy sources, and the type of commitment that it really takes to be a journalist.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much is this wonderful course. I learned how about effective and honest journalism and its societal importance. I learned about journalism integrity, the failing of the news industry, and possible solutions to revive journalism. I learned from Professor Tash and a variety of guests, who were both incredibly knowledgeable and passionate.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: learning how to understand news articles and see a deeper meaning of the newspaper

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course allowed me to develop an understanding of how the evolution of the news has impacted national governance and local communities. I've gained knowledge about how objectivity, activism, and bias in the news affect the production of news. Further, I've learned about the lessons of journalism and how they apply to its future.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much more than I anticipated in this class. Firstly, I learned the value of just pure writing when it comes to consuming news and also producing content ourselves. Next, I learned about the varying dynamics at play that shape the way news is appreciated in our society. Finally, I learned the merit in being a more engaged, critical consumer of news, paying attention to biases that I may otherwise ignore.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so incredibly much about journalism and the state of journalism today. The discussions that stand out to me the most were about anonymous sources, partisan bias in the news industry, and the struggles of local news (and possible solutions). Apart from the knowledge I gained about journalism, I gained experience in writing papers with more personality or journalistic style than the academic papers I had been used to.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1). Strategies and skills to improve our writing
2). An idea of the various problems facing the journalism industry, and how these problems are being combated
3). What it looks like to be part of the journalism industry

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to completely reframe my consumption and understanding of both local and mainstream news. First, I learned that perspective matters, especially when thinking about how a story or article was composed from the interview process all the way to final publication. Multiple guest speakers discussed the importance of newsroom diversity in multiple facets. I also learned how to be more concise and analytical in my writing due to Professor Tash's emphasis on this skill.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about 1) the economic pressures that news media face, 2) the process by which newsroom decisions are made, and 3) the challenges that must be addressed for the survival of the news industry.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Tash was incredible. He made the classroom a welcome environment, encouraged healthy disagreement and asking questions, and provided examples of impactful journalism that resonated with both the academic and human elements of being a student.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Tash was AMAZING. He was a fantastic teacher who taught me a ton about his expertise. He created a kind, thoughtful class community that helped me learn. I thought that the guest speakers and readings were very interesting as well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Tash was incredible; his experience in the news field and connections with the industry were unparalleled. His curation of class discussion, use of get speakers, and insight from his time in the news industry drastically improved my learning experience in the course. I don't think any other individual could have taught this class as well as he did.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Tash is a great professor. He is kind and gentle with his words, but constructive and helpful when it comes to papers and assignments. He has high standards that push his students to do better and assigns readings that are actually insightful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I've learned about the structures of newspapers - how they are divided and structured. 
I have learned about what good journalism is about - having courage, curiosity, and conviction when pursuing the truth.
I've learned about the different types of journalism, from objective news reporting to morning bulletins and opinion editorials, and how journalism can shape history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think critically about journalism and journalistic issues; how to research and form evidence-supported opinions; the values of journalism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Many of the topics we explored in this course are subjects I engage with daily in my role as news editor of The Chronicle. However, I enjoyed being able to hear the varying perspectives of my peers -- many of whom do not have extensive journalism backgrounds -- on some of the ethical questions I am consistently grappling with. The subjects we discussed included how news agendas are determined and why it's important to balance the slate of coverage on a given day, the importance of anonymous sources and dangers associated with using them too frequently, the obligation to thoroughly fact-check all reporting, and much more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how journalists think in regards to how they write, develop and produce news. One thing that I learned that stands out is that "facts are expensive, opinions are cheap." Being sure to take the time to research is important especially when crafting stories. I also learned the importance of clarity when writing and when reporting. And the importance of follow up questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The Role of Journalism in Society - What function does the news play? How has it shaped history? How do people interact with it? How has it changed?
Interdisciplinary thinking - How to approach complex challenges relating to justice and morality in a world constrained by business and personal influence 
Writing - How to edit our writing to ensure we make every word count and aren't redundant

response_text: This was my first journalism class, and I learned a ton about what the field is actually like, the types of stories produced, and how much variety there is in terms of long-form writing, TV broadcasting, podcasts, etc. This class also helped me work on my own writing skills through feedback on my essays, to just getting to read a vast collection of work over the semester and learn from those authors.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write in a less academic/more journalistic way, critically ask questions, and critically approach news.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had know and understood the threats that journalism faces, but I learned more about the complexity and evolution of these threats. It is an insight that I will carry with me as I consume media coverage for the rest of my life. In addition to refining my media literacy skills, I developed news ways of thinking when it comes to understanding the journalism industry. It is not just newspapers and TV outlets, but a blooming industry full of startups and people who simply want to share stories that are interesting to them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course did an excellent job of pushing students to think with perspective. As the semester continued on, I realized that in class discussion there was no right answer for anything we were discussing. Debating the moral ethics of journalism is no easy feat, and this class kept me engaged with the world around me, improving not just practical skills like my writing, but also helped me become more of a global citizen.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Incredible insight into the journalism world and profession, both through Professor Tash's experience and the amazing speakers
- Writing development: I have never had a professor take so much time and attention in helping us write better. 
- Hearing opinions and experiences differing from mine in respectful and productive ways

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot through the course of the semester. In fact, as my first and only journalism class of college, I feel grateful it was this one. I learned to think of news as a moral battleground, and received a well-lit tour of the horizon. I learned about partisanship in the news media and to be conscious of framing. I also learned about several important stories on an international, national and local level. Most importantly, I learned about what good journalism and writing looks like, and some tips and tricks to get there.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to analyze news academically, journalism ethics and morals, ways in which to help the journalism industry in the future

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a tremendous amount about the anatomy of the news business from national to local scales, the shortcomings and bright spots of the industry, and what strong, proper journalism should look like. The guest speakers were phenomenal, shedding light on some of the most pivotal moments in the history of journalism and the impact they have on our world. It was especially interesting to hear these guest speakers speak about the actual process of launching an investigation or expose of a particular subject. This class puts into perspective the indispensable role journalism plays in our society, and that we as a citizenry have an obligation to do our part to preserve that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As a STEM major / not having a pub pol or journalism background, this class was super interesting! I learned about the complexities and challenges surrounding both news reporting and journalistic consumption. My favorite aspects dealt with the discussions surrounding the evolution of the news -- how topics such as fact-checking, polarization, and bias have changed drastically in the last decade and especially the last few years. The class was focused on present-day trends not history which I liked.
