question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I worked on my philosophical writing skills. Professor Hazelwood frequently laments the inaccessibility/pretentiousness of philosophical writing, so by constantly reading examples of good and bad prose or and argumentation, as well as writing our own philosophical papers, I left the class with a better understanding of how to write effective and readable philosophy papers.
2. I developed my argumentation skills. With two in-class debates worked into the curriculum, we had a chance to put our ideas to the test against our fellow students. This was a great exercise in research, argument preparation, and effective delivery of complex ideas. 
3. As an applied ethics course, this class helped bridge the gap between what we learn in classrooms and how we live outside school. The "Living Ethically" semester-long project, as well as the content of many of the readings, helped to demonstrate the link between philosophy and praxis and pushed me to reflect harder on my everyday habits.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: learned background philosophical concepts, learned approaches for evaluating the morality of my own actions and ghg emissions, and I learned about environmental philosophies such as the land ethic and ecofeminism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: knowledge in environmental ethics in various aspects (animal rights, restorative ecology, ecofeminism, value ethics, scientific methodology etc.)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I got better at knowing how to condense my points into a couple of sentences, instead of talking myself in circles.I learned how to craft arguments in a debate format. Specifically, when it comes to knowing how not to walk into traps, knowing when to let logical facilities talk for themselves, and appeal to an audience.I learned how to value when my perspective was not valued. There are times when it is important for all voices to be heard, but there are also times when arguments can only be made in the context of deep personal connection to a topic.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I feel that I gained a thorough understanding of all topics covered in the course, including (but not limited to) the arguments for and against novel ecosystems, the ways Indigenous practices can be incorporated into or complement Western scientific practices, and the implications of Aldo Leopold's 'Land Ethic.' In addition to the topics covered, my ability to discern arguments within philosophical writing was greatly enhanced, and I gained considerable experience formulating and expressing personal ideas and arguments orally.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: the professors often asked a question and mostly left it to the students to formulate their opinions which made the class more engaging

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The pacing of readings was very manageable. Professor Hazelwood changed the reading quiz structure at the midpoint of the semester in response to student feedback and I think the final structure was very effective. I liked the reading quizzes because as long as you did the reading, it'll be easy, but if you didn't, you'll do poorly, so I found them to be fair and manageable, but by including an option for annotations in lieu of a quiz this was very accommodating to students who do the readings but may just not be great test-takers. I loved the debates, they were fun. The living ethically assignment was a great way to tie class concepts to the outside world, which is kind of the whole point of the class so that was great too. Podcast was a cool chance to discuss class concepts further with a real expert in the field. Honestly every part of the class was great and felt like it had a very intentional reason for being included in the curriculum.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: regular readings and quizzes were good for ensuring engagement although still manageable. Instruction and in class discussions were very engaging

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was by far my favorite class of the semester, and a large part of that was due to Caleb. The learning environment was very welcoming. As someone who has never taken a philosophy class at Duke, I was worried that I would struggle to grasp the concepts and fall behind, but Caleb was a great teacher who explained the concepts well and made this class an enjoyable experience for me. I like that the class had a lot of different types of assignments, like the vlog assignment and the podcast assignment, that kept it interesting and pushed the boundaries of what I usually do in classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the quizzes at the beginning of each class were very valuable in making sure that everyone understood the material and came to class prepared to talk. I have been in a lot of classes where nobody actually does the reading, and the class ends up being the professor lecturing at the classroom, with very little room for actual deep and thoughtful discussion. The concept of having a quiz at the beginning of class is scary, and was at times stressful, but it did ensure that class ran very smoothly and was full of actual thoughtful conversation, as opposed to simply being a recap of the text.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Hazelwood's teaching style, while strong from the start, wonderfully adapted to the needs and culture of the class, greatly enhancing our ability to engage with and consume content. For example, Professor Hazelwood would provide reading assessments to determine our engagement with written material prior to class. After receiving feedback requesting a different form of assessment more accessible for those who may have testing anxiety (or anything else other than their understanding of the reading that would limit their ability to perform will on the quizzes), Professor Hazelwood immediately provided an option that allowed thorough annotations of the text to stand in for the reading assessments. I would love for the annotating option to be available in the future, and I found having both the quiz and annotation options to be very beneficial to my learning.Additionally, Professor Hazelwood's classroom management was perhaps the greatest asset for my learning. He expertly guided discussion, providing helpful information and direction where needed. I truly felt that my classmates and I were learning from each other and working towards 'the answers' (as much as there are in philosophy), and there was always a sense of accomplishment when we realized we had 'gotten' a point. Professor Hazelwood was excellent at affirming our viewpoints (or constructively and kindly pointing us in a different direction). The discussion based classroom, particularly due to Professor Hazelwood's involvement, really helped me to retain content, as it ensured that all of the students logically work through readings, rather than being handed a point or simply memorizing an argument structure.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: the professor often asked a question and mostly left it to the students to formulate their opinions which made the class more engaging

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: See above comment about Nasher visit (that was awesome and so perfectly on topic for the class), Professor is a funny and engaging lecturer, every reading felt valuable and I learned something new from it, and there was plenty of discussions (as opposed to just lecturing) in each class. It was the epitome of intellectual exploration because sometimes we'd get on a tangentially related topic that everyone found interesting and we'd just see it through and keep discussing it even if it wasn't on the agenda, which meant we got to cover not just the assigned readings but all the different ideas students had that were sparked by the readings.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: very aligned with my interests, discussion based, thought provoking readings

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The topics were really interesting, and Caleb was great at engaging the class and creating challenging and intellectually stimulation discussions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was very stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings each week covered a topic I was either only vaguely aware of or that I had never encountered before. It was extremely refreshing to hear about new content, particularly from a variety of perspectives. Professor Hazelwood did an excellent job of curating our readings such that each week we often had papers 'for' the topic at hand and other papers 'against' which enabled us to engage with each other and have productive disagreements. I really appreciated hearing both sides of various debates, and it made class discussion much more intellectually stimulating. The content covered was challenging, but not beyond our capabilities, which also made the class more engaging. I also feel that Professor Hazelwood's personality contributed to students' engagement in the course. While serious when necessary, his warm demeanor and humor was excellent at drawing students in to participate and feel confident in presenting their viewpoints. While in the past I have been terrified of 'cold calling', on the somewhat rare occasion Professor Hazelwood used it, I felt empowered (rather than anxious) to share my answer or even admit my lack of understanding on a specific aspect of a topic. Professor Hazelwood did a great job of bringing everyone into the conversation and validating viewpoints, and very quickly our class time turned into free-flowing discussions where nearly everyone thoughtfully engaged several times.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: make sure that you have taken a few classes that require a paper before taking this one

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Drop your Honors Thesis course for this class. Trust me it'll be fine.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: definitely take it! Be prepared to talk and think

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a great course that I would definitely recommend it to everyone! The topics are really interesting and it is not hard to stay engaged with the material. Caleb makes the class an enjoyable experience that I looked forward to every week.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Best professor and learning environment that I have had at Duke, by a mile. Caleb makes everyone in the class feel like they are a person with something valuable to share to the conversation, as opposed to just a student consuming and regurgitating material. I don't think that I have felt as close to a group of students and professor as I have in this class. Caleb made me look forward to going to class twice each week, and I knew I was going to learn something new and hear different perspectives. Caleb also has a clear mastery of his craft, not only in the philosophy of biology, but in a speaker and philosophical interlocutor.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I highly recommend taking this course. It perfectly blends environmental science and philosophy, and is extremely informative and applicable to current events. Additionally, the class is very engaging (and fun). Personally, it was the coveted class of the semester that I really looked forward to attending. While there are a couple of group projects, I felt the work required for them wasn't stressful. Professor Hazelwood is a very fair grader, provides quality feedback to support his grading decisions, and is also willing to provide extra credit opportunities. It's definitely a class where the work you put in directly results in your grade, so as long as you do your assignments with good effort, you should do well in the course. Professor Hazelwood is also extremely helpful in office hours and provides thorough and detailed feedback.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We covered a wide variety of topics in the fields of ethics and neuroscience. I learned about fundamental moral theories and how contemporary neuroscience research informs and complicates our understanding of agency, the penal system, and more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned different theories of how emotion and reason contribute to ethical decision-making, I learned a lot about psychopathy, and I learned about the distinction between the ethics of neuroscience and the neuroscience of ethics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about various brain structures and how they relate to specific functions. I learned about how neuroscience and law interact. I learned about how consciousness is perceived and analyzed from a neuroscientifc lens.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: ethical discussions and talking with others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the neurobiological bases of psychopathy, moral judgments, and addiction.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think philosophically and hold philosophical discourse, how to integrate multidisciplinary information, how to be scientifically literate, and how to critically analyze scientific studies.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The why by which Prof. Huettel, and Prof. Sinnott-Armstrong divided teaching time to give us more information on their areas of expertise was incredibly helpful. I also really appreciated their encouragement of class engagement.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The readings were managable, interesting, and relevant. The May book was especially great!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love that this course is co-taught; it adds a level of dimensionality that really makes the course great. The presentations are always interesting, and I really enjoy the inclusion of a case study and discussion questions in each class period.

response_text: The group discussions made the class very stimulating. Sometimes the length of the slide decks dragged on and made it difficult to pay attention towards the end of class though.

response_text: The instructors frequently challenged us with both philosophical questions and empirical considerations and urged us to question theories and hypotheses we encountered.

response_text: The discussions every class were quite stimulating.

response_text: This class is question/discussion-focused, and the kinds of questions and the nature of overlap between neuroscience and philosophy really made me think in different ways. This was especially effective through the incorporation of case studies and examples regarding research studies. Having guest lecturers was also an amazing part of this class that provided different perspectives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: During Dr. Phillipsen's course, I adapted new ways of thinking about my life in academic settings and beyond. I became more cognizant of how my actions affect my environment in the long run. Overall, this course opened my eyes to exploring different arguments for different problems in our world without the expectation that there is only one correct answer.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to identify and explain an argument, what capitalism exactly is, and capitalism's impact on society and our planet.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Potential alternatives to capitalism 
- Capitalism impacts on progress and reform 
- Capitalism impacts on environment, politics, and social conditions

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to analyze arguments; history of capitalism; presenting ideas convincingly

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I DEVELOPED A WAY OF THINKING ABOUT THE world on a deeper scale than what I had previously. this course taught me to question why things are the way they are and what we will do next to combat destrucxtion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about the various mechanisms through which capitalism impacts our quality of life and degenerates the planet, including through expropriation, exploitation, starving the beast, the illusory concept of money, credit, and how salvery was a fundamental component of capitalism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Ways of thinking about human history and economics that challenge assumptions we make in society
Learning to properly develop an argument with all of its fundamental components
Learning about societies and communities often forgotten in society

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how capitalism has contributed to the injustices in our world today, including climate change, inequality, and exploitation of the vulnerable.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course gave me a completely different set of perspectives to view the world. It gave me a deeper understanding of the capitalist system we live in and how our choices and actions have ripple effects across the entire system and the world that is governed by it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Not only did I learn about capitalism, but I also learned how it is intricately tied with the health of our planet and how we think as individuals on a day to day basis. I learned how to read dense and influential readings such as New York Times Articles or the Communist Manifesto. Most importantly, I learned how there are so many things outside my career realm that I may be interested in studying and advocating for for the rest of my life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: critical way to view life - understand how capitalism influences every aspect of lifehow to engage with a reading. pay enough attention to it, to understand not just the gist of an article, but its central argument

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course gave me a new lens to view the entire world through. I think it brought some of the most critical aspects of life on earth to me in a different perspective than I had ever before considered.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was able to develop a comprehensive outlook on the economic, political, and social environment that we live in, and how capitalism as a system and ideology affects many aspects of them. I learned key ideas about how capitalism functions, and the pros and (many) cons to them in all of these spheres. We also delved into the historical origins of capitalism, how it manifests in the global landscape, and potential solutions for the problems it has created over time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about capitalism, how it works, and its implications for the world around us. It taught us to think critically and challenge our preconceived ideas about capitalism. And we learned how to analyse arguments and critically reflect on what claims and arguments are actually being made in specific readings.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class strengthened my critical thinking skills more than any other course in my time at Duke.  I learned to be more critical of the information I receive and about the historical background of our modern economic, social, and political systems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The greatest concrete skill I learned in this class is how to construct a good argument and how to tease out a good argument from other people.  I also learned how to question the current world and structures that we are usually blind to.  Lastly, I would say I really learned a lot historically about how our modern world came to be.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how capitalism is built on the brutal violence of the enclosure movement and slavery, relies on exponential GDP growth and material extraction from the planet, relies on overconsumption, planned and perceived obsolescence, the creation of imaginary needs. Importantly, capitalism is not just a "market system," it is a way of governing all life. It consumes every aspect of our lives, even ones that we wouldn't expect, such as our most personal and intimate relationships. I learned that we already have all the money, food, housing, healthcare, etc that we need for every human being to live a decent life, but these resources are fundamentally distributed such that the top 1% receives them all, while the poor suffer. We don't need more exponential GDP growth to solve the dysfunctions capitalism has created; we need degrowth.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the degrowth movement and learned about how capitalism is deeply related to the concept of exponential growth. I learned how to better identify arguments from scholarly sources and how to question and challenge notions in our society that we have simply been expected to accept blindly.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the foundations of the capitalist system. I learned about so many of the ways that capitalism is harming people today that I was previously unaware of. I learned about degrowth and care economics as feasible alternatives to our current system.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Phillipsen assigned reading assignments, which made the class more engaging as they encouraged everyone to read all the course material rather than breeze through it. Often, I find myself briefly looking through readings or only reading one of them, especially when I have a heavier workload. The assignment encouraged a closer read of the material, which encouraged further participation from my peers and me.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: By having argument exercises assigned for each class, I came into class prepared every day and learned much more because of this layout.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Very engaging discussions/lectures, mix of learning media with readings, videos, and presentation formats, and keeping students engaged through the argument exercises for each reading; I would keep all of these in future iterations of the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor is a highly engaging lecturer and discussion lead, and makes each class really interesting to both participate in and listen in on. The looser discussion format the class uses should be kept for future years

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class discussions were extremely engaging and people in class participating a lot, making it more interesting.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Philipsen is great and facilitates a very open and intellectually stimulating academic environment. I loved the class discussions and debates - it's seriously one of the favorite classes I've taken at Duke.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor facilitates a class discussion in an engaging way every class, jumping off of my classmates' points to elaborate and extend conversations. The class is truly conversational and personal, based on the readings we would do the night before for homework.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
I loved the cold call discussion/ how the class was a good mix of lecture and discussion (and that the lecture was never slides based, where we had to take notes...)
I liked the group cap projects a lot. Seeing so many of them and preparing one helped me understand how capitalism touches every aspect of life, and developed the muscle for being able to identify how.I also like how there isn't that much writing involved in this course. We have to write so many long, time consuming, and unmeaningful things in college. I appreciated how our assessments were very much tied towards inclass participation and sharing of ideas

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We had a an active discussion everyday. It was a very welcoming and supportive conversation. I would definitely keep the structure of the the day to day classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the argument exercises, as those not only improved my knowledge of the course material by having me engage with it consistently but also strengthened my argument skills (understanding and making arguments). This is a useful skill that I feel empowered to use in the future to improve our world through discourse. I thought the class discussions were usually productive, and the CAP presentations were always insightful and interesting to engage in.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor encouraged everyone to speak up and share their thoughts. We also had to keep up with the readings by writing an argument exercise, this helped to stay engaged and think critically of what claims are actually being made.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The seminar style oh the course facilitated learning, as we were all encouraged to have equal stake in learning and developing our thoughts.  As much work as it was, I would keep the reading reflection and randomized cold call system, as it keeps everyone accountable and responsible.  However, I would maybe add a strike system, or an unadvertised second chance for students who get called on when they are unprepared, just to add more grace and flexibility.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course required a lot of reading and argument assignments for each (2 for every class), a presentation, a paper, and a presentation on that paper.  The class was mostly discussion based, which I really enjoyed, and since you are likely to get called on to explain the argument in the reading, everyone is really engaged.  I will say, I think Professor Philipsen's ideas dominate the discussion, which is not necessarily a bad thing, but it would make for a better discussion if there was more push back from students (but I think this is honestly just a result of ignorance on the topics).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed that the class was an open discussion form, and that the professor would often want students to expand on their thoughts and answers. This isn't a class where "every answer is right" and you get a gold star just for speaking, which I really enjoyed. It allowed me to reflect on my thoughts and arguments and to not say things as statements, but to truly form an argument. This class made me think in entirely new ways through the readings that were assigned.I would KEEP most of the argument exercises, I do not think all 4 parts are necessary. I think that the quote and teasing out the central argument is important, but probably not parts 3 and 4 as they felt quite repetitive. I would definitely keep both the CAP and the Why capitalism matters Paper. Most of the readings were excellent and insightful, but I think at times some were repetitive. Having four every week was definitely overwhelming at times, but I'm ultimately glad to have read them.I would also keep the cold calling, it forced everyone to read the readings assigned and stay engaged throughout discussions. I also really enjoyed the format of the CAP

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Philipsen was amazing! He encouraged us to attend his office hours and was always excited to hear our perspectives and stories. I really enjoyed the CAP presentations specially--where I got to see how students processed everything that we were learning and examined a topic through a capitalist lens, highlighting how we truly live a life entrenched in capitalist values and expectations.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I learned a lot from the readings and from the CAP presentations and class discussions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would definitely take this course. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it - this class will engage you into critical thinking about the way our world works and completely change the way you view the world.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: As someone who comes from a STEM background, completing premed in 4 years without a gap year, I had no idea what I was getting myself into with this class. That being said... I totally recommend this class - one of the best classes I have taken at Duke, my only regret is not taking it sooner. It has taught me so many things about the world I wish I knew before.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class changed the way that I approach the world. Made me a much more critical thinker.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This, in my opinion, is as close to a must-take course as there is. It will challenge you to think differently but I’ve learned so much about the reality of our society and how I can think differently about major issues. The course is stimulating and the coursework is not difficult to do for that reason.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared for a lot of difficult and (sometimes) uncomfortable discussions that will really open up your perspectives on US society and how we function within capitalism.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend this class to anyone, no matter what background, you don't need any specific econ or public policy background. I this class is unique at Duke and will change the way you look at the world around you. I really enjoyed being in this class and the readings and class discussions were always super interesting and inspired me to think beyond just the class setting.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are curious about capitalism, ethics, climate change, post-modern angst, or anything at all related, you should take this course.  It is one of the most intellectually and personally challenging courses at Duke, but it is so worth the journey.  Academically, the reading is demanding but the course load isn’t overwhelming, and it is spread well throughout the semester.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend this course - especially if you are feeling a little lost in your career direction and feel like there's a lot of pressure to go into the typical career paths.  This class is a lot of work, but it is so rewarding.  This is by far the most engaged I've ever been in a Duke class.  If you are interested in how we got to this place in the modern world, (environmental destruction, inequality, work, etc.) I highly recommend.  Just don't take it with a bunch of other high engagement courses.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to read and write a LOT. It might seem overwhelming but it's so worth it. Consider it a privilege to take this course. It truly changed my personal value system and had me up late at night thinking about what was discussed in class. This course will pull out passion in you that you didn't know existed. It's definitely a lot of work but the work is worth it and necessary to learn about the important topics covered

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I took this class as a spring semester senior and even though it was a lot of work (more so than the typical class one expects to take in their last semester of Duke), I am SO SO thankful I took this course. This course has allowed me to challenge and reckon with my preconceived beliefs about capitalism. Not only that, I am now better at arguing what I believe are some of the "good" capitalism has brought and the bad and how we are now living in an epoch where we need to move on and create a better societal system that aligns more so with our values and natural world.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It will change the way you think about the world

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about the origins of philosophical thoughts on democracy by reading the works of Plato and Aristotle. We then examined how early ideas of democracy helped form American political institutions and the Constitution. Lastly, we learned how to write a philosophy-style paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned not only how to further analyze the writing of Nobel prize winners themselves, but also how to unpack the historical and social contexts behind them. By covering a new work of literature every week, we got a sense of the type of writing that earns this sort of recognition, in addition to an understanding of the breadth of form and topics that have been awarded the Nobel Prize.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read cross-textually and consider themes that persisted across all texts. I learned how to place texts in their historical, political, social environments. I learned how to bring in philosophical ideologies when reading texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking, analytical writing, literary criticism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Critical Analysis of Literature: One of the most significant skills I developed in this course was the ability to critically analyze literary works. We learned to dissect complex texts, examining their themes, narrative structures, character development, and use of language. This involved not only understanding the surface-level content but also interpreting the deeper meanings and societal implications. 
Historical and Cultural Contextualization: The course enhanced my ability to place literary works within their historical and cultural contexts. This skill was crucial in understanding the significance of each author's work in their time and its lasting impact.
Diverse Perspectives and Empathetic Understanding: Engaging with a broad range of authors from different cultural backgrounds greatly enhanced my ability to appreciate diverse perspectives. This course encouraged an empathetic approach to literature, urging us to understand and respect viewpoints and experiences different from our own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think more analytically about a literary text. I improved my skills in close reading, synthesizing my thoughts, and identifying themes that run throughout a piece.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned not only how to further analyze the writing of Nobel prize winners themselves, but also how to unpack the historical and social contexts behind them. By covering a new work of literature every week, we got a sense of the type of writing that earns this sort of recognition, in addition to an understanding of the breadth of form and topics that have been awarded the Nobel Prize.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading a book a week and analysis readings critically, it also helped with writing literary texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read cross-textually and consider themes that persisted across all texts. I learned how to place texts in their historical, political, social environments. I learned how to bring in philosophical ideologies when reading texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking, analytical writing, literary criticism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Critical Analysis of Literature: One of the most significant skills I developed in this course was the ability to critically analyze literary works. We learned to dissect complex texts, examining their themes, narrative structures, character development, and use of language. This involved not only understanding the surface-level content but also interpreting the deeper meanings and societal implications. 
Historical and Cultural Contextualization: The course enhanced my ability to place literary works within their historical and cultural contexts. This skill was crucial in understanding the significance of each author's work in their time and its lasting impact.
Diverse Perspectives and Empathetic Understanding: Engaging with a broad range of authors from different cultural backgrounds greatly enhanced my ability to appreciate diverse perspectives. This course encouraged an empathetic approach to literature, urging us to understand and respect viewpoints and experiences different from our own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think more analytically about a literary text. I improved my skills in close reading, synthesizing my thoughts, and identifying themes that run throughout a piece.

response_text: Creative thinking and critical analysis

response_text: We learned so much. We learned a lot about history and philosophy, and I think our explorations of so many texts in such depth made me a better critical reader and writer.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I’ve learned how to become a more ethical and engaged leader—both in research and in any future pre-professional experiences. This journey has emphasized the importance of rest and sustainability, as well as the power of cultural humility. I’ve also gained a deeper understanding of how our values shape our decisions and how researchers, leaders, and policymakers have a responsibility that extends far beyond themselves. This experience hasn’t just made me more informed, it’s made me a more intentional and compassionate person.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Community engagement practices, how to conduct root cause analysis, how to engage with communities you are not a part of

response_text: ethics and political thinking

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to conduct community-based research and not impose my biases on the communities we will be entering this summer for our research. I learned how to be a leader and uplift voices around me that are typically not heard as clearly. Finally, I learned to give myself grace and forgiveness. This class was very nice to take within my first year, because it provided a mentality to make change throughout my Duke journey and to not put pressure on myself.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained more self-awareness on my privileges and disadvantages, learned more about how to ethically engage with a community when it comes to research, and how to not put my biases onto others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned different ways to approach ethics as well as how to explore problems without overstepping. I think most importantly, I learned what it means to be an ethical leader and how important vulnerability and empathy is in that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this class I notably learned about decolonized frameworks of ethical leadership, ethical epistemologies, a deeper understanding of researcher-participant power dynamics, and how to center equity in the world of research,.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1. Dr. Hy was incredible at creating a warm and welcome environment—they began the semester establishing a community agreement, and the agreement of ‘recognizing the both/and’ (i.e., recognizing that multiple realities can be true at once, and therefore having this foster constructive and safe dialogue across differences) really resonated with me for the rest of the semester (and will beyond this semester)
2. Dr. Hy’s (and Carina, our TA’s) emphasis on progress over perfection—even if our submissions weren’t perfect, they encouraged us to submit our assignments anyway. As a lifelong perfectionist, still being recognized for ‘work in progress’ and my thoughts and writing in ‘first draft form’ helped massively in making me feel more confident and able to articulate my semi-formed thoughts, which really helped me engage with the course more—I really, really appreciated this

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The communities of practice on Wednesdays was a very interactive and effective way of both discussing and digesting the weekly material. I think one of the strengths of this course was the consistent structure that allowed students to measure progress in understanding from week to week. Additionally, I felt all of the guest speakers added something to our understanding of ethical leadership and I really appreciated the diversity in age and experience on the panels.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
Aspects that made the class stimulating:
1. Our incredible guest speakers, which featured experts, fellow students, and Hart Leadership alumni—it was so cool being able to interact directly with the authors of our readings!
2. Systems Change Project, where we were grouped by areas of research interest (e.g., tech policy, healthcare equity, etc.)—this allowed us to apply our learnings directly to an area of interest tied to our summer research as well, which really helped us prepareCould’ve been more stimulating:
1. I also really, really loved our class discussions! That being said, the format for the first half of the semester also began to feel a little repetitive (every Monday, we’d discuss each reading first in our small groups and then with the class, and every Wednesday we’d do the same thing with a different group (‘communities of practice’)). This was before we began our guest speaker lessons, though—that really elevated our learning, and made each lesson super interesting! Maybe spreading the guest speakers out more throughout the semester would help overcome this.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) how to connect health and humanitarianism to a more religious context 
2) how to conduct ethnographic research based on interviews and analysis
3) how to define and interpret acts that are deemed to be "humanitarianism"

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to develop an understanding of religion and humanitarianism through an anthropological approach. I also learned how to interview others in an ethnographic style. Lastly, I learned more about anthropology's history and anthropological theories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One thing that I learned is the importance of critiquing and not following information blindly. Another thing that I learned is what humanitarianism aid is and how it affects all of us. Also, one thing that I learned is how to conduct a professional interview and analyze it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: thinking about the way different religions think in different time periods, how to interview people, how to collect ethnographic data, class conversations and being able to connect to other people's thoughts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed interviewing skills and learned about ethnographic writing. Also, I learned about the history of humanitarianism and how it interacts with global health and religion (two areas that I had not considered its impacts). Finally, I learned about the importance of critically examining structures and avoiding the usage of the word "inherent" because it takes away from the system's impact and reduces it to the individual (in looking at how "aid economies" manifest in various parts of the world).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
critical consideration of philanthropic organizations/work being done
analysis of the ethics behind charity work
more deeply understanding the intersection between religion and humanitarianism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class I developed my critical thinking skills and learned how to evaluate a specific topics from multiple perspectives. Prior to this class I think I accepted a lot of things for the way that they were, but through this class I've learned to leverage different perspectives and think about one topic in different ways. I also strengthened my reading comprehension skills in interacting with readings before every class and pushing myself to think about them in a high level way in order to be able to contribute/have class discussions be meaningful. I was also able to refine my abilities to write in a concise way because I found that since every class was interesting and full of new thoughts, I had too much to write for each paper and had to condense them down to the most meaningful parts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about humanitarianism, especially unspoken issues, the interview process, which aided my people and communication skills, and time management.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about ways of using ethnography to analyze ways of giving. This included thinking about how other religions might conceptualize giving entirely differently, such as "uncompassionate care." We also learned about humanitarianism more broadly and the way this can intersect with religious beliefs, such as in the case of evangelicals in Uganda. Also, we learned about how different religions handle the ethical questions that arise from power imbalances between givers and receivers, such as the ways in which Liberation Theology emphasized an approach that contextualized inequalities and emphasized rights.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically think and engage in a form of rigorous analysis when reading a cultural anthropology paper on a theory framework or case study by engaging deeply with the argument not only in a logical linear fashion following the paper but to also really think through and challenge the presented ideas. I learned how to read the case studies presented in anthropology papers and analyze and and form my own opinion by engaging with them not only on the author's presented term of the paper but through my own and differing viewpoints. I learned how to write a paper that articulated a clear concise flow of logic while gaining a greater appreciation for the many ways tones and nuances can be layered in an argument.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about the ethics and anthropology of humanitarianism, and learned how to discern advanced readings with many allusions to history, culture, and religion. Furthermore, how to engage in the process of an interview, and the challenges of social hierarchies in doing such. Overall I learned very much from the outside readings and assignments of this class, not only in regards to ethics and global affairs, but about various distinct cultures, religions, and histories which I could not gain from a regular global health class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course facilitated deeper thinking about our systems of humanitarian aid and gave me a new set of anthropologic tools by which to examine the world, introducing such terms such as philanthrocapitalism and biopower (which helped shape my program II!) I was also introduced to new philosophies of giving within different religions such as Islam and Shamanism.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Dougan's course was one of the most memorable courses I have had in my time at Duke so far. Professor Dougan was extremely funny and personable during class, and used many analogies and anecdotes to better describe an abstract idea or concept. Professor Dougan was easily able to simplify a paper or many concepts that took me many reads and left me with my head spinning and feeling like there was no point in the paper to bring me to a point of understanding where I felt I could explain it to someone else. He was very kind and respectful, and always took the time to understand our point of view or misunderstandings on a topic to better explain a concept to us. The readings on the course were all very crucial and built up a rigorous foundation for my understanding of religious frameworks of humanitarian aid in a stepwise manner, but also gave differing points of view to allow us to navigate and reconcile conflicting viewpoints for ourselves.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

Dougan picked the readings very strategically, and that it allowed us to have a very comprehensive overview on the history, modern state, and future of colonialism’s effect on humanitarianism. Through this seminar, I gained much insight on the two parties including the policies of both the parties and the thinking behind parties when trying to levy support during an election. I also gained helpful skills on how to debate with classmates and consider opposing views. Lastly, I learned interdisciplinary analysis for example looking at the economic problems that influences the politics of the presidential election.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The main thing I learned was the skill of having a civil conversation with someone I don't agree with. Within that,
1. conversing to understand rather than to make my own argument
2. listening actively
3. weaving together empirical evidence, news headlines, and my personal experiences to further a point

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I got outside of my comfort zone. There were a lot of times where I disagreed with a lot of what was being said in the classroom. Although it was at points uncomfortable, I learned new points of view.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about the US, the electorate, this current election, and elections in general. This course helped me develop my critical thinking skills about campaigns, their actions, and their intentions. I feel like I can now identify voting patterns based on demographics and the positionality of voters. I feel more connected with the US and the issues that compel people to vote the way that they do.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- I learned how to engage with political perspectives that differ from my own in a manner that is thoughtful and oriented toward mutual understanding.
- I also learned how to critically evaluate policies and political rhetoric through multiple partisan angles, rather than just my worldview. 
- I learned how demographic backgrounds do--and sometimes, do not--shape how salient different policies are to certain people.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to make an informed voting decision, what goes into campaign strategy, and how to hold productive discourse with students who disagree with me.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have further developed my ability to speak ideas, listen to others opinions and respectfully read a conclusion, as well as the history of politics and how we got to where we are today.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I've developed the skill of analyzing and understanding different perspectives of voters in America. Through our discussions of each campaign and its strategies, I have also gained a greater insight into why the 2024 presidential elections played out as they did. This course has helped me look at every opinion with true open-mindedness.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In Nasser Hussain's class, I learned to deepen my critical analysis and communication skills throughout learning about the election and the emerging developments. While analyzing the both campaigns on the Democratic and Republican side, I took off our partisan lenses and I learned to use and refine my bipartisan approach through critically evaluating the merits of each candidate in a non-bias way. Insights on the institutions we have today and how ideals from the last 2 decades have embedded themselves from within was fascinating.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: I highly recommend this political policy class to any student considering it in the future. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: My expectations were sky-high and were mostly met. However, Watkins lost control when he allowed the demos to control the classroom setting. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the discussion-based element of the class because it allowed students to hear perspectives that approached the question from different angles. Professor Watkins always had thought-provoking questions and was able to guide the conversation really well. I also loved the structure of the course starting with philosophy and then moving into current affairs. It was so interesting to see how modern conflicts followed the same shape as ancient ones, and how the lessons learned from history still apply to today.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Completely discussion based with instructor going over the readings briefly then opening up the floor for socratic seminar-like class. The open discussion part was great and kept each class interesting because what we'd discuss would be co-led by the students and the instructor.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was the most engaging class and the professor was always available to discuss either course material or other relevant topics during office hours which helped facilitate the high level of engagement.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I deeply enjoyed the lecture + seminar format, and found Professor Watkins to be a great facilitator of in-class debates. The reading notes & discussion guides provided were deeply helpful in parsing historical texts/beliefs. Would have appreciated a slight tilt towards the instructional lecture formats (to ensure discussions were kept high-quality and nuanced) instead of the seminar discussions, but still found it productive nevertheless.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The readings and reading responses before each class ensured that I developed a comprehensive understanding of the material before each discussion, Then, the discussion-based format each class was a great way to learn and understand a wide variety of viewpoints from every student. I found myself thinking in new way and questioning my own beliefs every class which was refreshing. The required papers were also a great way to engage with the philosophers we read while integrating philosophy with the history we'd learn about in the readings. I appreciated the freedom for each paper, with 3 prompts we could choose from.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the Reading Responses. I thought they were a nice way to keep track of my learnings and thoughts in a non-stressful way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the use of the Socratic method, and I further loved the occasional change of scenery (occasionally the result of a coup d'etat).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Despite not being considered a seminar class, the seminar-like style was conducive to sharing and questioning political thought. This element, hopefully in addition to a seminar credit, should be kept.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Considering the content and how well it was delivered, I can't think of a way in which Professor Watkins could have made this more interesting to engage with.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The reading responses did not facilitate much learning or critical thinking (since they were so open-ended) and rarely lead to further conversation or analysis. They felt more so like a checklist, and didn't really contribute to my learning. The specific subjects and ideas that Dr. Watkins prioritized were also oftentimes too abstract and subjective to have meaningful conversation over, and the class didn't really lend itself to discussing implications and applications of the ideas we discussed.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was incredibly stimulating. Even when I was not participating in some debates, being in the peanut gallery was fun too.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
