question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Everyone has a unique calling based on their gifts and circumstances
- How Christians ought to act in work (in love)
- Advice on singleness and marriage

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We covered a variety of perspectives on voction from religious and secular thinkers. Specifically, we learned about calling from examples of God in the bible, secular ideas like "do what you love", and an interesting unit on calling for disabled people.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Thinking about how the idea of vocation has changed over time, from it's foundations in the Bible to the modern day.
Comparing secular vs. Christian writers on vocation.
Comparing primary source texts / biographies and applying them to our lives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how many people throughout history have thought about the idea of vocation, how students on this campus deal/handle vocation, and why vocation may be important to our own individual life and what role does that play.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Practiced how to connect and critique various sources on subtopics within vocation, especially distilling/identifying central theses within these sources (really helpful skill for remembering them). Developed some Biblical foundations for topics related to work and calling by God. Practiced developing complex/significant arguments in our papers which we were challenged to do.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I “defamiliarized” the idea of the Protestant Work Ethic by learning more fully what that actually means both to Weber and other Protestant authors
2. Incorporated more topics into my understanding of the Christian concept of vocation, to include subjects such as Sabbath rest, marriage, and even persecution/martyrdom; this afforded me a broader and richer view of the concept of being called by God
3. Received personalized feedback on six essays throughout the semester, and will be receiving feedback on final project, which helped to strengthen my writing skills

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor presented the historical context for the readings in the class and facilitated the discussions by asking deep questions. She challenged us to think about our beliefs and values as well as our interpretation of the readings. I would keep the argumentative and evidence-based essays in the future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the discussions and all the topics covered. I would keep the short lecture into discussion format.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The environment of the class was welcoming, serious, and very open to a diversity of ideas. I thought Dr. Wagner did a good job emphasizing that the classroom is open for discussion and even disagreement, and that you didn't need to fit a certain set of beliefs to belong. The seminar style class was good, as it kept me engaged and made me feel the need to do the readings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was heavily discussion-based which I thought was very conducive to critical thinking and allowed multiple viewpoints to be expressed. I would definitely keep lots of discussion in the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: She gave mini-history introductions which was useful for the older articles that we read. She prompts the class semi-frequently, so she guides the discussion usually without feeling over-bearing or it feeling like its her soap opera.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I felt that the socratic seminar structure for each class was immensely helpful, engaging, and interesting. We were all encouraged to participate (though I can understand if that is a difficult environment for some) and Professor Wagner asked really thought-provoking questions that helped us to dive into the readings and see these topics in a potentially new way. I enjoyed getting to hear a lot from others, and trying to articulate claims / come up with evidence from the reading on my own. I would keep the largely socratic discussion part of the class for future years. I think the no electronics policy also helped me to stay engaged since I get distracted easily (also just nice to have a class where we're not on electronics and get a break from that).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
- Well-curated readings that drew on a range of different Christian and secular writers
- Frequent essays of shorter length with thoughtful feedback 
- Final project that incorporated all of the sections of the class into a holistic final product
- Awesome guest speakers

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings from this class came from different perspectives, and the discussions in class were always full of different opinions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We talked about a variety of different topics and listened to arguments from different views on each topic. I particularly liked discussion on controversial topics, such as the Sabbath, or saints living in total devotion.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The discussion with classmates was very thought provoking. Dr. Wagner has great opinions on a lot of these topics, and I think most people would appreciate to hear her thoughts on things. She did a wonderful job guiding discussions, sometimes filling in gaps in our arguments in a way I found quite impressive. She is also a wonderful speaker, articulating complicated topics clearly and thoughtfully. To make the class more stimulating, I'd consider adding more chances for students to select outside sources.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The selection of topics and variety of readings made the class stimulating. I think discussing the opposing viewpoints on certain issues (like singleness, work vs. rest, effective altruism, etc) could make it more interesting.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Hearing different perspectives whether it be from Christians which is where the idea of vocation originate or from secular non-religious people, it was cool to hear how vocation has guided their life. Being able to talk about how different people approach vocation within a college setting also was cool because it was a connection that the issue at hand is not only historical but ever-present in our everyday life.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: A lot of these topics had a good blend between high level principles / theories / frameworks and pragmatic application. I enjoyed getting to read from such a wide variety of authors and sources across the Christian tradition, and I think I was able to articulate certain claims and explore them deeply through the amount of discussion, reading, and writing that we did. It was cool to be able to connect ideas from the Bible, pre and post modernity

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was intellectually stimulating by encouraging me to think about questions of vocation and theology in an open-minded way, and not just from my specific subset of the Christian tradition.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure you're engaging with the readings and are prepared to present your thoughts in class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a lot of reading and writing, and you get out of the course what you put into it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great class. Very interesting, but do know it will demand time. It forces you to be dedicated, but you will get a lot out of it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a good class! It has a fair bit of reading but otherwise it is not too challenging to succeed. If you do the readings and participate/listen in discussion, you'll learn about differing viewpoints of vocation/work/approach-to-life.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There are consistent essays(short 1-2 pages every other week so not too difficult), so if you don't like writing it may not be the class for you(she is seeking to change it?). If you wondered whats the purpose of your life or have wanted to dialogue and understand how people have came to that decision from the perspective of someone believing in a higher power or someone who is secular, it is both good for that. While you will not die if you do not do the readings, to get the most out of the class wanting to engage by reading and talking during discussion is heavily promoted.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don't be scared to talk in class, and block out enough time for the readings and writing assignments

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Christian approaches toward vocation is a great topic to be thinking about during your undergraduate time at Duke. The pre-professional nature of this university can lead you astray if that's not grounded int deeper truth.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I genuinely think that this class pushed me on many fronts. It taught me how to do a class which such dense complex readings, it challenged me to think critically on my feet in class, and it kept me challenged but in a way that never felt un-welcomed / unhealthy.I really appreciated learning about different thinkers (which I apply both inside and outside of class now)-- and bringing this through the rest of the course. Seriously an amazing course... I was very nervous to take to at first but I haven't regretted it for a moment. This taught me also to follow my interests -- despite fears -- because it will be much more rewarding to learn about a topic you actually enjoy and to challenge yourself opposed to simply taking an easy-A class just for the transcript boost.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: (1) I learned various terms and concepts in Ethics, Philosophy, and Cultural Anthropology. (2) I developed theoretical frameworks which have changed the way I look at the world. (3) I learned about hope. First theoretically, then in terms of medicine, home, and crisis.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to compare and connect different texts from throughout the semester. I also developed my close reading skills. Finally, I learned how to take texts from authors and add my own interpretation.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Anne Allison is fantastic. She is astoundingly brilliant on all fronts, has thought a lot about the topic of hope, and genuinely cares about what your thoughts are on the readings. Her reading-recaps are beyond helpful (she takes dense readings and makes them actually digestible), she is always able to answer questions, and she too applies the thinkers that we learned about early on in the semester on a daily basis. Professor Allison is a major component for why this class was so amazing and I think that she really went above and beyond to facilitate learning, engagement, and understanding in her class. Further, I think that she organized the class in a very intentional way. It was very smart to have thinkers first, then medicine, home, and finally disaster. She clearly thought about the structure of the course and every reading that we did / how it would weave together into conversations in class -- and I really commend her for how it played out throughout the semester. Professor Allison was also extremely available for help outside of class (I personally met with her a bunch) and she was overwhelmingly helpful each time. Finally, I really have appreciated the thought that goes into paper prompts because they prompt critical thinking that is engaging, intellectual, but also fun and enjoyable. Her and Anton did a great job with this -- serious kudos to them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Allison would guide the class through each reading. She would outline the general argument of a reading, draw connections to other readings, and emphasize the key takeaways. Some of the readings were more philosophical and dense, so I appreciated this method of instruction. Professor Allison was also incredibly encouraging. She was excited for us to participate, would help us articulate our points, and would refer back to our comments in later classes. I always felt heard and supported in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having the circle discussions and hearing all the unique insight Anton (TA), Professor Allison, and fellow students had to all the papers we read. The final discussion in replacement of the final essay was nice.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really loved the circle discussions, because it did not feel like a lecture at all. I also loved how we all would read the readings before class and come with our own individual interpretations before hearing what the professors thought or what my classmates thought.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was really stimulating simply because of the material that was selected and how all of the pieces that we read were constantly put in conversation with each other throughout the course. I genuinely think that each piece was picked for a reason and I really enjoyed doing readings that pushed me out of my comfort zone and engaging in class.Talks were always engaging and Professor Allison always posed thought-provoking questions to the class which was always challenging, yet enjoyable.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Allison made the class incredibly intellectually stimulating. Every weekly reading was fascinating. Professor Allison brought in two guest speakers. She shared her own experiences in Japan. I even thought the two short papers were fun and satisfying to write.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
- DO THE READINGS. I cannot stress this enough. 
- Try to really understand all the thinkers that you learn about in the first unit because they will all come up in conversation throughout the rest of the course and doing this would create a foundation to make the rest of the class easier.
- Just have fun with it! it is challenging but incredibly rewarding. You don't need to understand everything fully, just try your best
- Start your essays as early as possible - the prompts are long and really thought-provoking, which means leaving it to the last minute is not really possible
- Also meet with professor Allison outside of class! She really is the best!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class is by far the best class I have taken at Duke! Professor Admay challenges us to develop our critical thinking and close reading skills through a comprehensive list of TDQs (Thinking Development Questions) before class. The class discussions are always intellectually stimulating and open my perspectives to new areas that I have never thought about before. I have developed a much stronger critical thinking lens and have learned to look at issues from multiple perspectives with more maturity.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Dichotomy of humanities-communications style storytelling, ethics of storytelling in advocacy settings and what it means to tell someone else's story, using stories for advocacy work and to enact policy change, dissecting the messaging inside of memoirs about development work, critical thinking around what it means to create development policy that best suits the needs of communities, accompaniment and what it means to work alongside communities, rather than "for" as an outsider (nothing without us about us is for us).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: -Close reading, how stories and narratives shape minds, perspectives (the soft powers of storytelling), tangible impacts of “edutainment” and how to send those messages in an open minded way, the dangers of development work, but also hope for the world and the light that stories provide

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- distinctions between humanities and communications methods of storytelling and interrogating why one method may be chosen over the other 
- how storytelling is done using different platforms and methods -- videos, prose, graphic novels, guest visitors, etc
- critical analysis and thinking of who is telling a story, why they are telling the story, on whose terms is a story being told

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Tools of artistry : looking at devices storytellers employ strategically to tell stories (juxtaposition, irony, humor, etc.) 
Stories for Communication vs Stories for Humanities
(Ways of thinking) the dangers of a single story - really took to heart

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I developed the ability to analyze the shortcomings of stories that marginalize voices and impose narratives of what development “should be”.
2. I increased my capacity to listen to stories with empathy and curiosity as to truly understand the intentions of artists and classmates.
3. I was able to separate my policy brain focused on outcomes and results to a humanities appreciation for good stories and for understanding individuals.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course provided the opportunity to dive deep (in a way we don't always have the chance to in fast-paced policy oriented classes), to evaluate stories and their impact (both perceived and intended), and consider the implications for telling and elevating stories for social change (particularly when they are not our own).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have learned how to effectively analyze media and understand the importance of centering people in storytelling. I have learned the value of fully sharing and receiving stories.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved that we were mixed grad and undergrad. These are friendships I will carry with me, and it was so valuable to have different generations of perspective. It made me feel more connected with younger communities I may serve in my career and led to great networks, mentorship, and learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the half graduate/ half undergraduate structure, as well as the active class discussions. Admay always pushes us to go a step further and to question our ideas and dig deep

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Admay did a great job creating a culture of discussion. From making name tags to sharing stories with each other, we built rapport fairly quickly. I think the discussion style, the short stories we told, and TDQs beforehand were all helpful to promote a great learning environment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought the class activities were amazing, especially the story exchange and the guest practicioners. so was the teaching your own class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Admay is the best professor I have had at Duke. She is charismatic, compelling, extremely knowledgable and her passion for the subject area is contagious. She puts an incredible amount of time into preparing each lesson, pouring hours to think through the guiding questions for each class discussion which prepares me well for each class. I also love the participatory culture of the class, where every student is invited to speak and share their thought without hesitation or fear of any kind. Professor Admay has fostered an incredible collaborative culture in the classroom such that everyone has become friends. I have never seen this kind of class environment elsewhere.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Admay structured cooperative debates around the different works of storytelling methodologies that we read, forcing us to think critically about what we disagreed with or agreed with and why and also to defend our points or change our minds in conjunction with out peers. She also facilitated our learning by posting very detailed readings and instructions with thought and discussion questions on her Sakai page for each class, giving us a preview of what class would be like the following day to structure our thoughts around themes and takeaways. Most of all, Admay allowed us to put our learning into practice by allowing us to teach a "new narrative" that we would have the class read/watch/listen to and then dissect together to see how it used storytelling modalities to advocate for policy change or raise awareness for a social issue.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Admay is a brilliant instructor, her being just radiates compassion and genuine care. I really loved the class debates we had in class, I found that those were particularly intellectually stimulating (embodying different characters in Living Poor, HONY vs. Cunningham) and really made you consider and reflect upon different perspectives and arguments to form your own opinions. I also loved all the New Narrative classes at the end, and felt that everyone did an amazing job — those narratives added so much to class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course consisted of multiple reading and listening materials that fed into a broader theme related to story-telling that we focused on in class. Course materials were complemented by New Narratives that we engaged in -- ideated and facilitated by classmates to present new thinkings or projects or solutions to the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Cultivating a culture of compassion with accountability

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Admay’s personal attention to all of our needs as students was the most meaningful part of this course. She continually asked us what we wanted to learn and created space for new narratives. She invited reflection and constructive feedback (like the survey towards the middle of the semester). It felt like we co-created this class with her and created our own culture.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: More so than any course I've ever taken, I am leaving this class with a sense of community. Admay,s skills in creating this environment are invaluable.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I loved how Admay relied on creating “sticky” points for us to hold onto from stories. These created the foundations for threads to emerge. This class could have been made more stimulating by having more “creation” of stories from the part of the students, where we write/perform stories and get feedback on it and move from the critique to create lens.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The variety of types of stories we read and the variety of types of conversation made this course incredibly stimulating. You really need to sit deeply with the material so I found this class more stimulating that other classes I've taken at Sanford because I really felt like I had to consume everything to make sure I showed up fully present for class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: One aspect of this class that made it stimulating was open discussion and having guest speakers who wonderfully contributed to our class objectives. Having conversations that challenged my way of thinking and encouraged me to use a new lease in story telling was transformational.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is one of the more artistic and creative course you will take at Sanford, and you need to enter with an open mind and a willingness to be authentic and flexible. You will be valued as both a student and as a person in this course and you will leave it with meaningful relationships. If you want to apply the skills you learn in this course, you will have to think deeply about the specific things you are learning and what they mean for YOUR process. This process is subjective and the class will be, too.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: 100% take this course but be ready to read and push yourself.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You might complete the course without knowing what you actually learned but you will think differently after taking the course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You get out of this class what you put in. If you engage with an open-mind and are ready to think this class will serve you. Admay, is a great person to know and a great person to have in your corner.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Admay is an amazing person, and you will have a bunch of fun in this class! You will learn more nuances and less hard and fast skills.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE THIS CLASS 100%! You will regret if you do not take this class!! This is truly a life-changing class (something that I have never said before), and I came to Duke exactly for this type of classes.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: THIS CLASS IS A MUST TAKE FOR ANYONE WHO WANTS TO DO POLICY, LAW, OR ADVOCACY WORK OF ANY KIND. Admay is a supremely engaging instructor who provides detailed feedback, interesting class material, and runs her classroom with immense love and grace. I learned so much and I know I will be a better lawyer, policy advocate, and general human being as a consequence of the critical thinking I did in this course. Be prepared to work hard, as Admay can be a hard grader, but it will only make you a better thinker and writer.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course!! Regardless of whether you want to go into policy or development work (I don’t plan on it), this class and Professor Admay has so much to offer you. You will also get to connect with so many people who come from all walks of life — this class truly ends up feeling like a tight-knit community by the end of the semester. Take it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don't be deterred by this course's "Public Policy" label! Although we spend time linking concepts to policy and macro-level development ideas, the class has really been about how we move through this world as humans and how we listen to and process stories -- which are all fundamentally about understanding human nature and having a better concept of how we want to contribute as empathetic and caring individuals to the societies of which we are part. This course is applicable regardless of your major, would highly recommend.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! Admay is someone you want on your team. The relationships you build in this course under Admay’s leadership are for a lifetime.  Your mind and your community will change for the better.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Admay truly cares about her students and wants them to succeed. She is a mentor that you can always go to if you need help. The class is pretty easy workload, and it requires having an open mind and willingness to critique and co-create the class. If you do those two things, this class will be a meaningful experience for you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: With the right level of engagement on your behalf - this class can be transformative. Take advantage of the opportunity to learn from a combination of undergraduate and graduate students. Take advantage of the intentional community that comes out of 1) the nature of this course and its materials and 2) the community that Admay works so hard to create.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend future student to take this course! If you are are passionate about international development, human rights, stories, and curious of how all of the concepts connect; then this is the class for you!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The difference between empathy and sympathy, the power of stories from both an advocacy and humanities perspective, how to frame concepts in the context of development to name a few.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the specific aspects of a "good" story, how to use story to promote sustainable development, and how to deconstruct a story for meaning and purpose.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Admay truly went above and beyond. From the very first day, I was impressed by how much she already knew about each of us, and throughout the course, she continuously integrated our ideas into the class. That made the learning experience feel incredibly personal and intentional.Overall, we learned the deep importance and transformative power of storytelling as a tool to help build a world where every living being can flourish. Storytelling is one of the most powerful tools for change because it’s deeply embedded in how humans have shared knowledge for millennia—and because it speaks directly to the emotional part of the brain that shapes decision-making.Through this course, I learned:
1.  How to use artistic storytelling techniques and frameworks to craft narratives for social impact.
2. The science behind why stories move people and how they can shape attitudes, behaviors, and policies.
3. How to identify and counteract harmful or dominant narratives by telling stories that align with our values and vision for a better world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was the only class I've taken in Duke that challenged my way of thinking, I would have multiple "aha" moments in the course related to fundamental aspects of society, change, power, etc. that are missing in every other course.Insights- understanding parallel ways of communication, their intention, impact, power, strengths, weaknesses, and how to structure them. I feel incredible empowered to use this information to frame policy, and feel like I am walking away with value that all students should be getting because I took this course.Methods/skills- this is the only class where we consistently analyze and really go deep into the underlying ideas, values, impacts, and structure of development. Even though it was an international development course, the application is across all sectors because most policy we're interested in (schools, transpiration, etc.) is touched by development and is at its core, a subsection of development. I found the class to be highly relevant to every aspect of policymaking, and the process of metacognition, reflection, and analysis is unmatched. The skills and methods in ways of thinking I learned and practiced in this class are the most valuable aspect of my MPP so far.Knowledge- I learned so much about how a topic I was interested in- communicating policy- has a wide field around it that has very intentional goals and being able to really get exposure to the macro-level landscape that then shapes our ideas as policy makers that we're exposed to in the world, and then understanding how to TRULY analyze those options and expand, was a highlight. In prep for our final paper, we reviewed key parts of our work and key readings to reflect on and were asked which reading we would remove from the syllabus- I did not have a single one I would remove because I was so grateful for all that I learned. Meanwhile, in other courses you can get an A without ever doing the reading b/c the readings don't add anything and the professors just ask for you to spit back what they told you. Admay actually teaches you how to think, teaches you how to analyze, reflect, meaningfully synthesize, etc. and those skills are the kind that make leaders, create change, and actually influence policy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to look critically at development, its definitions, and its leading thinkers
2. What makes a good story and how to use stories strategically to convince stakeholders
3. How to value the gift of a story from someone else and how to treat someone's story as a gif

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned to analyze stories/narratives in the development space to identify effective strategies for advancing specific values, ideas/beliefs, agendas, and policies. 
2) I learned to craft my own stories/narratives employing these tools, refining my skills while drawing from resources shared by past cohorts and my current classmates.
3) I learned to put design my own class session around a strategic story/narrative of my choosing and integrate it into our learning outcomes and the other materials on the syllabus.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a deeper knowledge of how to use storytelling and storytelling devices to encourage societal and policy change. I learned what “development” means and how to engage in it in an ethical, self decentered way

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned to distinguish between listening with sympathy and listening with empathy—understanding that true empathy involves setting aside my own perspective to fully hear and honor another person’s experience in their own words.
2. I gained insight into the difference between message-signaling and humanitarian storytelling styles, recognizing how the latter values the listener’s autonomy in making meaning.
3. I developed a more critical and nuanced understanding of concepts like “development” and “empowerment,” realizing that these terms are more complex than often portrayed by global institutions and that I have a lot more learning and thinking to do.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to think strategically about storytelling by understanding audience, intention, and impact.  I gained insight into how values and identities shape stories—and how to center authenticity and the nature of being human

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to read all things well and understand intentional artistic decisions across genres. I learned teaching and deep listening skills, so many valuable personal skills. And finally, I learned the content of these stories, what I didn’t know before— a new way of thinking about development, about poverty.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Loved the story exchange, the guest speakers, new narratives, and honestly just the super personal way Admay teaches the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Admay is amazing. She will really push you to think and go deeper with the materials, which I appreciated. The class was incredibly collaborative and engaging.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Admay is incredibly intentional in crafting every single class. She genuinely thinks through how each of us might interact with the material, and that level of care, detail, and mindfulness is something I’ve never experienced before. Her intentionality made a huge difference in how we connected with the content and with each other.She is also very thoughtful in the feedback she provides on our assignments and creative work, always encouraging, constructive, and grounded in a deep understanding of our intentions. Beyond the classroom, she’s generous with her time and always willing to listen, whether during office hours or after class.Another key strength of this course is the diversity of students it brings together, undergrads, grads, people from many cultures and belief systems. Admay fostered a space where everyone felt safe to share, reflect, and even be vulnerable. That inclusive and supportive environment was essential to the learning experience and should definitely be preserved in future iterations of the class

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The TDQs to guide our reading, and making every reading meaningful were huge. Admay does NOT want to waste your time, and so she'll give you a one-paragraph excerpt out of a chapter if that's the part she wants you to learn instead of assigning the whole thing and only referencing one point.Admay really emphasizes it being our class, catering to our needs, seeing what we already know/what we want to know, and really goes above and beyond to ensure that the class is helpful and powerful for all of us. When we create our own lessons for the class, she requires so much intentionality and focus in prep, ensuring that all student projects are valuable and also teaching us what kind of intentionality we should bring to any presentation/workshop where we're asking for others' precious time. She's incredibly thoughtful, reflective, intentional, and smart. How she thinks, and what she says, are so valuable.I also really love the human aspect of this course, Admay emphasizes community and wellbeing and it really, really shows. She does not waste our time, she does not give us busy work, and all the assignments are intentional. She is understanding and flexible, open to new ideas of how things should go, and strikes the ideal teacher balance of firm, high expectations and loving, warm support to get there.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course was very fast-paced but extremely topical and fostered an incredible learning environment. Continuing this culture of teamwork and community would continue to be an asset to this course. The readings were also incredibly dense with meaning and conversation pieces. The syllabus was detailed and Admay was the asset that ensured that the pieces and the course facilitated our learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Admay was very good about adapting to the needs of the class, which I appreciate. She is able to sense where the conversation is going and I not afraid to redirect back to the set plan or explore a different avenue entirely. This is a skill that not all professors have.I also appreciate that she continuously makes en effort to update the course based on the information she learns about each of us throughout our time together. She makes a point to invite specific people in when she recognizes the topic is within their area of interest or expertise.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There was an environment of friendship and positive communal energy that made discussion deep, rewarding, and easy to participate in. All assignment details were clear and the guests were impactful and relevant to the course material

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciated how Admay created a learning environment rooted in deep respect and care for every one of us. She took the time to truly get to know each of us—how we think, feel, and express ourselves—and she meets us where we're at. She is transparent about her lesson plans and intentions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Admay fostered a supportive, collaborative environment that made thoughtful risk-taking feel safe. She is best professor I’ve ever had! The instructor’s feedback was clear, constructive, and always encouraged deeper thinking.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciated the class culture doc, and the seminar style. Plus, admay knows this, but she is a FANTASTIC professor. The effort she puts into everything she does, the effort and intention inspires me to me more intentional with both my education and everyday life.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Admay. A story is a gift, how can we honor that gift. A person who teaches you about stories is also an invaluable sacrifice that I will carry with me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Our conversation. I also appreciated, with our written assignments, how explicit the instructions were. It really helped me engage with the material correctly.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was very stimulating because of how deeply it connected personal reflection with broader ideas of social change. We weren’t just learning theory, we were using storytelling as a powerful tool to express values, challenge dominant narratives, and imagine a better world. The emotional depth, creative exploration, and the safe environment that Admay created made it possible to be vulnerable and grow. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Admay has really done her work learning how to teach and how people learn, so you do the readings + pay attention and you WILL learn. If you sit on your computer and don't read, you might not, but TRUST me when I say it's not difficult in terms of time or energy to do, and the way this class grows your thinking brain is truly stellar. Admay talks about metacognition, which gives us the skills to learn how to learn instead of always depend on others to guide us. It's so rare that professors do this, and it's so powerful.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was SO stimulating! The discussion, the buy-in from my classmates, the tough questions we addressed, the adaptive learning -- all of it was incredibly engaging and I learned so much in this course that I will apply to the rest of my policy career.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The vast and diverse amount of material that we covered was great.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I enjoyed the New Narrative projects where I was able to engage with the ideas and chosen interests of my classmates

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The parts of the class on storytelling were the most intellectually stimulating, such as breaking down how stories work to make us think and feel certain ways. Too often in development we think about head knowledge, like logical arguments for or against development, but not often enough do we talk about the narratives that shape our discourse.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made the class stimulating was the freedom to explore meaningful topics through our own creative lenses. It encouraged me to think deeply about not just what I wanted to say, but how and why I wanted to say it.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Everything!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class, and do the readings!!!!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I’d definitely recommend this course to a future student who is open to trying something different. It’s a great opportunity to slow down, reflect, and connect, not only with a diverse group of classmates, including younger students and MMPs, but also with yourself. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: YOU HAVE TO TAKE THIS COURSE! And then, please please please put your computer away and do the readings. Leaders are able to shape the world, and this class helps you understand both how to do it yourself and how others are doing it around you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Same as above, this is a must take course for anyone who wants a fuller understanding of the policymaking process. While policy development, implementation, and analysis is important, the stories/narratives we construct around these policies are just as important. In some ways, this class builds on 803/804 Policy Analysis I/II by allowing us to see how values, ideas/beliefs, agendas, and policies are advanced in practice. To me, this course is essential for anyone who is wanting to engage in policymaking in today’s age because it caters to the heart of how we relate to each other as human beings: through story.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

We had to tackle a lot of challenging texts, but I think the order in which we completed them made sense because we had to use the concepts as perspectives for future readings.  It was an interesting anthropological course, something I was not used to, we did not do a lot of field work and creating our own ethnographic work, nor did we solely read ethnographic material.  I did not expect this, but I have started to apply the tools we learned in this class on reading and discussing as well as the key concepts and developing ideas in other courses.  In summary, I learned how to go through readings differently and apply new perspectives for future readings as well as connect these to other readings with my own concept I create such as we did in the papers and finally talk through and relearn a reading in a way I did not originally do such as we did in Winart.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about proper ways to annotate reading, and how to read scholarly sources in general.  I also learned how to write an anthropology paper, I had never written a true college paper let alone anthropology paper so I learned the format of how to write that but also learned the differences between high school and college writing. I also learned so much through the course through discussion, we talked all the time and it was so helpful as it developed my understanding and knowledge of the reading but also the concepts within.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved having a specific syllabus with everything already planned at the beginning of the class. This was helpful for me in writing the essays because I was able to start early and write a paper that I could be proud of.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved how all of us were able to participate each class (disucssion-based rather than lecture). Instructor was very helpful and was willing to change the activity for the day based on the general consensus of the students. Structured but not too structured

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Solomon challenging us throughout class with difficult readings and topics helped to facilitate my learning because it made me think hard about everything we were learning and the different implications of it. I definitely think Professor Solomon should keep a lot of the syllabus the same because it helped me to improve my argument and reading comprehension skills.

response_text: Sitting in a circle every class really facilitated discussion and learning and I didn't realize how much an affect it would have. The discussion based classes also forced everyone to stay engaged considering how small the class is.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

Reading articles individually and then discussing them until we came to shared understandings in class was a wonderful way to not only learn the "facts" of the readings themselves, but also what the readings revealed about the course's themes overall.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Solomon provided a lot of specific feedback and models that truly helped my skills improve without it just being "trial and error." Additionally, having required readings was tedious at times but certainly necessary and taught me a lot.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Solomon was organized and communicative, we at times had trouble reading through different texts just because they were so dense but he would then reschedule class time just dedicated to going through pieces line by line and discussing until we all understood the message. the current method of one reading for each session, followed by a small reflection and then class discussion was one that worked really well and felt natural while also teaching a lot-- also having all the readings files linked to Google Drive is helpful because it is easy to go back and have them in one place

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is not a course about how hospitals actually work, it is a course about labor and how labor is performed in different circumstances.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think this is an awesome first year class. It I challenging but not work-load wise, thinking wise. It introduces skills that are critical throughout all college courses so it prepares you for everything to come. However, it does not overload work and there is no busy work so it's a good balance.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is not just for pre-meds or sociology majors - this class is a wonderful and interesting way to explore society, labor, and current events through many different lenses, while building very important academic skills. It is not difficult, and only requires a few out of class assignments. The majority of work is done via a very open discussion in class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: As long as you really take the time to understand and consume the readings and take each piece to your perspectives, you will take away a lot from this class!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class has only a few essays throughout the semester, but readings are due almost every class. Readings are graded based on three annotations which you do on the assigned reading. The annotations are pretty easy just 3-5 sentences per. The final assignment is a podcast which is pretty easy as well you work in groups and it takes a few hours to complete.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The readings are much longer and more complex and will take longer than expected. Purchase all of the books in the beginning of the year because the due dates sneak up on you and trying to get a book quickly is difficult in the middle of the year without spending a ridiculous amount of money.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to read a lot, and know that you will not understand everything-- but you will learn so much: in addition to the concepts, you'll learn just how to read effectively and what to pull from articles and how to make sense of works within historical context. cool guest speaker opportunities, meaningful assignments. This class taught me more about how to be a better writer than w101 ever did. If you have any interest at all in healthcare then this class is worth taking, and the prof is extremely smart (can be initially hard to follow, but cares a lot about us understanding and always takes time to cool it down and explain)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Some things I specifically learned through this course was a lot about specific aspects of healthcare in the United States that is lacking. For instance, I learned about how healthcare workers have to also consider many other social factors of their relationship with their patients, and avoid making their interaction like a transaction. We specifically dove into specific ways that we can prevent this, and make patients have the best care possible, and feel like people. In addition, we learned of women's health, and how lacking society is in accommodating it in terms of the level of knowledge and resources. Lastly, we learned of the economic aspects of healthcare that make healthcare almost inaccessible.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the best part of this course were the literary cafe's. They were great for multiple reasons. The first being that it allowed us to work with our peers in a collaborative setting, which was not done commonly in the class. Secondly, I just think it is frankly a lot less intimidating and easier to share when the students themselves are the ones presenting and asking the questions. Due to this, I think our best discussions came from our literary cafes. I think that the guiding questions that were used for each book were very effective. However, I think more needs to be done to prompt us to engage with the text rather than just asking questions.
