The variety of skills and knowledge we learn in this class is awesome, and Dean Sue is truly the best. I doubt you will have such a positive relationship with any other professor.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This has changed my view on the world in so many amazing ways. I recommend this course to anyone.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class. I could not recommend a first year seminar more. In the beginning, I really didn't know what I was getting myself into and I was nervous that I chose the wrong course. I simply could not have been more wrong, This is seriously the best class I took this semester. If you ever have the opportunity to take this class, do it. Dean Sue MAKES the class. She is everything and a literal angel on Earth.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this course, one of the best first year seminars at Duke.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's an amazing course especially because of the instructor. Take it with her, she's really good at creating an inclusive environment.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE IT!!! Dean Sue is the most inspirational person you'll ever meet, and the course content is applicable to all areas of academic interest. Regardless of what you want to do in life, you'll get something valuable out of this course for sure.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to be increasingly aware of the way societal systems norm us and how we are subject to those normative ideologies; I learned how to connect and tap into my body as a means of thought; I practices the skill of thinking in an imaginative and creative way to approach social change.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I really liked this class because I learned a lot about social injustices and social problems. Three things that I learned that really resonated with me are the connection between how diabled people are treated and the treatment of animals, the act up movement in the 80s and 90s surrounding HIV/AIDS, and how some children are at a huge disadvantage when it comes to access to education.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about how movement is a form of communication and can be used for activism, thought, and expression. We also learned a lot about different activist groups and what they did. We also learned how to think outside the box of what we think of as normal when it comes to restructuring and changing the systems we have in place to try to better our society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how to have productive discourse on politically motivated topics, particularly in an environment with various opinions on certain subjects. I also learned much about the connection between thought, emotion, and movement. To add to that, I understand my body and how I can utilize moving it as a tool to gain a deeper understanding of myself and my perceived environment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to use my body to think and what it means to "embody" concepts. I feel more connected to my body now. I also learned what the "soma" is and how philosophy, ethics, and neuroscience can inform how we process trauma, think, and perpetuate societal norms. I also know much more about the AIDS movement, criminal justice reform and reparations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of insight into what types of issues are out in the world and I got to develop my perspective on those illuminating problems. I learned how to think outside of the box and be creative in thinking up solutions to change the narrative, the societal norms.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Problem-solving skills, knowledge of current events and topics that are currently affecting society, and insight into how these problems can be solved.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course really made me think about my life and the position I'm in. It really made me want to be more aware of what is happening around me, especially what is going on in the scenes around social injustice and art. I learned a lot about the history of social injustices like sexism, racism, and classism. This class helped me to think using my body and know what it feels like to getting closer to merging the mind and body into one.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As a hardcore STEM enthusiast, I never in my life thought I would sit through a small public policy seminar during my first semester of college. But, looking in retrospect, this seminar was my one of my favorite classes that I have taken. First, I learned to think outside the "norm." During class, we called our professors by their first names and sat on bean bags and wool carpets instead of chairs. We had wild discussions ranging from prison abolition to using our body to connect with our thoughts ("dance is thought"). These discussions made me think outside the box and realize that if I continue to imagine the seemingly radical ideas, maybe one day it will become a reality. Secondly, I learned how to analyze texts and lead discussions/debates that differed from my personal, political, and ethical views. Our discussion section was very close-knit and welcoming, and I learned to value not only sharing my own opinions but also listening to other's viewpoints and peacefully debating controversial topics. Finally, I learned the value of exploring various ways to approach radical ideas. For instance, throughout class, we used our body to get in touch with our radical view of the world. This was very stimulating and eye-opening in that movement can change our thoughts and be used as a vehicle to explore the most radical ideas that are subconsciously in our brain.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professors were very available to talk, and facilitated deeply thought provoking discussions throughout each class and through the reading. This allowed me to analyze to a deeper level.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that they definately did a good job having us engage in class. It was refreshing to have teachers who also spoke about their opinions and ideas in class as well as leaving space for us students to discuss. the class was definitely not lecture based which I appreciated. It was a conversation between everyone including our professors which I really liked.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professors did a great job of pushing our thinking to the next level by always asking us questions to deepen our thoughts. They also did fun things in the dance studio, like setting up sculptures and art around it to create an environment that pushes the boundaries of what we see as normal.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think this class did a fabulous job of balancing productive discourse with artistic elements of movement. Having an approximately 50/50 split between discussions and movement breaks kept the class interesting, informative, and fun. I would say the overall structure of the class is refreshing from the typical lecture style, so I recommend keeping it the same in future classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that the class felt conversational and the instructors were overall very open to new ideas or even tangential conversations. I also liked that we were able to call them by their first names as it created a greater sense of intimacy. I also appreciated that the class was held in a dance studio as it was a great canvas to build upon as we moved, built, and imagined.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The ways the instructors facilitate my learning by giving me the opportunity to learn on my own in a capacity of no-hand holding of figuring out what is important to me and what I as an individual can do in the here and now. I love the weekly reflections of seeing different modes and solutions to societal issues that impact us in a small or little way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: instructors made classroom environment very comfortable and safe, applying unconventional methods (like sitting on the floor, setting up classroom in a strange way, referring to profs by first name, and using movement to engage the body and the mind during class time) to challenge what is deemed "normal". I liked the casual, comfortable environment of the class and felt that it helped students engage more with the material and think outside the box.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The part of the course that I really enjoyed the most was the movement exercises that we did. We were lead in an exercise typically meant to bridge the gap between body and mind and use our imaginations to do so. We were challenged to do movements we've never felt before and experience new feelings. The instructors used these exercises to expand our imaginations. We learned what it was like to imagine new ideas from the texts that we read in class and how people in the past have really thought outside of the box in order to address social injustices. The instructors gave us a good amount of reading material but let us interpret our own understanding in discussion posts. I think I would keep these same methods of instruction in the future, except that some weeks had a large amount of reading.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Both instructors were very very VERY welcoming, friendly, and easy to approach. I even turned to Brookes for personal advice and had a conversation about my love for arts and how I could explore that throughout college. The professors were genuinely SO caring about each and every one of their students, and I will always be on a lookout if they teach more courses in the future. They not only helped me grow as a student and a thinker, but as a person.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The deep conversations, the lack of normativity in the teaching style, and the engaging and comprehensive discussions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course was extremely stimulating because we talked about so many different and interesting things that really made us think and form opinions. As I said before, there was a lot of talk about social justice issues and issues that plague the world so talking about those definitely got me thinking.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating because we were constantly being pushed past our comfort zone in a good way. We had to move and think differently, forcing us to be outside our comfort zone.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the emphasis is on thinking beyond the normal patterns we inhabit. I appreciated that we strayed away from the typical approach to social justice. I feel that this skill is something I can take with me into my future education and work in social justice. I also think that the skills we learned about being in touch with your body are wildly important and I have inhabited them as part of my mindfulness and self-reflection techniques.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really appreciated the readings—it was nice to get a new perspective and information on some social justice concepts I don't interact with every day. I also appreciated the different art projects the instructors presented at the beginning of some of the classes.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The discussions made the class stimulating and the active movement in unlocking the suppressed emotions created by society.

It also highlighted the importance of the body, which is often overlooked in typical classrooms, in the process of thinking and brainstorming.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This course was most stimulating to me because it covered topics that were new and proposed viewpoints I hadn't looked through.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was one of the most stimulating classes I have taken in my life. It was very stimulating in that the class was set inside a dance studio and the whole premise of the course being about breaking the norms of the society.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to move and go outside of your comfort zone! You will learn a lot about social issues in a thorough way, which better prepares you to engage with/understand the world, the news, and current events.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that the course is definitely so interesting and not like any other class I've ever taken. I would tell the student that you have to engage in some uncomfortable things but ultimately they make you more aware of yourself and how you take up space in the world around you. I would also warn them that there is a lot of reading and it does take a lot of time out of your day.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is not much work, but it is a lot of fun. The professors and the course are pretty liberal and focus on social justice issues. If you do not care about social justice a lot, I recommend not taking the class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's not the typical learning style most Duke students are used to. If you excel in lecture-based classes, this will be outside of your comfort zone. However, there are a lot of benefits to inhabiting a different kind of learning environment and I feel the skills I gained from this class, in terms of discussing politics and being in touch with my body, can be harnessed beyond the seminar.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is definitely not your typical Duke class. I appreciated it because it was a refreshing departure from some of my more "normative" large lecture courses. However, be prepared to push your thinking. Be prepared to be uncomfortable, embarrassed, confused, inspired. There is more reading than I expected.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course was amazing in opening my mind to the real world and providing a break from the college structure.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It will definitely push you to escape the limitations of your comfort zone. There may be times where you will feel uncomfortable with the movements and physical activities conducted in the class, but ultimately if you engage, you will learn and grow as a student and as a thinker and activist. Teachers do a good job ensuring that the classroom is a safe space.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would encourage students to take this course because it helps them to realize the situation they are in and how to use your imagination to work for a better future.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will change the way you think and view radical ideas. One quote from Brookes and the reading that will forever stick with me is "dance is thought." As a dancer, this quote stays in my heart as I perform and practice every time. I have always battled internally whether my movements lead to my dance moves or my movements led to the feeling of liberation I always have when I'm dancing. But through this course, I realized that dance is purely just my thinking; movement is thought. This course taught me how to view my dancing career and also imagine for liberation. As the professors said, radical imaginations are always needed for real change.

As a dancer, this quote stays in my heart as I perform and practice every time. I have always battled internally whether my movements lead to my dance moves or my movements led to the feeling of liberation I always have when I'm dancing. But through this course, I realized that dance is purely just my thinking; movement is thought. This course taught me how to view my dancing career and also imagine for liberation. As the professors said, radical imaginations are always needed for real change.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: On the first day of this course, Professor Adair anonymously asked us how much news we consume on a given day... I was one of the students who consumed 0 articles/day and now I consume 5+ articles/day... all because of this class! Even though the class can be "depressing," as it explores the topic of lack of trust in journalism, it actually made me enjoy reading the news for the first time ever. Instead of reading a news article and only thinking about the subject matter of the article, I now think about how the article fits with the news outlet's business goals (ex: Athletic articles in NYT), whether it is "solutions journalism," whether it could contribute to the problem of "news avoidance," etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Entering this class I had no experience in journalism and was apprehensive of my ability to interact and engage. However, this class was an incredible introduction and inspiration to journalism. The flow of the class from the structures of journalism to innovative solutions was logical to follow. First, I gained knowledge about journalism ethics, the different types of reporting, and interviewing jargon that I will take with me into my professional career. However, these barely covered the surface of the deep insights I gained into the implications of partisan media and the challenges all media companies face. The discussions of Fox compared to CNN and MSNBC were eye-opening and going deeper into more unique media sources allowed me to interact with formats I had not seen before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I developed an appreciation for the role of local news in my community.
I developed an understanding of the issues facing journalism.
I learned about the different forms of journalism, both traditional and non-traditional.

response_text:

I have learned how to apply these skills in different formats of media.

response_text: I developed a deeper understanding of the foundations of journalism and journalistic principles, the necessary role fact-checking plays in journalism as well as in our larger democracy, and the evolution of the journalism industry as well as the threats it currently faces.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

My only suggestion would be to make the powerpoints more engaging or perhaps limiting them altogether. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a great course for students taking the JAM minor and also students like myself who are not. It's not the hardest class, but it will require you to be intentional about the three big assignments it has, and it will also require you to be engaged with the material during class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take the course with Bill if you're specifically interested in his work with fact checking because that ends up taking a good chunk of the class. This is not the most rigorous course but it is unique in its level of exposure to great speakers and untouched topics of trust and business in media.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you want to be more informed about politics and journalism you should take this class. Opens your eyes to what is out there and keeps you informed on how to consume news the right way. I believe this is a very important skill to have especially as a young adult going through college and hopefully an election year like we did.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Enjoy it! And speak a lot more in class, I think that proves to be quite important.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class! It might be my favorite at Duke so far (and it convinced me to declare a journalism minor).  Bill is a fantastic professor who makes lectures fun and will introduce you to a variety of interesting topics. You'll learn a lot about media and meet super cool people in the industry. I also made good friends in the class thanks to the small-group environment and open discussions. As an added bonus, the workload was always very manageable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you have any mild interest in journalism or want to just try it out this course is perfect to begin. It allows you to gain so much knowledge about media and dive into all the complexities and implications. My bet is even if you start with a small interest in journalism you will definitely end with a large one after taking this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure you are outspoken enough of a student to participate in this course and get the most out of it. Perhaps take it with people with whom you feel supported.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Understand that though the content is fun and engaging at times, you should see if your learning style will fit with the instructor that is taking it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a good course to take if you enjoy politics and are liberal.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE IT! You absolutely will not regret it. This has been my favorite class and professor I have ever had in my four years at Duke.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: how to diversify my news diet, how to read news more critically

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about current news topics and the evolution of the media and the news.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about different types of reporting (opinion, profile, TV broadcasting, etc.) and the practices and ethics that come with both. I really enjoyed learning about journalists think through the purpose and impacts of their job, such as our class discussions about what is truth, the relationship between subject-journalist-audience, and how information is presented. ALSO this class made me so much more aware of the news, and I think the news quizzes were such a great idea and absolutely essential to the class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. How the Trump administration is attacking the mainstream media 2. How journalists approach the ability to respect and protect their sources and also their responsibility to hold systems/governments accountable 3.The effects of declining trust in the media

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: the facilitation of class discussion with lectures was great. easy to get a good takeaway even if I didn't read everything

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think that it was pretty stimulating as it is, but I think at times debates felt a little one-sided or simple. I don't think this is the fault of the professor but more the class makeup -- it was dominated by students with the same ideologies getting their news from large papers that skewed left of center. Maybe in order to combat this, more of the readings could be from conservative outlets or perhaps "extra credit" of not only keeping up with Reliable Sources/The Morning but also regularly consuming news from right-leaning papers. Not sure how feasible that is but an idea.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This might be a controversial take – and I hate to suggest more quizzes – but I think that if there were more news quizzes that were shorter and more frequent (but still worth a relatively small part of our grade), that would be more incentive to pay attention to headlines throughout the semester, rather than cramming right before. Also, they're fun. And if the stakes are relatively low, I think it would be beneficial.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: take it! I think it's important for everyone, on an academic, cultural, and personal standpoint

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Frank Bruni is a legend, and you should take any class with him that you can. More than just his direct insights, he has access to incredible guest speakers.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You will not practice journalistic writing in this class. This class is a discussion of current events and how political climates shape the media. If you do not like talking about political polarization, do not take this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I loved taking this with Professor Bruni! He was a wonderful professor, a great orator, and a kind person. He is so incredibly knowledgeable about the journalism world and I really valued the opportunity to learn from him.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to really think about political issues from both sides, to be as finely detailed as possible in my writing (reading it over and over again), and to come up with good questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my writing skills, learned more about the process of journalism, and understood the role of the media in our world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course gave unparalleled insight into the world of news and its impact on the public and policy. More specifically, I learned about the business of the news world, the struggle in maintaining local news, and the polarization in the news world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot in this course. I improved my journalistic writing but more notably I improved my idea generation when planning papers. In receiving one of my lower grades at Duke, I learned how to take constructive criticism on a piece of writing and turn it around for the next assignment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a better understanding of how to view larger themes in news. I also developed a thorough understanding of the problems in the current news landscape and the decline of local news. I also developed an understanding of the ethical issues underlying journalism and the journalistic process.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot in this course, specifically about critical analysis and discussion. I also thought this was a great opportunity to write more creatively, though sometimes I struggled with this writing style.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to synthesize news amidst such partisanship, learn from impressive guest speakers, and how to have healthy political discourse in a class environment in a respectful way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I really developed my writing skills, particularly in regards to informative but casual writing. I feel as though this was the first class I have taken which emphasizes writing for readbility, understanding and enjoyment which I think is really important. I also learned a lot about how the news is the lens through which we view our democracy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Writing with concision 
Analyzing differing perspectives and engaging in respectful dialogue 
Skills and mindsets reporters need, whether in investigative journalism, local news, etc

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned:
The importance of keeping up with the news
How to ask thoughtful questions of guest speakers
That journalism and local news is dwindling (and ways we can save it)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have never been more informed on the news than I have been in this class. I learned about how local news is dying and the younger population prefers to get a lot of their news from social media.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the ethics of journalism, the underlying factors that contribute to its eficacy or lack thereof, and what can be done to make the institution of journnalism better.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The legal and ethical protocols for journalism; how journalistic enterprises function as businesses; how to better recognize biases in journalism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how important it is to report against your beliefs and stay quick on your feet in this industry. Being part of the news gives you tremendous power, and it is your absolute responsibility to not fall into easy ways of thinking but rather constantly confer with others, challenge yourself, and make bold decisions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learn all about the news industry. Through the coruse readings, guest speakers and discussion topics, I recognized the important role that news has played and currently plays in our society. I also developed a critical thought process when consuming news.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was amazing. I learned countless things throughout the semester, so I'll just name a few. First, I learned that objectivity is a difficult ideal to achieve in journalism, and the closest we can get to total objectivity is by reporting against our own biases and hypotheses. I also learned that there is no single path to a successful career in journalism, and many successful reporters began their professional lives in other careers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. The intersection between journalism and community-building. 
2. How the news functions as a first draft of history which is why journalistic practices of fairness and truth-seeking are so important. 
3. Ways journalism can distinguish itself in an increasingly crowded media environment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: lots of insights from acclaimed guest speakers in the journalism field, knowledge about the troubles facing the news industry today, knowledge about the values and principles that journalism ought to embody

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned virtually everything about journalism as an industry, and what it means to be a great journalist. I had never taken a journalism class before, so a lot of the material that we covered was completely new to me. I learned so much about the importance of preserving this industry, and what it really takes to be a journalist during this day and age. I learned how to make my writing more muscular, the importance of collecting trustworthy sources, and the type of commitment that it really takes to be a journalist.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much is this wonderful course. I learned how about effective and honest journalism and its societal importance. I learned about journalism integrity, the failing of the news industry, and possible solutions to revive journalism. I learned from Professor Tash and a variety of guests, who were both incredibly knowledgeable and passionate.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: learning how to understand news articles and see a deeper meaning of the newspaper

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course allowed me to develop an understanding of how the evolution of the news has impacted national governance and local communities. I've gained knowledge about how objectivity, activism, and bias in the news affect the production of news. Further, I've learned about the lessons of journalism and how they apply to its future.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much more than I anticipated in this class. Firstly, I learned the value of just pure writing when it comes to consuming news and also producing content ourselves. Next, I learned about the varying dynamics at play that shape the way news is appreciated in our society. Finally, I learned the merit in being a more engaged, critical consumer of news, paying attention to biases that I may otherwise ignore.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so incredibly much about journalism and the state of journalism today. The discussions that stand out to me the most were about anonymous sources, partisan bias in the news industry, and the struggles of local news (and possible solutions). Apart from the knowledge I gained about journalism, I gained experience in writing papers with more personality or journalistic style than the academic papers I had been used to.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1). Strategies and skills to improve our writing
2). An idea of the various problems facing the journalism industry, and how these problems are being combated
3). What it looks like to be part of the journalism industry

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to completely reframe my consumption and understanding of both local and mainstream news. First, I learned that perspective matters, especially when thinking about how a story or article was composed from the interview process all the way to final publication. Multiple guest speakers discussed the importance of newsroom diversity in multiple facets. I also learned how to be more concise and analytical in my writing due to Professor Tash's emphasis on this skill.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about 1) the economic pressures that news media face, 2) the process by which newsroom decisions are made, and 3) the challenges that must be addressed for the survival of the news industry.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Tash was incredible. He made the classroom a welcome environment, encouraged healthy disagreement and asking questions, and provided examples of impactful journalism that resonated with both the academic and human elements of being a student.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Tash was AMAZING. He was a fantastic teacher who taught me a ton about his expertise. He created a kind, thoughtful class community that helped me learn. I thought that the guest speakers and readings were very interesting as well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Tash was incredible; his experience in the news field and connections with the industry were unparalleled. response_text: Professor Tash was warm, funny, engaging, and an incredible lecturer. response_text: I found the learning environment was heavily discussion based which is great except for that it is extremely nerve racking and excludes students who are too shy and lack confidence in their news intelligence.

response_text: My absolute favorite classes were those with guest speakers, especially when they were in person. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Tash is seriously a one of a kind professor. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Tash invited an incredibly high number of guest speakers to talk with us throughout the semester which was extremely beneficial. The days that we had guest speakers were conducted so that Professor Tash could ask some questions to get the class started, but would then turn it over to the students to drive the conversation forward. It was very easy to engage in the course, both through the way classes were structured but also due to the comfortable, respectful, and generally upbeat environment curated by Professor Tash. I also really appreciated the days when there were no guest lecturers and only Professor Tash was instructing. He makes the content so engaging and frequently involves the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think above all this course taught me the importance of thinking holistically due to the fact that it gave me a greater appreciation for the process of journalism. 2 other things I learned include the importance of being articulate and up-to-date on current affairs as well as the importance of listening and trying to understand opposing viewpoints to the greatest of extents. Without opposing viewpoints, we wouldn't have journalism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I've learned about the structures of newspapers - how they are divided and structured. 
I have learned about what good journalism is about - having courage, curiosity, and conviction when pursuing the truth.
I've learned about the different types of journalism, from objective news reporting to morning bulletins and opinion editorials, and how journalism can shape history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think critically about journalism and journalistic issues; how to research and form evidence-supported opinions; the values of journalism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Many of the topics we explored in this course are subjects I engage with daily in my role as news editor of The Chronicle. However, I enjoyed being able to hear the varying perspectives of my peers -- many of whom do not have extensive journalism backgrounds -- on some of the ethical questions I am consistently grappling with. The subjects we discussed included how news agendas are determined and why it's important to balance the slate of coverage on a given day, the importance of anonymous sources and dangers associated with using them too frequently, the obligation to thoroughly fact-check all reporting, and much more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how journalists think in regards to how they write, develop and produce news. One thing that I learned that stands out is that "facts are expensive, opinions are cheap." Being sure to take the time to research is important especially when crafting stories. I also learned the importance of clarity when writing and when reporting. And the importance of follow up questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the principles, economics and different mediums of journalism and how those coincide in a digital world that is constantly evolving.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The Role of Journalism in Society - What function does the news play? How has it shaped history? How do people interact with it? How has it changed?
Interdisciplinary thinking - How to approach complex challenges relating to justice and morality in a world constrained by business and personal influence 
Writing - How to edit our writing to ensure we make every word count and aren't redundant

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped a lot with my writing. Professor Tash took the time to read my paper, mark it up, and offer in-depth feedback.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my first journalism class, and I learned a ton about what the field is actually like, the types of stories produced, and how much variety there is in terms of long-form writing, TV broadcasting, podcasts, etc. This class also helped me work on my own writing skills through feedback on my essays, to just getting to read a vast collection of work over the semester and learn from those authors.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write in a less academic/more journalistic way, critically ask questions, and critically approach news.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had know and understood the threats that journalism faces, but I learned more about the complexity and evolution of these threats. It is an insight that I will carry with me as I consume media coverage for the rest of my life. In addition to refining my media literacy skills, I developed news ways of thinking when it comes to understanding the journalism industry. It is not just newspapers and TV outlets, but a blooming industry full of startups and people who simply want to share stories that are interesting to them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course did an excellent job of pushing students to think with perspective. As the semester continued on, I realized that in class discussion there was no right answer for anything we were discussing. Debating the moral ethics of journalism is no easy feat, and this class kept me engaged with the world around me, improving not just practical skills like my writing, but also helped me become more of a global citizen.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Incredible insight into the journalism world and profession, both through Professor Tash's experience and the amazing speakers
- Writing development: I have never had a professor take so much time and attention in helping us write better. 
- Hearing opinions and experiences differing from mine in respectful and productive ways

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot through the course of the semester. In fact, as my first and only journalism class of college, I feel grateful it was this one. I learned to think of news as a moral battleground, and received a well-lit tour of the horizon. I learned about partisanship in the news media and to be conscious of framing. I also learned about several important stories on an international, national and local level. Most importantly, I learned about what good journalism and writing looks like, and some tips and tricks to get there.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to analyze news academically, journalism ethics and morals, ways in which to help the journalism industry in the future

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to be a conscious consumer of the news, how to develop my journalistic writing skills, and how to analyze different news articles.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a tremendous amount about the anatomy of the news business from national to local scales, the shortcomings and bright spots of the industry, and what strong, proper journalism should look like. The guest speakers were phenomenal, shedding light on some of the most pivotal moments in the history of journalism and the impact they have on our world. It was especially interesting to hear these guest speakers speak about the actual process of launching an investigation or expose of a particular subject. This class puts into perspective the indispensable role journalism plays in our society, and that we as a citizenry have an obligation to do our part to preserve that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As a STEM major / not having a pub pol or journalism background, this class was super interesting! I learned about the complexities and challenges surrounding both news reporting and journalistic consumption. My favorite aspects dealt with the discussions surrounding the evolution of the news -- how topics such as fact-checking, polarization, and bias have changed drastically in the last decade and especially the last few years. The class was focused on present-day trends not history which I liked.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We covered a wide variety of topics in the fields of ethics and neuroscience. I learned about fundamental moral theories and how contemporary neuroscience research informs and complicates our understanding of agency, the penal system, and more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned different theories of how emotion and reason contribute to ethical decision-making, I learned a lot about psychopathy, and I learned about the distinction between the ethics of neuroscience and the neuroscience of ethics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I worked on my philosophical writing skills. Professor Hazelwood frequently laments the inaccessibility/pretentiousness of philosophical writing, so by constantly reading examples of good and bad prose or and argumentation, as well as writing our own philosophical papers, I left the class with a better understanding of how to write effective and readable philosophy papers.
2. I developed my argumentation skills. With two in-class debates worked into the curriculum, we had a chance to put our ideas to the test against our fellow students. This was a great exercise in research, argument preparation, and effective delivery of complex ideas. 
3. As an applied ethics course, this class helped bridge the gap between what we learn in classrooms and how we live outside school. The "Living Ethically" semester-long project, as well as the content of many of the readings, helped to demonstrate the link between philosophy and praxis and pushed me to reflect harder on my everyday habits.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: learned background philosophical concepts, learned approaches for evaluating the morality of my own actions and ghg emissions, and I learned about environmental philosophies such as the land ethic and ecofeminism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: knowledge in environmental ethics in various aspects (animal rights, restorative ecology, ecofeminism, value ethics, scientific methodology etc.)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I got better at knowing how to condense my points into a couple of sentences, instead of talking myself in circles.I learned how to craft arguments in a debate format. Specifically, when it comes to knowing how not to walk into traps, knowing when to let logical facilities talk for themselves, and appeal to an audience.I learned how to value when my perspective was not valued. There are times when it is important for all voices to be heard, but there are also times when arguments can only be made in the context of deep personal connection to a topic.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I feel that I gained a thorough understanding of all topics covered in the course, including (but not limited to) the arguments for and against novel ecosystems, the ways Indigenous practices can be incorporated into or complement Western scientific practices, and the implications of Aldo Leopold's 'Land Ethic.' In addition to the topics covered, my ability to discern arguments within philosophical writing was greatly enhanced, and I gained considerable experience formulating and expressing personal ideas and arguments orally.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The pacing of readings was very manageable. Professor Hazelwood changed the reading quiz structure at the midpoint of the semester in response to student feedback and I think the final structure was very effective. I liked the reading quizzes because as long as you did the reading, it'll be easy, but if you didn't, you'll do poorly, so I found them to be fair and manageable, but by including an option for annotations in lieu of a quiz this was very accommodating to students who do the readings but may just not be great test-takers. I loved the debates, they were fun. The living ethically assignment was a great way to tie class concepts to the outside world, which is kind of the whole point of the class so that was great too. Podcast was a cool chance to discuss class concepts further with a real expert in the field. Honestly every part of the class was great and felt like it had a very intentional reason for being included in the curriculum.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: regular readings and quizzes were good for ensuring engagement although still manageable. Instruction and in class discussions were very engaging

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was by far my favorite class of the semester, and a large part of that was due to Caleb. The learning environment was very welcoming. As someone who has never taken a philosophy class at Duke, I was worried that I would struggle to grasp the concepts and fall behind, but Caleb was a great teacher who explained the concepts well and made this class an enjoyable experience for me. I like that the class had a lot of different types of assignments, like the vlog assignment and the podcast assignment, that kept it interesting and pushed the boundaries of what I usually do in classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the quizzes at the beginning of each class were very valuable in making sure that everyone understood the material and came to class prepared to talk. I have been in a lot of classes where nobody actually does the reading, and the class ends up being the professor lecturing at the classroom, with very little room for actual deep and thoughtful discussion. The concept of having a quiz at the beginning of class is scary, and was at times stressful, but it did ensure that class ran very smoothly and was full of actual thoughtful conversation, as opposed to simply being a recap of the text.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Hazelwood's teaching style, while strong from the start, wonderfully adapted to the needs and culture of the class, greatly enhancing our ability to engage with and consume content. For example, Professor Hazelwood would provide reading assessments to determine our engagement with written material prior to class. After receiving feedback requesting a different form of assessment more accessible for those who may have testing anxiety (or anything else other than their understanding of the reading that would limit their ability to perform will on the quizzes), Professor Hazelwood immediately provided an option that allowed thorough annotations of the text to stand in for the reading assessments. I would love for the annotating option to be available in the future, and I found having both the quiz and annotation options to be very beneficial to my learning.Additionally, Professor Hazelwood's classroom management was perhaps the greatest asset for my learning. He expertly guided discussion, providing helpful information and direction where needed. I truly felt that my classmates and I were learning from each other and working towards 'the answers' (as much as there are in philosophy), and there was always a sense of accomplishment when we realized we had 'gotten' a point. Professor Hazelwood was excellent at affirming our viewpoints (or constructively and kindly pointing us in a different direction). The discussion based classroom, particularly due to Professor Hazelwood's involvement, really helped me to retain content, as it ensured that all of the students logically work through readings, rather than being handed a point or simply memorizing an argument structure.

response_text: See above comment about Nasher visit (that was awesome and so perfectly on topic for the class), Professor is a funny and engaging lecturer, every reading felt valuable and I learned something new from it, and there was plenty of discussions (as opposed to just lecturing) in each class. It was the epitome of intellectual exploration because sometimes we'd get on a tangentially related topic that everyone found interesting and we'd just see it through and keep discussing it even if it wasn't on the agenda, which meant we got to cover not just the assigned readings but all the different ideas students had that were sparked by the readings.

response_text: It was very stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings each week covered a topic I was either only vaguely aware of or that I had never encountered before. It was extremely refreshing to hear about new content, particularly from a variety of perspectives. Professor Hazelwood did an excellent job of curating our readings such that each week we often had papers 'for' the topic at hand and other papers 'against' which enabled us to engage with each other and have productive disagreements. I really appreciated hearing both sides of various debates, and it made class discussion much more intellectually stimulating. The content covered was challenging, but not beyond our capabilities, which also made the class more engaging. I also feel that Professor Hazelwood's personality contributed to students' engagement in the course. While serious when necessary, his warm demeanor and humor was excellent at drawing students in to participate and feel confident in presenting their viewpoints. While in the past I have been terrified of 'cold calling', on the somewhat rare occasion Professor Hazelwood used it, I felt empowered (rather than anxious) to share my answer or even admit my lack of understanding on a specific aspect of a topic. Professor Hazelwood did a great job of bringing everyone into the conversation and validating viewpoints, and very quickly our class time turned into free-flowing discussions where nearly everyone thoughtfully engaged several times.

response_text: It is a great course that I would definitely recommend it to everyone! The topics are really interesting and it is not hard to stay engaged with the material. Caleb makes the class an enjoyable experience that I looked forward to every week.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Best professor and learning environment that I have had at Duke, by a mile. Caleb makes everyone in the class feel like they are a person with something valuable to share to the conversation, as opposed to just a student consuming and regurgitating material. I don't think that I have felt as close to a group of students and professor as I have in this class. Caleb made me look forward to going to class twice each week, and I knew I was going to learn something new and hear different perspectives. Caleb also has a clear mastery of his craft, not only in the philosophy of biology, but in a speaker and philosophical interlocutor.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I highly recommend taking this course. It perfectly blends environmental science and philosophy, and is extremely informative and applicable to current events. Additionally, the class is very engaging (and fun). Personally, it was the coveted class of the semester that I really looked forward to attending. While there are a couple of group projects, I felt the work required for them wasn't stressful. Professor Hazelwood is a very fair grader, provides quality feedback to support his grading decisions, and is also willing to provide extra credit opportunities. It's definitely a class where the work you put in directly results in your grade, so as long as you do your assignments with good effort, you should do well in the course. Professor Hazelwood is also extremely helpful in office hours and provides thorough and detailed feedback.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned how to articulate the causes of the local news problem and how to describe the current circumstances and consequences of the local news problem.
2) I gained insight into how the current culture and environment of the journalism landscape incentivizes some journalists to plagiarize or fabricate facts in their stories, like Stephen Glass.
3) I'm now able to better emphasize in what way the journalist of an article is biased—and I can also avow that all journalists and people are biased in some way. For example, you can be biased towards the truth.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I learned how to think critically about the partisan divide in news and reframe my perspective. I learned how to read articles from opposing viewpoints with an open mind, and consider the bias in journalism. As someone who tries to  naively and impossibly avoid politics, I was also pushed out of my comfort zone to analyze partisan issues and consider the polarization of our news. Go narrow and deep.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I found that the course struck a perfect balance between class speakers and lecturing from Bill. And throughout both mediums, we were continuously empowered as students to ask questions and contribute to the discussion. Specifically, I think the class speakers are what helped to facilitate student learning. Not only did we hear from journalists and journalist experts, but we also heard from students like us who have ventured into journalism and encountered its problems from a fresh perspective. We heard from right-wing-leaning media owners. We heard from people who were impacted by right-wing media rabbit holes firsthand. Essentially, we got a variety of perspectives on the state of journalism, and this empowered us to use these testimonies to form our own conclusions.I also think all of the writing assignments clearly signaled relevance to the class, and they helped to apply and facilitate our learning. The individual prompts were also well-timed with what we were currently learning about or where we were in the course syllabus/timeline.

response_text: Everyone in the class was very eager to participate, which made for exciting conversations. I think that we all tended to have similar viewpoints, and I would have liked to see a devil's advocate more often?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The best part of the class was the guest speakers, the instructor, and the readings. All of those together are intellectually stimulating, but if you don't try to engage with all the material and people in class, you'll miss out on it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would encourage any student interested in this course to be unafraid to ask questions and steer class discussions toward topics relating to journalism that they're interested in learning about. This course is purposefully broad and covers a myriad of ethical issues in journalism. Continue to consume a variety of media and news sources as you go through the course, and use that knowledge to find out what you're passionate about further investigating. Then ask Bill or your peers!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about research methods in psychology, how this research can be implemented into our lives in tangible ways, and how the meaning of happiness can differ across cultures.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
