question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned ways to up regulate positive emotions and down regulate negative emotions

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned to think more critically about my happiness practices, learned to implement new positive psychology based practices in my life, and learned a lot about the theory behind many of the popular practices.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned many different insights on positive psychology and the ways to improve my own well being.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned new skills that I can use in my everyday life to improve my happiness and well being. I also learned about theories and studies that support these ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Since I've taken many psychology classes, I came into this course well-informed about studies, research processes, and other related concepts. However, I learned a lot more about the research part of psychology. Specifically, I was able to get a better understanding of the elements that go into validating research and having it approved. I also learned how to dissect research papers and draw out the important information embedded in those long texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned many methods and strategies to increase our happiness and regulate our emotions. Within lectures, we looked at studies and how we could use their results to increase happiness in our life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Evaluating strengths and weaknesses of existing scientific (psychological) theories, exploring ways to improve your subjective well being, reading research papers

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course we have learned and discussed important topics of positive psychology. Positive psychology is not discussed often in the current literature and there are several misconceptions. I have learned about 1) emotional regulation 2) imposter syndrome 3) and about living a psychologically rich life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about happiness theories and the barriers to happiness. I also gained more knowledge about empirical papers, including how to read and understand them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned many applicable skills and insights into how positive psychology works, as well as many useful tricks for increasing my well-being. These ranged from simple exercises to insights on habit formation and positive psychology as a research field.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: As a busy college student, I thoroughly enjoyed receiving tangible tips and practices that I was able to test out; I feel that this fosters more engagement with the course. Additionally, having activities outside of class allowed me to foster relationships with my classmates and professor. I went on a class outing to Serenity Farms, where we took a yoga class outdoors and enjoyed a delicious brunch. It was nice to connect with my professor outside of the classroom, and I learned things about my peers that I would not have otherwise.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: During Dr. Phillipsen's course, I adapted new ways of thinking about my life in academic settings and beyond. I became more cognizant of how my actions affect my environment in the long run. Overall, this course opened my eyes to exploring different arguments for different problems in our world without the expectation that there is only one correct answer.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to identify and explain an argument, what capitalism exactly is, and capitalism's impact on society and our planet.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Potential alternatives to capitalism 
- Capitalism impacts on progress and reform 
- Capitalism impacts on environment, politics, and social conditions

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to analyze arguments; history of capitalism; presenting ideas convincingly

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I DEVELOPED A WAY OF THINKING ABOUT THE world on a deeper scale than what I had previously. this course taught me to question why things are the way they are and what we will do next to combat destrucxtion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about the various mechanisms through which capitalism impacts our quality of life and degenerates the planet, including through expropriation, exploitation, starving the beast, the illusory concept of money, credit, and how salvery was a fundamental component of capitalism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Ways of thinking about human history and economics that challenge assumptions we make in society
Learning to properly develop an argument with all of its fundamental components
Learning about societies and communities often forgotten in society

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how capitalism has contributed to the injustices in our world today, including climate change, inequality, and exploitation of the vulnerable.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course gave me a completely different set of perspectives to view the world. It gave me a deeper understanding of the capitalist system we live in and how our choices and actions have ripple effects across the entire system and the world that is governed by it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Not only did I learn about capitalism, but I also learned how it is intricately tied with the health of our planet and how we think as individuals on a day to day basis. I learned how to read dense and influential readings such as New York Times Articles or the Communist Manifesto. Most importantly, I learned how there are so many things outside my career realm that I may be interested in studying and advocating for for the rest of my life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: critical way to view life - understand how capitalism influences every aspect of lifehow to engage with a reading. pay enough attention to it, to understand not just the gist of an article, but its central argument

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course gave me a new lens to view the entire world through. I think it brought some of the most critical aspects of life on earth to me in a different perspective than I had ever before considered.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was able to develop a comprehensive outlook on the economic, political, and social environment that we live in, and how capitalism as a system and ideology affects many aspects of them. I learned key ideas about how capitalism functions, and the pros and (many) cons to them in all of these spheres. We also delved into the historical origins of capitalism, how it manifests in the global landscape, and potential solutions for the problems it has created over time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about capitalism, how it works, and its implications for the world around us. It taught us to think critically and challenge our preconceived ideas about capitalism. And we learned how to analyse arguments and critically reflect on what claims and arguments are actually being made in specific readings.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class strengthened my critical thinking skills more than any other course in my time at Duke.  I learned to be more critical of the information I receive and about the historical background of our modern economic, social, and political systems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The greatest concrete skill I learned in this class is how to construct a good argument and how to tease out a good argument from other people.  I also learned how to question the current world and structures that we are usually blind to.  Lastly, I would say I really learned a lot historically about how our modern world came to be.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how capitalism is built on the brutal violence of the enclosure movement and slavery, relies on exponential GDP growth and material extraction from the planet, relies on overconsumption, planned and perceived obsolescence, the creation of imaginary needs. Importantly, capitalism is not just a "market system," it is a way of governing all life. It consumes every aspect of our lives, even ones that we wouldn't expect, such as our most personal and intimate relationships. I learned that we already have all the money, food, housing, healthcare, etc that we need for every human being to live a decent life, but these resources are fundamentally distributed such that the top 1% receives them all, while the poor suffer. We don't need more exponential GDP growth to solve the dysfunctions capitalism has created; we need degrowth.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the degrowth movement and learned about how capitalism is deeply related to the concept of exponential growth. I learned how to better identify arguments from scholarly sources and how to question and challenge notions in our society that we have simply been expected to accept blindly.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the foundations of the capitalist system. I learned about so many of the ways that capitalism is harming people today that I was previously unaware of. I learned about degrowth and care economics as feasible alternatives to our current system.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Phillipsen assigned reading assignments, which made the class more engaging as they encouraged everyone to read all the course material rather than breeze through it. Often, I find myself briefly looking through readings or only reading one of them, especially when I have a heavier workload. The assignment encouraged a closer read of the material, which encouraged further participation from my peers and me.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Philipsen is great and facilitates a very open and intellectually stimulating academic environment. I loved the class discussions and debates - it's seriously one of the favorite classes I've taken at Duke.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor facilitates a class discussion in an engaging way every class, jumping off of my classmates' points to elaborate and extend conversations. The class is truly conversational and personal, based on the readings we would do the night before for homework.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
I loved the cold call discussion/ how the class was a good mix of lecture and discussion (and that the lecture was never slides based, where we had to take notes...)
I liked the group cap projects a lot. Seeing so many of them and preparing one helped me understand how capitalism touches every aspect of life, and developed the muscle for being able to identify how.I also like how there isn't that much writing involved in this course. We have to write so many long, time consuming, and unmeaningful things in college. I appreciated how our assessments were very much tied towards inclass participation and sharing of ideas

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We had a an active discussion everyday. It was a very welcoming and supportive conversation. I would definitely keep the structure of the the day to day classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the argument exercises, as those not only improved my knowledge of the course material by having me engage with it consistently but also strengthened my argument skills (understanding and making arguments). This is a useful skill that I feel empowered to use in the future to improve our world through discourse. I thought the class discussions were usually productive, and the CAP presentations were always insightful and interesting to engage in.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor encouraged everyone to speak up and share their thoughts. We also had to keep up with the readings by writing an argument exercise, this helped to stay engaged and think critically of what claims are actually being made.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The seminar style oh the course facilitated learning, as we were all encouraged to have equal stake in learning and developing our thoughts.  As much work as it was, I would keep the reading reflection and randomized cold call system, as it keeps everyone accountable and responsible.  However, I would maybe add a strike system, or an unadvertised second chance for students who get called on when they are unprepared, just to add more grace and flexibility.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course required a lot of reading and argument assignments for each (2 for every class), a presentation, a paper, and a presentation on that paper.  The class was mostly discussion based, which I really enjoyed, and since you are likely to get called on to explain the argument in the reading, everyone is really engaged.  I will say, I think Professor Philipsen's ideas dominate the discussion, which is not necessarily a bad thing, but it would make for a better discussion if there was more push back from students (but I think this is honestly just a result of ignorance on the topics).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed that the class was an open discussion form, and that the professor would often want students to expand on their thoughts and answers. This isn't a class where "every answer is right" and you get a gold star just for speaking, which I really enjoyed. It allowed me to reflect on my thoughts and arguments and to not say things as statements, but to truly form an argument. This class made me think in entirely new ways through the readings that were assigned.I would KEEP most of the argument exercises, I do not think all 4 parts are necessary. I think that the quote and teasing out the central argument is important, but probably not parts 3 and 4 as they felt quite repetitive. I would definitely keep both the CAP and the Why capitalism matters Paper. Most of the readings were excellent and insightful, but I think at times some were repetitive. Having four every week was definitely overwhelming at times, but I'm ultimately glad to have read them.I would also keep the cold calling, it forced everyone to read the readings assigned and stay engaged throughout discussions. I also really enjoyed the format of the CAP

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Philipsen was amazing! He encouraged us to attend his office hours and was always excited to hear our perspectives and stories. I really enjoyed the CAP presentations specially--where I got to see how students processed everything that we were learning and examined a topic through a capitalist lens, highlighting how we truly live a life entrenched in capitalist values and expectations.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I learned a lot from the readings and from the CAP presentations and class discussions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are curious about capitalism, ethics, climate change, post-modern angst, or anything at all related, you should take this course.  It is one of the most intellectually and personally challenging courses at Duke, but it is so worth the journey.  Academically, the reading is demanding but the course load isn’t overwhelming, and it is spread well throughout the semester.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend this course - especially if you are feeling a little lost in your career direction and feel like there's a lot of pressure to go into the typical career paths.  This class is a lot of work, but it is so rewarding.  This is by far the most engaged I've ever been in a Duke class.  If you are interested in how we got to this place in the modern world, (environmental destruction, inequality, work, etc.) I highly recommend.  Just don't take it with a bunch of other high engagement courses.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to read and write a LOT. It might seem overwhelming but it's so worth it. Consider it a privilege to take this course. It's definitely a lot of work but the work is worth it and necessary to learn about the important topics covered

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I took this class as a spring semester senior and even though it was a lot of work (more so than the typical class one expects to take in their last semester of Duke), I am SO SO thankful I took this course. This course has allowed me to challenge and reckon with my preconceived beliefs about capitalism. Not only that, I am now better at arguing what I believe are some of the "good" capitalism has brought and the bad and how we are now living in an epoch where we need to move on and create a better societal system that aligns more so with our values and natural world.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1. Dr. Hy was incredible at creating a warm and welcome environment—they began the semester establishing a community agreement, and the agreement of ‘recognizing the both/and’ (i.e., recognizing that multiple realities can be true at once, and therefore having this foster constructive and safe dialogue across differences) really resonated with me for the rest of the semester (and will beyond this semester)
2. Dr. Hy’s (and Carina, our TA’s) emphasis on progress over perfection—even if our submissions weren’t perfect, they encouraged us to submit our assignments anyway. As a lifelong perfectionist, still being recognized for ‘work in progress’ and my thoughts and writing in ‘first draft form’ helped massively in making me feel more confident and able to articulate my semi-formed thoughts, which really helped me engage with the course more—I really, really appreciated this

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The communities of practice on Wednesdays was a very interactive and effective way of both discussing and digesting the weekly material. I think one of the strengths of this course was the consistent structure that allowed students to measure progress in understanding from week to week. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
Aspects that made the class stimulating:
1. Our incredible guest speakers, which featured experts, fellow students, and Hart Leadership alumni—it was so cool being able to interact directly with the authors of our readings!
2. Systems Change Project, where we were grouped by areas of research interest (e.g., tech policy, healthcare equity, etc.)—this allowed us to apply our learnings directly to an area of interest tied to our summer research as well, which really helped us prepareCould’ve been more stimulating:
1. I also really, really loved our class discussions! That being said, the format for the first half of the semester also began to feel a little repetitive (every Monday, we’d discuss each reading first in our small groups and then with the class, and every Wednesday we’d do the same thing with a different group (‘communities of practice’)). This was before we began our guest speaker lessons, though—that really elevated our learning, and made each lesson super interesting! Maybe spreading the guest speakers out more throughout the semester would help overcome this.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Listening to different political perspectives on the election and having civil discourse.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I went into this class with a very minimal understanding of politics and the process gone through during elections. Through this seminar, I gained much insight on the two parties including the policies of both the parties and the thinking behind parties when trying to levy support during an election. I also gained helpful skills on how to debate with classmates and consider opposing views. Lastly, I learned interdisciplinary analysis for example looking at the economic problems that influences the politics of the presidential election.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The main thing I learned was the skill of having a civil conversation with someone I don't agree with. Within that,
1. conversing to understand rather than to make my own argument
2. listening actively
3. weaving together empirical evidence, news headlines, and my personal experiences to further a point

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about the US, the electorate, this current election, and elections in general. This course helped me develop my critical thinking skills about campaigns, their actions, and their intentions. I feel like I can now identify voting patterns based on demographics and the positionality of voters. I feel more connected with the US and the issues that compel people to vote the way that they do.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- I learned how to engage with political perspectives that differ from my own in a manner that is thoughtful and oriented toward mutual understanding.
- I also learned how to critically evaluate policies and political rhetoric through multiple partisan angles, rather than just my worldview. 
- I learned how demographic backgrounds do--and sometimes, do not--shape how salient different policies are to certain people.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I've developed the skill of analyzing and understanding different perspectives of voters in America. This course has helped me look at every opinion with true open-mindedness.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In Nasser Hussain's class, I learned to deepen my critical analysis and communication skills throughout learning about the election and the emerging developments. While analyzing the both campaigns on the Democratic and Republican side, I took off our partisan lenses and I learned to use and refine my bipartisan approach through critically evaluating the merits of each candidate in a non-bias way. Insights on the institutions we have today and how ideals from the last 2 decades have embedded themselves from within was fascinating.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the class structure of Professor Hussain talking for about 15 minutes at the start of class, weaving together the news events from the week into a theme or narrative focus for the day's discussion, and then opening up the floor for us to respond in a free-flowing discussion. The conversations never halted.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the open format of the class where Professor Hussain introduced an idea at the beginning and the rest of the class was time spent responding, with shifts based on the agenda. I also love the contemporary nature, the prediction assignment, and the campaign video assignment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Hussain did an excellent job ensuring that our discussions had a balanced representation of political views. I enjoyed the roundtable-style discussions and how he encouraged every student to participate. In future years, I recommend keeping the class to this small, intimate size and keeping the lessons discussion/debate-centric.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Hussain was phenomenal. He encouraged us to contribute meaningfully in class with thorough analysis of trends and assigned readings. Contribution was fairly open-ended, and empowered us to lead the class in the direction of our choosing (within reason).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the learning approach of conversation.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor facilitated various political discussions and forced us to take both sides and argue on both points of view. Additionally, he had very good assignments included making a campaign ad (so we could see how campaigns strategize to influence voters), and analyze the campaigns with an essay.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Hussain has done an amazing job of ensuring our class is open to every student and their unique opinions and perspectives. Through the weekly assignments, this course has also opened me to different historical media which has enriched my knowledge in many ways.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Nasser Hussain took a very balanced approach towards ensuring the pedagogical structure gave a voice to every person in the room. His hands-on approach did a great job in ensuring the class was on track when we veered into off-topic conversations, as well as letting us have independent discussions amongst ourselves. He would talk for about 20 minutes on the topic of the day, that we got through a detailed syllabus, and the rest of the time is allocated towards a mix of both approaches.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If there is another presidential election, I would highly recommend the class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

You'll learn to survey different types of Americans and what shapes their philosophies and worldviews.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would tell them not to take it. I think they could get most of what was taught in the classroom online, in the news, or on social media. There were a couple interesting readings but not many.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be ready to get outside of your political comfort zone. This course is eye opening but requires self awareness and going beyond what may seem right or wrong politically before you start this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend this class to anyone interested in politics and political strategy! I really loved the discussion-centered nature of the course. Just be prepared for conversations that rigorously analyze policies from a medley of viewpoints, which can sometimes feel uncomfortable when they come into conflict with your worldview.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a great opportunity to sharpen your political literacy. I grew a ton over the course of this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: A really interesting class, more so when it overlaps with the United States elections

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Have an open mind.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I highly recommend this political policy class to any student considering it in the future. It offers an invaluable opportunity to engage with complex and pressing policy issues such as modern day division and the trouble of bipartisanship in our society while developing a strong foundation in both theory and practice. They go through a variety of ideologies and gets you comfortable with both sides of the spectrum to evaluate its merits in total. The professor is a charismatic and wonderful person who you could grab a coffee or a lunch with. Even if it's MMA, Football or the dating market, he is well-versed in a lot of topics that we keep scratching our heads over. He makes the class enjoyable, even to anyone who isn't involved or interested in politics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will expose you to different political perspectives to gain tolerance and widen your perspectives.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Come into each discussion with an open mind and be ready to be flexible. The conversations move quickly and take a lot of turns. If you aren't prepared for your worldview to be challenged and your perspective broadened, I would sit this class out.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: evaluation of corporate influence on society, specific stakeholders (employees, areas they occupy, etc.), and the individual. saw these applications in case studies: textile factories, NC with smithfield farming, duke, prisons, etc. also learned how these systems were created in the first place, and the different schools of thought on how to address corporatization (friedman, and then interpretations of CSR, how the EU has addressed it through the Global Compact, etc.)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked the class facilitations; they were so engaging and so personal. I really enjoyed essay 2 as well, reflecting on what hope means for me and what hope means in our discussions of business and human rights. One of my favorite moments in this class, one that I have shared with family and friends, is when we talk about what we each hope for in a circle. It's these moments of engaging discussions and sharing personal experiences and viewpoints that make this class so memorable.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the articles that we read, and the videos that we watched in class. I think documentaries are such an amazing way to get students passionate about the subject material. I also thought the student facilitations were a great idea, and made it interesting to learn. I also loved writing about hope - giving people the time to write creatively is super important. I was liked discussing topics that were relevant to our own lives, and also Duke. I also loved the speakers we had.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the course was structured in an extremely beneficial way. Professor K made the class really welcoming (and I got to meet a lot of new students) because we opened the class for just a few minutes with an opening question. At the beginning of the course we read a lot of foundational articles/essays that solidified my understanding of Buisiness and Human rights and I really felt like I was able to understand them because we were giving class time (in small groups and whole class) to reflect and work through the arguments (and counter arguments, and flaws in arguments). it was always engaging, especially as the end of the class moved to student-led facilitation. We had such engaging readings and class time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: In terms of the learning environment, Professor Katzenstein has a genuine and candid way about her that made me naturally comfortable to share my opinions and analysis of sometimes sensitive or touchy topics in BHR. In this regard, I think she is the perfect instructor for this course and that not many others could carry the classroom in the same way. I'd keep everything about the class the same - the open discussion, small group discussion, and community partner aspects.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: I learned about storytelling techniques, I learned about significant change agents, and I reflected deeply on my experiences.

Critical thinking around different storytelling practices
storytelling skills

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class is by far the best class I have taken at Duke! Professor Admay challenges us to develop our critical thinking and close reading skills through a comprehensive list of TDQs (Thinking Development Questions) before class. The class discussions are always intellectually stimulating and open my perspectives to new areas that I have never thought about before. I have developed a much stronger critical thinking lens and have learned to look at issues from multiple perspectives with more maturity.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Dichotomy of humanities-communications style storytelling, ethics of storytelling in advocacy settings and what it means to tell someone else's story, using stories for advocacy work and to enact policy change, dissecting the messaging inside of memoirs about development work, critical thinking around what it means to create development policy that best suits the needs of communities, accompaniment and what it means to work alongside communities, rather than "for" as an outsider (nothing without us about us is for us).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: -Close reading, how stories and narratives shape minds, perspectives (the soft powers of storytelling), tangible impacts of “edutainment” and how to send those messages in an open minded way, the dangers of development work, but also hope for the world and the light that stories provide

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- distinctions between humanities and communications methods of storytelling and interrogating why one method may be chosen over the other 
- how storytelling is done using different platforms and methods -- videos, prose, graphic novels, guest visitors, etc
- critical analysis and thinking of who is telling a story, why they are telling the story, on whose terms is a story being told

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Tools of artistry : looking at devices storytellers employ strategically to tell stories (juxtaposition, irony, humor, etc.) 
Stories for Communication vs Stories for Humanities
(Ways of thinking) the dangers of a single story - really took to heart

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I developed the ability to analyze the shortcomings of stories that marginalize voices and impose narratives of what development “should be”.
2. I increased my capacity to listen to stories with empathy and curiosity as to truly understand the intentions of artists and classmates.
3. I was able to separate my policy brain focused on outcomes and results to a humanities appreciation for good stories and for understanding individuals.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course provided the opportunity to dive deep (in a way we don't always have the chance to in fast-paced policy oriented classes), to evaluate stories and their impact (both perceived and intended), and consider the implications for telling and elevating stories for social change (particularly when they are not our own).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have learned how to effectively analyze media and understand the importance of centering people in storytelling. I have learned the value of fully sharing and receiving stories.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved that we were mixed grad and undergrad. These are friendships I will carry with me, and it was so valuable to have different generations of perspective. It made me feel more connected with younger communities I may serve in my career and led to great networks, mentorship, and learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the half graduate/ half undergraduate structure, as well as the active class discussions. Admay always pushes us to go a step further and to question our ideas and dig deep

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: Admay did a great job creating a culture of discussion. From making name tags to sharing stories with each other, we built rapport fairly quickly. I think the discussion style, the short stories we told, and TDQs beforehand were all helpful to promote a great learning environment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought the class activities were amazing, especially the story exchange and the guest practicioners. so was the teaching your own class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Admay is the best professor I have had at Duke. She is charismatic, compelling, extremely knowledgable and her passion for the subject area is contagious. She puts an incredible amount of time into preparing each lesson, pouring hours to think through the guiding questions for each class discussion which prepares me well for each class. I also love the participatory culture of the class, where every student is invited to speak and share their thought without hesitation or fear of any kind. Professor Admay has fostered an incredible collaborative culture in the classroom such that everyone has become friends. I have never seen this kind of class environment elsewhere.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Admay structured cooperative debates around the different works of storytelling methodologies that we read, forcing us to think critically about what we disagreed with or agreed with and why and also to defend our points or change our minds in conjunction with out peers. She also facilitated our learning by posting very detailed readings and instructions with thought and discussion questions on her Sakai page for each class, giving us a preview of what class would be like the following day to structure our thoughts around themes and takeaways. Most of all, Admay allowed us to put our learning into practice by allowing us to teach a "new narrative" that we would have the class read/watch/listen to and then dissect together to see how it used storytelling modalities to advocate for policy change or raise awareness for a social issue.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Admay is a brilliant instructor, her being just radiates compassion and genuine care. I really loved the class debates we had in class, I found that those were particularly intellectually stimulating (embodying different characters in Living Poor, HONY vs. Cunningham) and really made you consider and reflect upon different perspectives and arguments to form your own opinions. I also loved all the New Narrative classes at the end, and felt that everyone did an amazing job — those narratives added so much to class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course consisted of multiple reading and listening materials that fed into a broader theme related to story-telling that we focused on in class. Course materials were complemented by New Narratives that we engaged in -- ideated and facilitated by classmates to present new thinkings or projects or solutions to the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Admay’s personal attention to all of our needs as students was the most meaningful part of this course. She continually asked us what we wanted to learn and created space for new narratives. She invited reflection and constructive feedback (like the survey towards the middle of the semester). It felt like we co-created this class with her and created our own culture.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: More so than any course I've ever taken, I am leaving this class with a sense of community. This is the only course I've taken where I know every student's name and feel like I know them deeply. The size of this course and the varying styles of discussion and engagement (guest speakers, group work, readings, videos, poetry, etc.) was conducive to creating an inclusive and collaborative learning environment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course facilitated my learning by being structured in a way that felt comfortable and meaningful. Many of the assignments were geared towards improving our understanding of concepts.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

response_text: Admay was stimulating. She pushes you to think of new things and ground your thoughts in our text.

response_text: The class is extremely intellectually stimulating for it challenged me to think in ways that I have never imagined before. This stimulating environment stems from Professor Admay's dedication to her students inside and beyond the classroom, as well as the comfortable, collaborative environment that she fosters for everyone to freely speak their mind. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Most of all — Admay as an instructor makes you think, makes you care, and if you don’t care about the material/readings of the class, she’ll make you want to care! The guest speakers were also really incredible. Lyndon Harris in particular, with Right Here, Right Now, is going to be something that sticks in my mind for the rest of my life. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: multiple materials to consume, insightful guest speakers, a range of topics that all center human flourishing and well-being -- these components and focuses made the class extremely intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Stories from many different perspectives in conjunction with looking at the how (strategies) people were telling stories and for what purposes. The new narratives from my peers were stimulating and an excellent example of putting the skills and analytical ways of thinking into practice that started generative conversation. Admay,s skills in creating this environment are invaluable.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I loved how Admay relied on creating “sticky” points for us to hold onto from stories. These created the foundations for threads to emerge. response_text: The variety of types of stories we read and the variety of types of conversation made this course incredibly stimulating. You really need to sit deeply with the material so I found this class more stimulating that other classes I've taken at Sanford because I really felt like I had to consume everything to make sure I showed up fully present for class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: One aspect of this class that made it stimulating was open discussion and having guest speakers who wonderfully contributed to our class objectives. Having conversations that challenged my way of thinking and encouraged me to use a new lease in story telling was transformational.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is one of the more artistic and creative course you will take at Sanford, and you need to enter with an open mind and a willingness to be authentic and flexible. You will be valued as both a student and as a person in this course and you will leave it with meaningful relationships. If you want to apply the skills you learn in this course, you will have to think deeply about the specific things you are learning and what they mean for YOUR process. This process is subjective and the class will be, too.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: 100% take this course but be ready to read and push yourself.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You might complete the course without knowing what you actually learned but you will think differently after taking the course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You get out of this class what you put in. If you engage with an open-mind and are ready to think this class will serve you. Admay, is a great person to know and a great person to have in your corner.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Admay is an amazing person, and you will have a bunch of fun in this class! You will learn more nuances and less hard and fast skills.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE THIS CLASS 100%! You will regret if you do not take this class!! This is truly a life-changing class (something that I have never said before), and I came to Duke exactly for this type of classes.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: THIS CLASS IS A MUST TAKE FOR ANYONE WHO WANTS TO DO POLICY, LAW, OR ADVOCACY WORK OF ANY KIND. Admay is a supremely engaging instructor who provides detailed feedback, interesting class material, and runs her classroom with immense love and grace. I learned so much and I know I will be a better lawyer, policy advocate, and general human being as a consequence of the critical thinking I did in this course. Be prepared to work hard, as Admay can be a hard grader, but it will only make you a better thinker and writer.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course!! Regardless of whether you want to go into policy or development work (I don’t plan on it), this class and Professor Admay has so much to offer you. You will also get to connect with so many people who come from all walks of life — this class truly ends up feeling like a tight-knit community by the end of the semester. Take it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don't be deterred by this course's "Public Policy" label! Although we spend time linking concepts to policy and macro-level development ideas, the class has really been about how we move through this world as humans and how we listen to and process stories -- which are all fundamentally about understanding human nature and having a better concept of how we want to contribute as empathetic and caring individuals to the societies of which we are part. This course is applicable regardless of your major, would highly recommend.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! Admay is someone you want on your team. The relationships you build in this course under Admay’s leadership are for a lifetime.  Your mind and your community will change for the better.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Admay truly cares about her students and wants them to succeed. She is a mentor that you can always go to if you need help. The class is pretty easy workload, and it requires having an open mind and willingness to critique and co-create the class. If you do those two things, this class will be a meaningful experience for you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: With the right level of engagement on your behalf - this class can be transformative. Take advantage of the opportunity to learn from a combination of undergraduate and graduate students. Take advantage of the intentional community that comes out of 1) the nature of this course and its materials and 2) the community that Admay works so hard to create.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend future student to take this course! If you are are passionate about international development, human rights, stories, and curious of how all of the concepts connect; then this is the class for you!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The difference between empathy and sympathy, the power of stories from both an advocacy and humanities perspective, how to frame concepts in the context of development to name a few.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the specific aspects of a "good" story, how to use story to promote sustainable development, and how to deconstruct a story for meaning and purpose.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Admay truly went above and beyond. From the very first day, I was impressed by how much she already knew about each of us, and throughout the course, she continuously integrated our ideas into the class. That made the learning experience feel incredibly personal and intentional.Overall, we learned the deep importance and transformative power of storytelling as a tool to help build a world where every living being can flourish. Storytelling is one of the most powerful tools for change because it’s deeply embedded in how humans have shared knowledge for millennia—and because it speaks directly to the emotional part of the brain that shapes decision-making.Through this course, I learned:
1.  How to use artistic storytelling techniques and frameworks to craft narratives for social impact.
2. The science behind why stories move people and how they can shape attitudes, behaviors, and policies.
3. How to identify and counteract harmful or dominant narratives by telling stories that align with our values and vision for a better world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was the only class I've taken in Duke that challenged my way of thinking, I would have multiple "aha" moments in the course related to fundamental aspects of society, change, power, etc. that are missing in every other course.Insights- understanding parallel ways of communication, their intention, impact, power, strengths, weaknesses, and how to structure them. I feel incredible empowered to use this information to frame policy, and feel like I am walking away with value that all students should be getting because I took this course.Methods/skills- this is the only class where we consistently analyze and really go deep into the underlying ideas, values, impacts, and structure of development. Even though it was an international development course, the application is across all sectors because most policy we're interested in (schools, transpiration, etc.) is touched by development and is at its core, a subsection of development. I found the class to be highly relevant to every aspect of policymaking, and the process of metacognition, reflection, and analysis is unmatched. The skills and methods in ways of thinking I learned and practiced in this class are the most valuable aspect of my MPP so far.Knowledge- I learned so much about how a topic I was interested in- communicating policy- has a wide field around it that has very intentional goals and being able to really get exposure to the macro-level landscape that then shapes our ideas as policy makers that we're exposed to in the world, and then understanding how to TRULY analyze those options and expand, was a highlight. In prep for our final paper, we reviewed key parts of our work and key readings to reflect on and were asked which reading we would remove from the syllabus- I did not have a single one I would remove because I was so grateful for all that I learned. Meanwhile, in other courses you can get an A without ever doing the reading b/c the readings don't add anything and the professors just ask for you to spit back what they told you. Admay actually teaches you how to think, teaches you how to analyze, reflect, meaningfully synthesize, etc. and those skills are the kind that make leaders, create change, and actually influence policy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to look critically at development, its definitions, and its leading thinkers
2. What makes a good story and how to use stories strategically to convince stakeholders
3. How to value the gift of a story from someone else and how to treat someone's story as a gif

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned to analyze stories/narratives in the development space to identify effective strategies for advancing specific values, ideas/beliefs, agendas, and policies. 
2) I learned to craft my own stories/narratives employing these tools, refining my skills while drawing from resources shared by past cohorts and my current classmates.
3) I learned to put design my own class session around a strategic story/narrative of my choosing and integrate it into our learning outcomes and the other materials on the syllabus.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a deeper knowledge of how to use storytelling and storytelling devices to encourage societal and policy change. I learned what “development” means and how to engage in it in an ethical, self decentered way

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned to distinguish between listening with sympathy and listening with empathy—understanding that true empathy involves setting aside my own perspective to fully hear and honor another person’s experience in their own words.
2. I gained insight into the difference between message-signaling and humanitarian storytelling styles, recognizing how the latter values the listener’s autonomy in making meaning.
3. I developed a more critical and nuanced understanding of concepts like “development” and “empowerment,” realizing that these terms are more complex than often portrayed by global institutions and that I have a lot more learning and thinking to do.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to think strategically about storytelling by understanding audience, intention, and impact.  I gained insight into how values and identities shape stories—and how to center authenticity and the nature of being human

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to read all things well and understand intentional artistic decisions across genres. I learned teaching and deep listening skills, so many valuable personal skills. And finally, I learned the content of these stories, what I didn’t know before— a new way of thinking about development, about poverty.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Loved the story exchange, the guest speakers, new narratives, and honestly just the super personal way Admay teaches the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Admay is amazing. She will really push you to think and go deeper with the materials, which I appreciated. The class was incredibly collaborative and engaging.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Admay is incredibly intentional in crafting every single class. She genuinely thinks through how each of us might interact with the material, and that level of care, detail, and mindfulness is something I’ve never experienced before. Her intentionality made a huge difference in how we connected with the content and with each other.She is also very thoughtful in the feedback she provides on our assignments and creative work, always encouraging, constructive, and grounded in a deep understanding of our intentions. Beyond the classroom, she’s generous with her time and always willing to listen, whether during office hours or after class.Another key strength of this course is the diversity of students it brings together, undergrads, grads, people from many cultures and belief systems. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The TDQs to guide our reading, and making every reading meaningful were huge. Admay does NOT want to waste your time, and so she'll give you a one-paragraph excerpt out of a chapter if that's the part she wants you to learn instead of assigning the whole thing and only referencing one point.Admay really emphasizes it being our class, catering to our needs, seeing what we already know/what we want to know, and really goes above and beyond to ensure that the class is helpful and powerful for all of us. When we create our own lessons for the class, she requires so much intentionality and focus in prep, ensuring that all student projects are valuable and also teaching us what kind of intentionality we should bring to any presentation/workshop where we're asking for others' precious time. She's incredibly thoughtful, reflective, intentional, and smart. How she thinks, and what she says, are so valuable.I also really love the human aspect of this course, Admay emphasizes community and wellbeing and it really, really shows. She does not waste our time, she does not give us busy work, and all the assignments are intentional. She is understanding and flexible, open to new ideas of how things should go, and strikes the ideal teacher balance of firm, high expectations and loving, warm support to get there.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Admay. A story is a gift, how can we honor that gift. A person who teaches you about stories is also an invaluable sacrifice that I will carry with me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was very stimulating because of how deeply it connected personal reflection with broader ideas of social change. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Admay has really done her work learning how to teach and how people learn, so you do the readings + pay attention and you WILL learn. If you sit on your computer and don't read, you might not, but TRUST me when I say it's not difficult in terms of time or energy to do, and the way this class grows your thinking brain is truly stellar. Admay talks about metacognition, which gives us the skills to learn how to learn instead of always depend on others to guide us. It's so rare that professors do this, and it's so powerful.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was SO stimulating! The discussion, the buy-in from my classmates, the tough questions we addressed, the adaptive learning -- all of it was incredibly engaging and I learned so much in this course that I will apply to the rest of my policy career.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The vast and diverse amount of material that we covered was great.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The parts of the class on storytelling were the most intellectually stimulating, such as breaking down how stories work to make us think and feel certain ways. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made the class stimulating was the freedom to explore meaningful topics through our own creative lenses. It encouraged me to think deeply about not just what I wanted to say, but how and why I wanted to say it.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
