question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class, and do the readings!!!!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I’d definitely recommend this course to a future student who is open to trying something different. It’s a great opportunity to slow down, reflect, and connect, not only with a diverse group of classmates, including younger students and MMPs, but also with yourself. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: YOU HAVE TO TAKE THIS COURSE! And then, please please please put your computer away and do the readings. Admay doesn't waste your time, will help you if you ask, and your brain WILL grow in key ways even if you feel like you already know about a lot of the classic constraints and critiques of development, or if you think storytelling isn't "technical" or "quant" enough. Leaders are able to shape the world, and this class helps you understand both how to do it yourself and how others are doing it around you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Read the assigned readings! They are the backbone of the class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Same as above, this is a must take course for anyone who wants a fuller understanding of the policymaking process. While policy development, implementation, and analysis is important, the stories/narratives we construct around these policies are just as important. In some ways, this class builds on 803/804 Policy Analysis I/II by allowing us to see how values, ideas/beliefs, agendas, and policies are advanced in practice. To me, this course is essential for anyone who is wanting to engage in policymaking in today’s age because it caters to the heart of how we relate to each other as human beings: through story.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The power to make meaning out of stories resides with the listener—how much you get out of the class depends on how much you trust Admay's teaching process.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: With the nightly reading homework and responses, I was able to get better at reading complex texts written by different authors. I was able to think about how other religions/cultures think about evil, and learn how to use my voice in areas I was not an expert in.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like how the grade is made up of reading HW, attendance and 2 essays. It makes it easier for me to focus in on the material and stay engaged. I'd recommend arranging the chairs in a circle to facilitate better discussion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the structure of the course, reading and then discussing in class. I thought most of the readings were very helpful and important, but having less readings and more time to discuss specifics in class would be more helpful in my opinion. I would've liked more engaging conversations about the material rather than simply going question by question to give answers.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Class discussions were extremely helpful to my understanding of the text. I am certain that I would not be able to distill useful takeaways from the text on my own. Professor Kadivar is very knowledgeable and does his best to help us when we are confused about more confusing philosophical principles. I also think structuring the class discussions around the reading response questions also allowed us to feel that homework was useful and had utility, unlike other classes where it feels like doing the homework doesn't help prepare us for class at all.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the overall interaction with this class. This was a close class with fewer students that allowed everyone to be engaged, answer questions, and interact with each class.

I did find formulating my own arguments on the content to be challenging in midterm papers and the final paper, but I think that is simply a testament to the nuance that Professor Kadivar emphasizes in class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made this class stimulating were the constant questions about morals, ethics, and how one thought about the problem of evil, beliefs, and things alike. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I also learned how to write an argumentative philosophical paper.
